\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 16 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png","linkMd5":"cd88b345192683b387cbe527476f0778","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","destWidth":754,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7622,"destBytes":12106,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-1.gif?width=448&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-1.gif":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-2.gif?width=624&height=332&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-2.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn46@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-58-992_c3b518574590b7e0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn.png?width=624&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn81@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-00-262_69621f623395b610.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-3.png?width=624&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn81@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-52-211_5e087d386743bb52.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-2.png?width=624&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn24@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-51-788_957d695f2ebfdd40.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-1.png?width=624&name=How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn11@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-51-489_7283af8f28efd6f7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20To%20Use%20Hashtags%20on%20LinkedIn.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn8@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-58-903_c0def32074d8f984.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-50-01-107_85ce3eb0b1d04252.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fuse-hashtags-on-linkedin&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn11@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-51-586_bc03cff127f5d300.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370090},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How to Size & Design Your Facebook Cover Photo or Video [Templates]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-cover-photo-size-best-practices","description":"<p>When people arrive at your Facebook Page, where do you think they first look?</p> \n<p>I'll give you some hints. It's a visual piece of content that sits at the top of your Page. Its dimensions are 820 pixels wide by 312 pixels tall. It takes up almost a quarter of the screen on most desktop browsers.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>That's right — it's your Facebook cover photo.<br><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=69cf0017-d61c-4fc6-b644-fe344f8d6330&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Templates: Facebook Cover Photos for Businesses\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/69cf0017-d61c-4fc6-b644-fe344f8d6330.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Sometimes called your Facebook banner, this graphic is one of the most noticeable parts of your Page. It's therefore crucial that you follow Facebook cover photo best practices and optimize your cover photo for the right dimensions.</p> \n<p>A cover photo can take your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5492/how-to-create-a-facebook-business-page-in-5-simple-steps-with-video.aspx\">Facebook Business Page</a> to the next level. Whether you're using Facebook to generate leads, close your next sale, or create a customer community, knowing how to make and optimize your cover photo is very important. And when you consider the Facebook cover photo dimensions above, it can be tough to balance creativity with the requirements of the platform.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-cover-photo-dimensions.jpg?width=690&amp;name=facebook-cover-photo-dimensions.jpg\" alt=\"Facebook cover photo dimensions (with a green space denoting what's visible on both mobile and desktop)\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>As you can see from the figure above, there's a lot of space that you can risk cutting off of your final cover photo design depending on where your audience is viewing the page — mobile or desktop.</p> \n<p>Therefore, it's best to focus the brunt of your content in that green space, where everyone can see your cover photo regardless of the device they're using.</p> \n<p>Need help getting started? Below, you'll find Facebook cover photo templates, and just as many best practices to guide you when designing your brand's banner artwork. At the bottom of this post, find out how to turn your cover photo into a cover video, and check out a few examples to see what others have done.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>Facebook Cover Photo Best Practices</h2> \n<h3>1. Do abide by Facebook's cover photo guidelines.</h3> \n<p>It seems like a no-brainer, but obeying <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/www/276329115767498?rdrhc\">Facebook’s cover photo guidelines</a> is crucial to your Facebook Page existing in the first place. I'd highly suggest reading through the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/page_guidelines.php\">full Page Guidelines</a>, but here are a few important things to keep in mind for your Facebook banner:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Your cover is public.</li> \n <li>Covers can't be deceptive, misleading, or infringe on anyone else's copyright.</li> \n <li>You can't encourage people to upload your cover to their personal timelines.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you get caught violating the above terms, Facebook could take action against your Page. And while Facebook doesn't explicitly say what will happen if you violate their cover photo guidelines, it's probably not smart to get your Facebook Page taken down over a cover photo infraction, so read the guidelines in full and adhere to them.</p> \n<h3>2. Do make sure your Facebook cover photo size is right.</h3> \n<p>As stated at the beginning of this article, the best Facebook banner size is 820 pixels wide by 312 pixels tall for computers, and 640 pixels wide by 360 pixels tall on mobile devices.</p> \n<p>You don't want to spend all this time designing a cover photo only to have it look weird when you upload it to Facebook.</p> \n<p>If you upload an image smaller than those dimensions, Facebook will stretch it to fit the right size, as long as it's at least 399 pixels wide and 150 pixels tall.</p> \n<p>If you want a no-hassle way to make sure your cover photos are the right size, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/facebook-cover-photo-templates?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-cover-photo-size-best-practices&amp;hubs_post-cta=download%20our%20pre-sized%20template%20for%20Facebook%20cover%20photos%20here\">download our pre-sized template for Facebook cover photos</a>.</p> \n<h4 style=\"text-align: center;\">Featured Resource: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/facebook-cover-photo-templates\">Facebook Cover Photo Templates</a></h4> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/facebook-cover-photo-templates?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;__hstc=233546881.7e6d2aead10f5c676f7d722052b8ea0d.1615235731484.1615235731484.1615235731484.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615235731484&amp;__hsfp=512429567&amp;_ga=2.212232084.1006362716.1615235730-1953554424.1615235730\"><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen_Shot_2021-01-25_at_2.52.22_PM-removebg-preview.png?width=400&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2021-01-25_at_2.52.22_PM-removebg-preview.png\" alt=\"Facebook Cover Photo Templates\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></strong></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/facebook-cover-photo-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom&amp;__hstc=233546881.7e6d2aead10f5c676f7d722052b8ea0d.1615235731484.1615235731484.1615235731484.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615235731484&amp;__hsfp=512429567&amp;_ga=2.245059461.1006362716.1615235730-1953554424.1615235730\">Download the Free Templates</a></p> \n<h3>3. Don't worry about the old '20% text' rule, but still try to stay visual.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://marketingland.com/toss-all-the-text-youd-like-on-facebook-covers-the-20-rule-has-been-lifted-50516\">Back in 2013</a>, Facebook removed any reference to the 20% rule on text in cover photos ... but that doesn't mean you should go wild with using text in your design. The previous rule said that only 20% of your cover photo could be text. Personally, I thought that was way too restrictive for marketers, but the sentiment behind the rule was a good one.</p> \n<p>If you're going to use text in your cover photo, keep that text concise. Your photo will be much more informative and engaging. You can see how we've tried to strike that balance on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/hubspot/\">HubSpot's Facebook Page</a> below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-facebook-page-banner.jpg?width=650&amp;name=hubspot-facebook-page-banner.jpg\" alt=\"HubSpot Facebook cover photo \" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Want to see how HubSpot uses Facebook? Like our <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/hubspot\">Facebook Page here</a>.</p> \n<h3>4. Do give your cover image a focal point and colors that match your brand.</h3> \n<p>Think of your cover photo as the portion of your Page that's \"above the fold.\" If it's distracting or confusing, people will be more likely to click off the Page.</p> \n<p>Many of the best Facebook cover photos include a centerpiece to focus visitors' attention, along with a color scheme that aligns with the rest of their brand. Remember, your social media accounts are extensions of your business, and should give that impression to visitors right away.</p> \n<p>They also use negative white (i.e., empty) space as an advantage to make the subject, the copy, and the elements unique to Facebook (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-call-to-action-buttons-business-pages\">like the CTA button</a> on Facebook business Pages) stand out even more.</p> \n<p>Here's an example from <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/nytimes/\">The New York Times</a>:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-new-york-times-facebook-banner.png?width=650&amp;name=the-new-york-times-facebook-banner.png\" alt=\"The New York Times' simple Facebook cover with its logo against white text\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>And one from social media management platform <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/SproutSocialInc/\">Sprout Social</a>:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sprout-social-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=sprout-social-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Sprout Social Facebook cover photo\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>5. Don't try to blend the contents of your cover photo with your profile picture.</h3> \n<p>With some clever design tweaks, you used to be able to manipulate your profile picture and cover photo so they appear as if they're two parts of the same canvas.</p> \n<p>One of Paris' old cover photos is a great example of this:</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-family: AvenirNext, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; color: #33475b;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/paris-facebook-cover-photo.jpg?width=650&amp;name=paris-facebook-cover-photo.jpg\" alt=\"Paris Facebook cover photo with blended profile picture\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></h4> \n<p>You can still do this on your personal profile, but Facebook no longer sets up Business Pages this way.</p> \n<p>Now, as shown in the examples earlier in this article, the profile picture is completely separate from the cover photo.</p> \n<p>We admire your creativity, but don't prepare your design this way if you haven't yet launched a Business Page.</p> \n<h3>6. Do draw attention to the action buttons on the bottom right.</h3> \n<p>You might've noticed in a few of the cover photo examples above that their primary call-to-action (CTA) buttons were different. HubSpot’s says \"Send Message,\" while Sprout Social's says \"Sign Up.\"</p> \n<p>Depending on your business, you can launch a Page on Facebook with a unique CTA button to the bottom right of your cover photo. Take this button into consideration when designing your cover photo, and make it clear in the photo that this is a visitor's next step.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/linkedinlearning/\">LinkedIn Learning</a> does this in a subtle way below, placing the graphic of a man on a laptop over the “Sign Up” button, drawing your eye to that call-to-action.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/linkedin-learning-facebook-page-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=linkedin-learning-facebook-page-cover.jpg\" alt=\"LinkedIn Learning Facebook cover photo\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: While it might seem like a good idea to add directional cues like an arrow to get people to click on the CTA buttons, note that those CTA buttons don't appear the same way on the mobile app. In other words, it might be confusing to mobile users if you directly integrate the cover photo design with the buttons.</p> \n<p>I'll show you how Business Pages look on mobile devices in just a minute.</p> \n<h3>7. Do right-align the objects in your cover photo.</h3> \n<p>Since your profile picture is on the left, you want to add some balance to your Facebook cover photo design by having the focus of the image be on the right.</p> \n<p>Take a look at these cover photos. Which one looks more aesthetically pleasing?</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Right-aligned focus:</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/samsung-new-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=samsung-new-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Samsung's new Facebook cover photo with a pair of phones on the right\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Left-aligned focus:</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/samsung-old-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=samsung-old-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Samsung's old Facebook cover with important elements on the left\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Doesn't the right-aligned cover photo look better? In Samsung’s new cover photo, the biggest design elements (the profile picture, the text, and the two phones) are evenly spaced. In Samsung's old cover photo, your attention goes immediately to the left side of the page, completely missing the name of the product on the upper-right side.</p> \n<p>Not only is adding balance a crucial element of design, but it also allows for your cover photos to be more visually effective on mobile. Which brings me to my next point ...</p> \n<h3>8. Do keep mobile users in mind.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/377808/distribution-of-facebook-users-by-device/\">Statista</a> reports that 98.3% of Facebook's user base accesses the social network from mobile devices like smartphones and tablets. That's huge — and it's exactly why it's so important to keep mobile users top-of-mind when designing your Facebook cover photo.</p> \n<p>On mobile, a much larger portion of your cover photo is blocked out. The right side is typically cut out entirely.</p> \n<p>Let's take a look at a real-life example. Below, check out what <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/Cisco/\">Cisco's Facebook Page</a> looks like in a desktop browser versus on Facebook's mobile app.</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Desktop:</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cisco-desktop-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=cisco-desktop-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Cisco's Facebook cover on desktop \" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Mobile:</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cisco-mobile-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=cisco-mobile-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Cisco's Facebook cover on the mobile website\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Whereas your cover photo displays at 820 pixels wide by 312 pixels tall on desktop, it displays only 640 pixels wide by 360 pixels tall on smartphones. <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/125379114252045\">Take a look at this Facebook help document</a> for more information.</p> \n<p>It’s important to note that the text in Cisco’s cover photo is completely cut off. While it looks best to right-align your visual elements, be careful not to put important content so far to the right that it gets cut off on mobile.</p> \n<h3>9. Do include a shortened link in your cover photo description that aligns with your page CTA.</h3> \n<p>If you want to use your cover photo to support a Page CTA, make sure your cover photo description also includes a text CTA and link to the same offer. This way, any time people view your cover photo directly, they can access the link.</p> \n<p>Here's this practice in action on the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/adobecreativecloud\">Adobe Creative Cloud Facebook Page</a>:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/adobe-cc-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&amp;name=adobe-cc-facebook-cover.jpg\" alt=\"Adobe Creative Cloud Facebook cover with a CTA link in the description\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Make sure you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">shorten your links and add UTM codes</a> so you can track clicks on them. Shortening and tracking features are available <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/analytics?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-cover-photo-size-best-practices&amp;hubs_post-cta=in%20the%20HubSpot%20Marketing%20Platform\">in Marketing Hub</a> and in tools like <a href=\"https://bitly.com/\">bitly</a>.</p> \n<p>(If you want to learn more about how to write effective call-to-action copy for your cover photo description, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/write-design-calls-to-action?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-cover-photo-size-best-practices&amp;hubs_post-cta=click%20here%20to%20download%20our%20free%20ebook%20on%20creating%20compelling%20CTAs\">click here to download our free ebook on creating compelling CTAs</a>.)</p> \n<h3>10. Do pin a related post right below your Facebook cover image.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever \"pinned\" a post to your Facebook Page's Timeline? Basically, pinning a post allows you to highlight a typical Facebook post on the top of your Timeline for seven days. It's signified by a “PINNED POST” title on the top right of the post, like on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/Behance\">Behance’s Page</a> below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/behance-pinned-facebook-post.jpg?width=650&amp;name=behance-pinned-facebook-post.jpg\" alt=\"Behance pinned Facebook post announcing its new features\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>How does this relate to optimizing your Facebook cover photo? Well, if you're spending time aligning your Facebook Page CTA, your cover photo design, and your cover photo description copy, you should also make sure to post about the same thing directly to your page, and pin that post to the top of your Timeline.</p> \n<p>That way, you're giving people one very clear call-to-action when they arrive to your page (albeit in several different locations) — which should help conversions.</p> \n<p>To pin a Facebook post: Simply publish the post to Facebook, then click the three dots on the top right corner of the post and choose \"Pin to Top of Page.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pin-to-top-option.png?width=400&amp;name=pin-to-top-option.png\" alt=\"Drop-down menu with pin to top option highlighted\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>11. Do consider publishing a Facebook cover video.</h3> \n<p>You read that right. Facebook Business Pages now have the option to add a video in lieu of a static cover photo, provided they meet certain requirements.</p> \n<p>Let’s go over how you can do that.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/132465104004008\">Post a Facebook cover video</a> by first saving a video file at 820 pixels wide by 312 pixels tall to your desktop.</p> \n<p>Next, upload that video to your Page’s video library.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-upload-video.jpg?width=650&amp;name=facebook-upload-video.jpg\" alt=\"Facebook Creator Studio with a blue button that says &quot;Upload Video&quot;\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Facebook will only let you choose a video that fits its dimension requirements. The platform currently supports cover videos that are between 20 and 90 seconds long, and a minimum of 820 pixels wide by 312 pixels tall. The maximum (and recommended) size is 820 by 462 pixels with a video resolution of 1080p.</p> \n<p>After uploading the video, click \"Edit\" at the bottom right of your cover photo, and select “Choose from Videos.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/choose-from-video-option.png?width=400&amp;name=choose-from-video-option.png\" alt=\"Drop-down menu with the Choose from Videos option highlighted\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Pick the video you’ve just uploaded and reposition it so that it focuses on the element you’d like to highlight.</p> \n<p>When you click “Next,” you'll be asked to select from 10 thumbnails for your video. Choose the one that works best.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that Facebook cover videos play on a loop — once it ends, it automatically starts over if the viewer is still on your Facebook page. With that in mind, make sure whatever you post is pleasant if seen more than once. Extreme, action-packed videos might appear exhausting when played over and over.</p> \n<h3>Facebook Cover Video Examples</h3> \n<p>Cover videos are a terrific option for the video-inclined, and brands across numerous industries have already taken advantage of it to hold their visitors' attention.</p> \n<p>Here are some great cover videos to inspire you.</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">REI</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">REI sells outdoor equipment for activities like camping, hiking, running, boating, and biking. The company's subtle cover video reflects its products, all in one peaceful time lapse of the scenery it knows its audience craves.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rei-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=rei-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"REI Facebook cover video with a landscape\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/d04c1349098fce86cd156e3388c183db\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Nokia</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Nokia wants to be everywhere its users are — whether they're paddle-boarding, scuba diving, skateboarding, or working. Its Facebook cover video embodies its core customer in a visually pleasing way.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/nokia-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=nokia-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Nokia Facebook cover video with exciting scenes\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/0102a971e9ee2bcdbe451c083a41ffc1\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">WIRED Magazine</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">When your publication changes as fast as the news cycle, it can be hard to keep your readers focused on the stories you feel deserve extra attention. WIRED Magazine uses its Facebook cover video for just this purpose, as shown in the example below.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wired-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=wired-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Wired Facebook cover video with the magazine zooming out into a pink background\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/6830659d3d8583f32142ca05144191e5\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">HubSpot Academy</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Alright, maybe we're biased, but our brilliant creative team crushed it with the video below, made for HubSpot Academy. Sometimes, animation is the best way to capture the essence of your brand.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-academy-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=hubspot-academy-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"HubSpot Academy Facebook cover video with the word &quot;Grow&quot;\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/b5dc070fb3039734646eb55265240b81\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Next, let’s look at some examples of what Facebook cover videos look like when you’re logged into the platform.</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Black Girl Sunscreen</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Black Girl Sunscreen makes us feel all the good things with its Facebook cover video. In it, the brand shows its customers enjoying the sun, making us wish that summer were here (or that it would last forever).</p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/black-girl-sunscreen-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=black-girl-sunscreen-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Black Girl Sunscreen Facebook cover video with woman walking to the pool\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></h4> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/a00125f4158c96b44bd53dd73195d3ed\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Grammarly</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Grammarly is a tool for error-checking articles, emails, and any other written documents. The company's subtle cover video reflects how smooth its customers’ writing will be after they run it through the Grammarly program.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/grammarly-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=grammarly-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Grammarly Facebook cover video with smooth gradient\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/d40e99ea72af051e67ceda90f82cbcca\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">The Sip</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">The Sip is a Black-run and woman-owned Facebook community dedicated to promoting self-care and social awareness. The brand uses a video to present the topics that they cover in their platform, which invites users to stay on the page and engage.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-sip-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=the-sip-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"The Sip Facebook cover video with the text &quot;Political Engagement&quot;\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/3f0c31478e7ed44c0859066c800c07be\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sprout Social</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sprout Social allows brands to manage their social media profiles in one platform. Its Facebook cover video shows four different bubbles that signify the writing, posting, reporting, and analyzing of social media posts in a single box. In this way, Sprout Social shows exactly how its tool works.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sprout-social-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=sprout-social-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Sprout Social Facebook cover video with text boxes sliding in\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/63462c29871c8c7a0be4050186bd1c3c\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Sundays Studio</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">This woman-owned nail care brand uses its cover video to show how customers feel once they step into a Sundays salon — or wear Sundays nail polish.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sundays-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=sundays-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Sundays Facebook cover video with woman getting her nails done\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/6d18f0cb9c5f1e7e213d4239bc6153f6\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">ComicBook.com</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">ComicBook.com is a news website covering everything that’s related to movies, shows, and pop culture. In its Facebook cover video, it gives viewers a taste of the topics, movies, and actors the publication covers on a daily basis.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/comicbook-dot-com-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=comicbook-dot-com-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"ComicBook.com Facebook cover video with various actors speaking\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/ee0b288875d11407d234554d50526498\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Stasher</h4> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Stasher appeals to eco-conscious buyers with a fun, animated Facebook cover video that shares how your purchase impacts the planet.</p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/stasher-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&amp;name=stasher-facebook-cover-video.gif\" alt=\"Stasher Facebook cover video with a graphic about single-use plastic\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal; text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://gyazo.com/c1ca4412c01da75f645977e271d35879\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">As you can see from these examples, your video should be just as simple as a cover photo. Keep in mind that the same guidelines outlined in best practice #1 apply to cover videos as well.</p> \n<h2>Facebook Cover Photo Sizes that Work for Your Business</h2> \n<p>Choosing the right cover size for your Facebook Page may seem simple, but it can have a huge impact on users and prospects visiting your Page. An ill-fitting cover photo or video can look unprofessional and give the wrong impression about the quality of your products or services. With the tips I’ve shared, you’ll be sure to choose a Facebook cover photo that embodies your brand, conveys quality, and engages users on the platform.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=fe6ccf43-a6d0-45a6-b8e8-bb381d859caf&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" /cdn23@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-51-708_ec4d626daacacf65.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/samsung-old-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&name=samsung-old-facebook-cover.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn17@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-53-489_cb7189eadded5da9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cisco-desktop-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&name=cisco-desktop-facebook-cover.jpg":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/cisco-mobile-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&name=cisco-mobile-facebook-cover.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn90@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-58-511_e62f8c021899ed8c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/adobe-cc-facebook-cover.jpg?width=650&name=adobe-cc-facebook-cover.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn26@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-58-767_9486c3828cdd4639.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/behance-pinned-facebook-post.jpg?width=650&name=behance-pinned-facebook-post.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn91@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-00-758_5a5e083c757778b0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pin-to-top-option.png?width=400&name=pin-to-top-option.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn65@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-52-960_ebce8712a05f03ac.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/facebook-upload-video.jpg?width=650&name=facebook-upload-video.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn85@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-55-339_db4daad508a9ceea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/choose-from-video-option.png?width=400&name=choose-from-video-option.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn50@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-51-283_05269099049eec17.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rei-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=rei-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn14@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-54-793_cc9ce4a2ccc0af9a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/nokia-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=nokia-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn72@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-57-290_ca33691502871669.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wired-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=wired-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-50-08-766_7456442b43be18d2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-academy-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=hubspot-academy-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn89@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-03-507_8132183c2ba776b1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/black-girl-sunscreen-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=black-girl-sunscreen-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn96@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-051_1034cd194f07f96a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/grammarly-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=grammarly-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn5@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-53-247_4067212c83ac5e8c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-sip-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=the-sip-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn6@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-04-796_5aed045a7e173805.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sprout-social-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=sprout-social-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn14@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-54-717_8fe336190d0651fb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sundays-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=sundays-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn29@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-57-793_68b3b3993fd5bea9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/comicbook-dot-com-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=comicbook-dot-com-facebook-cover-video.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn62@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-01-309_7996d887130df089.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/stasher-facebook-cover-video.gif?width=650&name=stasher-facebook-cover-video.gif":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fe6ccf43-a6d0-45a6-b8e8-bb381d859caf.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn68@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-54-658_cb14705e96251d3e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-cover-photo-size-best-practices&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn54@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-50-01-777_06fac1e6e84b101a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370085},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","title":"25 Post Event Survey Questions to Ask","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/post-event-survey-questions","description":"<p>Just like <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/25121710392270396/\">Joey from \"Friends,\"</a> we recognize the importance of giving and receiving in marketing. One of the best things to give and receive is feedback.</p> \n<p>Without feedback, we would never be able to improve. And even though it's hard, feedback is a great way to measure success.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>With a post event survey, you'll learn what attendees thought about the event, how they heard about it, and what they enjoyed most. Measuring attendee satisfaction will help you improve your event marketing and figure out what's working and what isn't.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://www.markletic.com/blog/virtual-event-statistics/\">90% of virtual event organizers</a> use surveys to measure attendee satisfaction. And <a href=\"https://welcome.bizzabo.com/post-covid-19-event-outlook-report\">80%</a> report that attendee engagement and satisfaction were KPIs used for measuring event success.</p> \n<p>To design a post event survey, you'll want to ask several types of questions -- from Yes/No, rating, to open-ended questions.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review the best post event survey questions to ask.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=7ad084e3-bb2d-429e-9cbd-2b09416729f1&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download free resources for executing your best event yet. [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7ad084e3-bb2d-429e-9cbd-2b09416729f1.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. How satisfied were you with the event?</h3> \n<p>First and foremost, it's important to ask attendees about their overall satisfaction with an event. You can also ask participants to rate specific things including the venue, date, speakers, vendors, catering, quality of sessions, amount of sessions, and more.</p> \n<p>This will help you gauge specifically how well you did in each area, but also the overall satisfaction of attendees.</p> \n<p>This is probably the first and most important question that is asked on most surveys. It's a great starting point for the specific questions that follow next.</p> \n<h3>2. What was your favorite experience or moment of the event?</h3> \n<p>This question should be open-ended and let the participants describe what they liked most about the event and why they liked that moment.</p> \n<p>This will help you discover what you did right and what experiences are most valuable to your event attendees.</p> \n<p>With this information, you can get an idea about how to plan events in the future and figure out if there's anything that a majority of your attendees agree with or want to see again.</p> \n<h3>3. What could we improve on?</h3> \n<p>Again, this will be an open-ended question that lets your participants give constructive feedback. While it's hard to hear sometimes, this will help you figure out what resonates with your audiences and what doesn't.</p> \n<p>By tracking what audiences don't like, you can then improve and iterate future events so people don't have those barriers about attending your next event.</p> \n<p>The point of getting feedback isn't just to receive positive feedback, but to figure out what isn't working as well.</p> \n<h3>4. How useful was the event?</h3> \n<p>This is a great question for figuring out how actionable the event content was. Did your attendees find the information useful? Did they learn anything? Were they able to apply something they learned from your event into their work flow?</p> \n<p>Depending on the type of event you're holding, this can be a great way to figure out if people felt they got their money's worth.</p> \n<h3>5. Did the event meet your expectations?</h3> \n<p>Similar to the question above, this question measures if people got what they thought they were going to get. This answers the question, <em>\"Did my audience achieve their goal by attending this event?\"</em></p> \n<p>This should be an open-ended question that allows users to expand and explain why the event met their expectations, or why it didn't.</p> \n<h3>6. How likely would you be to attend our events in the future?</h3> \n<p>With this question, you'll learn how many people plan to keep up to date with your events. If they were generally satisfied, they'll say yes. If they weren't, they'll say no.</p> \n<p>This does a good job of figuring out how well you marketed and sold your company as an authority and trustworthy leader in the industry.</p> \n<h3>7. Would you recommend our events to a friend or colleague?</h3> \n<p>Given that people are more likely to purchase a product their friend has shared with them and the importance of customer reviews, referrals are a great way to measure how satisfied your event attendees are.</p> \n<p>Liking your event or products isn't enough -- do they like you enough to talk about you with their friends? That's the true mark of success for an event.</p> \n<h3>8. Did you have an opportunity and place to ask questions and participate?</h3> \n<p>Whether you provided online support or you had event helpers around the building, it's important to note whether attendees noticed that help and if they felt supported. When you run an event, there are bound to be questions about registration, access to certain workshops, and more.</p> \n<p>This question lets you know that your audience knew where to go if they had a question. If they didn't feel like they had a space to ask questions, then you can do better about promoting your support channels.</p> \n<h3>9. What would have made this event better?</h3> \n<p>This is a great question to crowdsource event ideas from your target audience. What do they want to see? What gaps did they see in your event from competitors? With this question, you'll be able to brainstorm ways to improve your next event.</p> \n<h3>10. Why did you attend this event?</h3> \n<p>You can use this question as a way to inform your pre event marketing. This will let you know what your audience liked about your marketing and what they expected from you. This open-ended question will give you a chance to show up for your audience and give them what they want.</p> \n<h3>11. How did you hear about this event?</h3> \n<p>Again, this is a great way to evaluate your pre event marketing. Where are attendees learning about your event? What marketing channels are working best? What marketing channels aren't working at all?</p> \n<p>This will tell you where to focus your pre event marketing for your next event and let you know places where you need to pay more attention and improve on.</p> \n<h3>12. Have you attended this event before?</h3> \n<p>A great metric to keep track of is how many repeat attendees you have coming to your regular or annual events. This will let you know how many people see the value in your event and want to continue attending.</p> \n<p>Again, this metric will let you know where to focus your marketing efforts. Do you want to increase repeat attendance? Then perhaps you need to focus on the customer experience during the event. Do you have great repeat customers but not enough new acquisitions? This will let you know that you need to focus on pre event marketing channels.</p> \n<h3>13. Would you want to attend this event again in the future?</h3> \n<p>This question, while similar to one of the above, measures how likely someone is to attend the same event in the future. Do they see value in attending this event every year? Or do they feel like they got everything they needed?</p> \n<p>Again, just like it's easier to retain customers than get new ones, it's easier to convince former participants to attend the same event again. This will reveal if your audience is excited about coming to your event in the future and then you can compare with the number of attendees who actually came back the next year.</p> \n<h3>14. Have you attended our other events before?</h3> \n<p>This question will let you know how many loyal followers you have. Are the people coming to your events in your community? Or are these new people who haven't heard of your brand before? This will help you measure where you're acquiring event attendees.</p> \n<h3>15. Were you satisfied with the amount of activities/workshops?</h3> \n<p>This is a specific question that measures satisfaction with the quantity of activities or workshops available to attendees. Essentially, was there enough for your participants to do during the event. Or was there too much? Either way, this question is important to figure out if you and your audience are aligned on what content they want.</p> \n<h3>16. Were you satisfied with the quality of the content?</h3> \n<p>Once you know how much content to offer your audience, it's time to ask about the quality of the content. Did they find the information helpful? Was this worth paying for? This will help establish trust with your audience that you can present high quality content and information that they find valuable and useful.</p> \n<p>This will also help you gauge what content your audience is interested in. If they were not satisfied with the quality, it could be because the type of content, the speakers, or the way it was presented.</p> \n<h3>17. How helpful was the staff at the event?</h3> \n<p>This is an excellent question that will help you figure out how your staff performed during this event. When attendees asked questions or used support, was the staff friendly and helpful? Or was there a staffing issue?</p> \n<p>This will help you figure out how quickly issues were resolved and if participants enjoyed their experience.</p> \n<h3>18. What was your biggest takeaway from the event?</h3> \n<p>Again, this helps you determine what people were able to learn from your event and what they got out of it. Does that align with your goals for the event? If not, this is a great way to learn what people took away from your event and what they expected.</p> \n<h3>19. How satisfied were you with the virtual experience?</h3> \n<p>If you're holding a virtual event, it's important to add post event questions that measure the success of the virtual experience.</p> \n<p>You can leave this as a rating and/or an optional open-ended question to let people explain why they were or were not satisfied with the virtual experience. Attendees might comment on the ease of navigation or the audio quality, for instance.</p> \n<h3>20. What were your favorite virtual features?</h3> \n<p>If you offered any special online features or an event app, this is the place to figure out what your attendees thought about those features. This lets you measure the success of your virtual platform overall -- did this platform provide features that your audience liked? Or were there other features they wished were available?</p> \n<h3>21. How easy to navigate was the platform for the event?</h3> \n<p>Similarly, this question is meant to measure the effectiveness of your online platform for your virtual events. If the platform isn't intuitive or easy for participants to use, then they probably won't consider coming back for your other events. This will help you gauge if improvements need to be made to the online experience.</p> \n<h3>22. How satisfied were you with the networking opportunities provided?</h3> \n<p>Lots of marketing events are meant to allow networking and a lot of people attend these events to network with other professionals. If networking is something that your audience wants from you, it's important to measure the success of your networking opportunities.</p> \n<p>This can be a rating question or an open-ended question so your attendees can elaborate on what they liked about the networking opportunities or didn't like.</p> \n<h3>23. What topics would you want to see more of at future events?</h3> \n<p>Again, it's always a good idea to learn what content your audience wants to see. How can you figure that out? Just ask.</p> \n<p>In your survey, you can ask what type of topics they're interested in learning about in the future. This will also give you new perspectives and content ideas for your next event.</p> \n<h3>24. How did this event impact your perception of our company?</h3> \n<p>This is a great question for learning how effective your brand story and messaging is at your event. Is your branding clear through your event marketing materials? How does it fit in to the larger strategic picture? This question will let you track how effective your event was in terms of branding.</p> \n<h3>25. Please share any additional comments, thoughts, suggestions for future events.</h3> \n<p>Of course, ending with an open-ended question where participants can leave feedback on any area is a best practice. You want your attendees to feel like they can tell you their overall thoughts and opinions.</p> \n<p>Hopefully the questions in your survey got your attendees thinking and they might also feel like there are other topics to cover. Since you can't ask every question you'd probably like to, this helps you figure out what's important to your audience.</p> \n<p>Post event surveys are mainly used to measure how successful an event was. These surveys will give you information that you need to improve future events.</p> \n<p>Now, post event survey questions aren't the only type of surveys you'll want to send out. You might consider also sending a pre-event survey. A pre-event survey will help you measure your current event marketing, see what got people excited about the event in the first place, and how to tailor the event to the actual attendees.</p> \n<p>Here are some examples of what that might look like.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. How did you hear about this event?</h3> \n<p>This question is great to ask either before or after an event. You could send this in a pre event survey to figure out what marketing channels are working the best. This will help you make changes to your budget and priorities when you continue marketing the event.</p> \n<h3>2. What are you most excited about?</h3> \n<p>With this pre event question, you can gauge what people are most looking forward to. Again, this will help inform your marketing budget and priorities so you can fulfill any customer expectations.</p> \n<h3>3. Have you attended this event before?</h3> \n<p>Similar to the first question, this can be asked before or after an event. The reason to find this out before an event is to see if you are getting a lot of repeat attendees or if you need to do more marketing to previous attendees.</p> \n<h3>4. Why did you choose to attend this event?</h3> \n<p>This is a great question to ask before an event because it will tell you what people are most looking forward to. This will help you prepare for an event so you can deliver on what people are expecting.</p> \n<h3>5. Do you have special accommodations you would like us to be aware of?</h3> \n<p>Logistically, this is important to know. If you don't have a lot of attendees, and accommodations need to be made, then you should be aware of what those accommodations are. If you're holding a larger event, you need to consider the type of accommodations you'll need to make for various attendees.</p> \n<h3>6. Was there any event information that was difficult for you to find?</h3> \n<p>Again, this will help you make adjustments to the pre event and registration process while it's still going on. This should help you get more registrants, ultimately, because you can pivot your strategy in real time.</p> \n<h3>7. Which social media platform do you use the most?</h3> \n<p>If you don't have a plan for how you're going to communicate with your attendees during the event, social media is a great option. But what platform would work best? You can use a pre event survey to learn what social media platforms your audience uses the most, so you can provide helpful information during your event.</p> \n<p>Conducting pre or post event surveys is an important part of measuring the success of your event team and marketing team. To do this, you can use a survey tool, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/service/customer-feedback\">HubSpot</a>. Regardless of the tool you use, remember that the goal of sending a survey is to receive both positive and constructive feedback so that you can improve your event marketing and events.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=bd0c27ef-31a6-464a-b8a8-a65cbc33e2a5&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Event Marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bd0c27ef-31a6-464a-b8a8-a65cbc33e2a5.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpost-event-survey-questions&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 31 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7ad084e3-bb2d-429e-9cbd-2b09416729f1.png","linkMd5":"05fb53bb3b49354e7a6d93ec079f7494","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn68@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-795_6ca0430bfb5ec4d1.webp","destWidth":472,"destHeight":19,"sourceBytes":4523,"destBytes":4712,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7ad084e3-bb2d-429e-9cbd-2b09416729f1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn68@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-795_6ca0430bfb5ec4d1.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bd0c27ef-31a6-464a-b8a8-a65cbc33e2a5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-56-208_31f5fd92c8680d09.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fpost-event-survey-questions&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn95@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-00-822_1985586e96e90a40.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425369946},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"13 Things NOT to Do on Facebook","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/9134/top-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx","description":"<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <p>These days, most businesses know they need to have a presence on Facebook. Searching for a business on Facebook and seeing they don't have a page garners the same reaction from users as searching for a business on Google and seeing they don't have a website: They just don't look legitimate.</p> \n <p>But <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5492/How-to-Create-a-Facebook-Business-Page-in-5-Simple-Steps-With-Video.aspx?_ga=2.152964976.858853954.1615321527-821602908.1615321527\">once you've created your business page</a>, navigating the waters of building a Facebook presence is another matter entirely. How often should you post? When should you post? Why are your images all pixelated, and how can you fix them? Do you really have to respond to that troll?</p> \n <p>Many mistakes businesses make on Facebook are entirely preventable. To help you avoid these pitfalls and operate your Facebook page smoothly, we've listed some of the most common mistakes businesses make with their <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/9134/top-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=Facebook%20marketing\">Facebook marketing</a>. Here's what not to do.</p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Social Media Trends in 2021 [Free Report]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n <h2>13 Facebook Mistakes to Avoid</h2> \n <h3>1. Don't create a profile instead of a page for your business.</h3> \n <p>This may seem elementary, but you'd be surprised by how many people make this mistake. Before we get to more advanced tips, let's set the record straight: Facebook profiles are meant for people, while <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/facebook-for-business?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/9134/top-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=Pages%20are%20meant%20for%20businesses\">Facebook pages are meant for businesses</a>.</p> \n <h3>2. Don't have multiple Facebook accounts.</h3> \n <p>This advice applies to both your personal and professional activities on Facebook. You might think having more than one Facebook account helps you separate your personal life from your work, family, or school life. Let’s be real, you can’t have your great Aunt Debrah commenting on your embarrassing college photos from ten years ago causing them to resurface in people’s timelines.</p> \n <p>On a more practical note, Facebook does <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/community/question/?id=765037383609149#:~:text=People%20can't%20have%20more,have%20more%20than%205%2C000%20fans.\">limit personal accounts</a> to 5,000 friends. After that, people will need to follow you which limits the type of engagement they can have with your content. As a fix, you might think a second or third account might be a good idea.</p> \n <p>However, there are two reasons why you wouldn't want to have two accounts. The main reason is that Facebook doesn't allow users to have more than one personal account — it's against their <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/legal/terms\">Terms of Service</a>. So if they find out you have two personal accounts, they'll shut them down.</p> \n <p>The second reason is that, even if it weren't against their terms, having two personal accounts would be a pain to maintain. Do you have enough content going up on both to round out your presence? Where do you draw the line between the two? Which account will you show to your friend who works in your industry? Instead of having to delineate between two parts of your life, you should instead take advantage of Facebook's robust privacy settings.</p> \n <p>On the professional side, there are no such restrictions from Facebook. You can make several pages for your business without the social network even noticing. But should you?</p> \n <p>For most businesses, we don't recommend it. You've only got so much time in the day to devote to Facebook — why spread yourself thin just to maintain several pages?</p> \n <p>Plus, there are lots of other great options for you. First, you can <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/352402648173466\">take advantage of Facebook's targeting options </a>— you don't need to pay to send updates to certain segments of your audience. Instead of creating a page for one segment of your audience, you can just post tailored content to be shown only to them.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/GlobalPagesFB.png?width=635&amp;name=GlobalPagesFB.png\" alt=\"Facebook Global Pages structure\" width=\"635\" style=\"width: 635px;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/331800410323820?id=960266880806087\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>Second, if you have a huge audience that lives all over the world, you can think about <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/905034079579176\">implementing a global page</a>. If you'd like to get your global page set up, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/contact-us/\">you need to get in contact with Facebook directly</a>. (Full disclosure: You'll probably already need to have a hefty Facebook ad budget in place to make this happen.)</p> \n <p>In short: Keep it simple. Don't create more accounts and pages than you need.</p> \n <h3>3. Don't neglect the posts or comments on your page.</h3> \n <p>JetBlue's manager of customer commitment Laurie Meacham <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/jetblue-customer-service-twitter\">once told me</a>, \"We're all about the people, and being on social media is just a natural extension of that. It's no different than any other part of the airline.\"</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.47.56%20PM.jpg?width=650&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.47.56%20PM.jpg\" alt=\"JetBlue airplane on the tarmac\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/jetblue-customer-service-twitter\"><em> Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>No matter your industry, that couldn't be more true. The point of business accounts on Facebook is to interact with your customers and prospects who are already engaging there. (And considering as of Q4 2020, Facebook had <a href=\"https://investor.fb.com/investor-news/press-release-details/2021/Facebook-Reports-Fourth-Quarter-and-Full-Year-2020-Results/default.aspx\">just under two billion</a> active users, it's likely that they are engaging out there.)</p> \n <p>Ignoring comments and interactions is like saying to your customers, \"I don't care what you have to say.\" To avoid this, start by making sure that the desired publishing options for your Timeline are turned on. While some businesses allow users to post and leave comments on their page without review, others prefer to manually approve them, and some don't allow publishing permissions at all.</p> \n <p>Although the choice is entirely up to you, we recommend that you treat your page like a two-way street rather than a channel to broadcast your voice, and your voice only.</p> \n <p>Once you've got that straightened out, be sure to monitor the comments daily and respond when appropriate.</p> \n <p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-templates?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F9134%2Ftop-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=flip%20through%20our%20free%20ebook&amp;_ga=2.158872895.483290293.1615432405-2017445484.1615432405\">Pro Tip: For time-saving tips, flip through our free ebook on how to monitor your social media accounts in 10 minutes a day.</a></p> \n <h3>4. Don't ignore negativity.</h3> \n <p>What if customers complain? What if they troll?</p> \n <p>You can't stop people from saying things about your brand, good or bad. What you can do is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/12-methods-for-diffusing-negativity-on-social-media\">respond respectfully</a> and with helpful information based on the comments that were shared. Responding not only shows people you're concerned about their happiness but it also shows that you're engaged and listening.</p> \n <h3>5. Don't leave the meta description as is.</h3> \n <p>When you paste a link into a new Facebook post, the metadata from that post (an image and a short description) gets pulled in automatically. But that doesn't mean you should just press \"Publish.\" Instead, add some relevant post copy like a quote or statistic from the article you're linking to.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.55.27%20PM.png?width=650&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.55.27%20PM.png\" alt=\"Editing a meta description and removing the URL before posting to Facebook\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing?_ga=2.264946959.1629497862.1615322760-982386085.1615322760\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>In addition to editing the post copy, you'll want to remove the URL from the box before posting. Knowing that Facebook automatically populates metadata when you paste a link, deleting the extra URL will help to reduce visual clutter without messing with the post.</p> \n <h3>6. Don't just post photos.</h3> \n <p><a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/blog/video-marketing-statistics#4_Consumers_Love_Seeing_Videos_on_Social_Media\">Video is now </a>consumers’ favorite type of content on Facebook. As of 2020, <a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/blog/facebook-trends\">17% of all content</a> on the platform is video content..</p> \n <p>Instead of sticking to one or two content types, experiment a little bit. Facebook is a place where you can let your brand's personality shine. Post company culture pictures and have people tag themselves. Consider having Facebook Q&amp;A discussions. Post links with one-word copy, and others with several paragraphs of copy. Find out what works best for your audience, and remember that your audience is always changing — so <a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1615325088154000&amp;usg=AOvVaw1j4gWpn1PZsADs87RVr4Ka\">t</a><a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1615325088154000&amp;usg=AOvVaw1j4gWpn1PZsADs87RVr4Ka\">est continually</a>.</p> \n <h3>7. Don't make your posts too long.</h3> \n <p>Again, testing post length is the best way to gauge what your audience likes. The optimal length of your Facebook Timeline posts will vary from company to company. For some, longer, informative Facebook posts perform better. For others, like BuzzFeed, short ones work perfectly.</p> \n <p>While it's important to experiment and see what your audience responds to best, here's what we will say: There is some solid evidence that shorter posts generate the highest engagement — in fact, a HubSpot research experiment found that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/character-count-guide\">posts with about 40 characters in length received more engagement</a> than longer posts.</p> \n <h3>8. Don't post images of just any size.</h3> \n <p>Pixelated, cluttered, or difficult-to-read visuals will not only frustrate users, but they'll also give you a bad reputation.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic?_ga=2.215891218.483290293.1615432405-2017445484.1615432405\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social-Media-Image-Sizes-2020.png?width=650&amp;name=Social-Media-Image-Sizes-2020.png\" alt=\"Social Media Image Sizes Infographic\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></a><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>Not only does Facebook have specific image dimensions for profile photos and cover photos, (although those are important, too), it also has ideal image dimensions for images you post on your timeline, the ones you use in sponsored posts, sidebar ads, and so on. To help you keep everything straight, bookmark this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">handy cheat sheet</a>.</p> \n <h3>9. Don't post click-bait.</h3> \n <p>When you link to a web page in a Facebook post, the platform tracks <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/dwell-time\">dwell time</a> on the page to see how much time people spend looking at it. The lesson? Don't post click-bait headlines that don't deliver on your promises.</p> \n <p>If you're looking to meet the needs of your audience on Facebook, consider posting links to clear, informative blog articles. When the headline sets the right expectation for what a user can expect from the content, it's easier for them to see the value in what you're offering and remain on the page to read the article. When it doesn't, they bounce off the page and Facebook takes note.</p> \n <h3>10. Don't assume you should only post during business hours.</h3> \n <p><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/best-times-to-post-on-social-media/#fb-times\">A Sprout Social study</a> found that the best times and days to post on Facebook vary by industry. However, the common theme across industries using Facebook to generate engagement is that activity on the platform hits a peak on Wednesdays and the best time to post is early afternoon.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/BTP-2020-Facebook-Heatmap-Global.png?width=650&amp;name=BTP-2020-Facebook-Heatmap-Global.png\" alt=\"Heatmap of the best times to post on Facebook by SproutSocial\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/best-times-to-post-on-social-media/#fb-times\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>What about weekends? Sprout Social also noted that Sundays are, across the board, the worst days to publish content to Facebook. In summary, stick with publishing posts during the middle of the week, right before engagement and activity wane heading into the weekend.</p> \n <h3>11. Don't post too often (but do post regularly.)</h3> \n <p>Yes, you should post regularly to keep your audience engaged, show them you're present and listening, and answer their questions and concerns.</p> \n <p>However, what you don't want to do is overwhelm them with tons and tons of posts. We even ran a few experiments to figure out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-frequently-should-i-publish-on-social-media\">how often businesses should post on Facebook</a>. Our research included posting frequency benchmarks by industry and company size based on Facebook data from thousands of our customers.</p> \n <p>What we found was this: Companies that are selective about what they publish — i.e. they take the time to craft a smaller number of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/24422/the-ultimate-facebook-marketing-cheat-sheet.aspx\">high-quality Facebook posts</a> instead of a lot of Facebook posts — performed best.</p> \n <h3>12. Don't forget to experiment with targeting and ads.</h3> \n <p>As a result of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-declining-organic-reach\">recent decline in organic reach on Facebook</a>, many companies are turning to Facebook advertising to capture the attention of a more qualified audience. With <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-paid-ad-checklist\">Facebook advertising</a>, you can target people who've visited your website, used your app, or signed up for an email list. You can also target similar or \"Lookalike\" audiences or set up campaigns aimed at getting likes on your page.</p> \n <p>But you can't just throw money at Facebook advertising and expect everything to work. It'll only work if you're smart about it — which means experimenting and tweaking your advertising plan to see what works.</p> \n <p>Where should you start? We created <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/guide-social-media-advertising?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/9134/top-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=this%20step-by-step%20guide%20to%20Facebook%20advertising\">this step-by-step guide to digital advertising</a> to help marketers learn how to create successful Facebook ads. And if you want to check out examples of real Facebook ads that have worked really well for brands, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33319/10-Examples-of-Facebook-Ads-That-Actually-Work-And-Why.aspx\">check out this blog post</a>.</p> \n <h3>13. Don't forget which account you're posting from.</h3> \n <p>The Facebook News Feed looks basically the same whether you're logged in to your personal account or your company's account, making it all too easy for Page administrators to forget which one they're posting from. You wouldn't want to respond to commenters from your personal account when you meant to respond from your business account or vice versa.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pamelumps-hubspot-twitter-fail-cropped.png?width=418&amp;name=pamelumps-hubspot-twitter-fail-cropped.png\" alt=\"Pam Bump baby bump photo on HubSpot's Twitter account\" width=\"418\" style=\"width: 418px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/15-minutes-social-media-shame?__hstc=233546881.1d7ce66fb7438b7409cfa0488f21afc4.1615322760771.1615322760771.1615322760771.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615322760772&amp;__hsfp=1304563561&amp;_ga=2.260825101.1629497862.1615322760-982386085.1615322760\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n <p>However, the truth is sometimes accidents happen. In fact, one of my colleagues accidentally posted a picture of her baby bump from HubSpot's Twitter account. While it was a harmless mistake, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/15-minutes-social-media-shame\">she wrote up a blog article</a> to provide businesses with the advice they need to overcome a social media slip-up.</p> \n <h2 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Do This Not That On Facebook</h2> \n <p>Facebook is one of the longest-standing social media platforms that businesses rely on to reach their audiences. And it makes sense — more than a third of the people on earth use Facebook. With such a large audience watching for the latest and greatest social content to connect with, you must be certain that you put your best foot forward when publishing posts. I hope this list gives you more than enough ideas for what not to do on Facebook so you aren’t caught off guard by even the wildest faux pas.</p> \n <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3.png\"></a></p> \n</div>  \n<img
