Cox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn47@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-30-576_ebc276d76ef14084.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/GlobalPagesFB.png?width=635&name=GlobalPagesFB.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn7@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-51-336_080f7a7b83eadf7c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.47.56%20PM.jpg?width=650&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.47.56%20PM.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn41@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-58-965_ff4033cd3e5025a1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.55.27%20PM.png?width=650&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-09%20at%202.55.27%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn28@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-51-540_aedcef231d50459a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social-Media-Image-Sizes-2020.png?width=650&name=Social-Media-Image-Sizes-2020.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn23@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-57-915_4e287c5146bc4856.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/BTP-2020-Facebook-Heatmap-Global.png?width=650&name=BTP-2020-Facebook-Heatmap-Global.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn10@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-59-500_bdfe53d7a4c467a8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pamelumps-hubspot-twitter-fail-cropped.png?width=418&name=pamelumps-hubspot-twitter-fail-cropped.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn55@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-54-084_ea7829971c89c990.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn80@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-59-302_73ab6e288063122a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F9134%2Ftop-5-things-not-to-do-on-facebook.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-50-00-860_8674c56062c20796.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370023},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How Primary Colors Help HubSpot Build a CRM That Customers Love","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/primary-colors-help-build-hubspot-crm","description":"<p>At HubSpot, customer experience comes first. Always.</p>  \n<p>Whether our marketing team is selecting a time at which to send an email or our web team team is choosing the size and location of a button on our homepage, the question we always go back to is: “Will this be a good experience for our customers?”</p> \n<p>As HubSpot's Chief Product Officer, this customer-first principle is my guiding light when it comes to product development. And it's the reason why we don't <em>buy</em>&nbsp;technology when we want to deliver a new product to our customers. We <em>build</em>&nbsp;it.</p> \n<p>This build-first approach is becoming increasingly rare in our industry. Traditional SaaS companies tend to acquire other companies when they want to significantly expand their product offerings or quickly increase their customer base. This can sometimes lead to a quick uptick in revenue — after all, when a company buys another, it acquires all of its customers — but it's often a very negative experience for the customer.</p> \n<p>When two completely different systems are cobbled together after an acquisition, the burden of making them work together is foisted onto the customer. Each company probably took a completely different approach to product development, resulting in different underlying technology, different processes, and different user interfaces.</p> \n<p>Reconciling these differences without causing friction for customers is an almost impossible task. And when SaaS companies apply this approach over time, the friction accrues, technical debt goes through the roof, and the customer experience steadily degrades as a result.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=76520ae5-1a3b-4055-9e8e-95e150b90965&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Download: How to Create a Style Guide [+ Free Templates]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/76520ae5-1a3b-4055-9e8e-95e150b90965.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>This approach solves for the company implementing it, not the customers it's supposed to serve. That's why we do things differently at HubSpot. After all, it isn't like us to follow the crowd.</p> \n<p>When most companies were doubling down on the old outbound playbook, we championed inbound approaches instead. When most businesses were wondering whether remote work could ever work, we saw the percentage of HubSpotters working from home<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/careers-blog/future-of-work-hybrid\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/careers-blog/future-of-work-hybrid?_ga=2.212458068.1513525045.1615841638-356781811.1615841638\">hit double digits</a>&nbsp;long before 2020 forced everyone's hand. And while our industry was still furiously focused on funnels, we embraced <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/flywheel?_ga=2.212458068.1513525045.1615841638-356781811.1615841638\">the flywheel</a>.</p> \n<p>We're different. It's in HubSpot's DNA. It's even reflected in our company mission: we help organizations grow better. Not grow according to the status quo. Not grow by adhering to age-old playbooks. Grow better.</p> \n<p>Just as we believe there's a better way to <em>grow</em>, we also believe there's a better way to <em>build</em>. That's where the Primary Colors come in.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Meet the Primary Colors</h2> \n<p>Our approach to product development is simple, and it allows us to create multiplicative benefits for customers that no other CRM platform offers. We focus on five foundational elements that span all of our products, and we work at improving each one of them, all of the time. Those elements are: Automation, Content, Data, Messaging, and Reporting. We call them “Primary Colors.”</p> \n<p>Every one&nbsp;of our Hubs – CMS Hub, Marketing Hub, Sales Hub, and Service Hub&nbsp;– comprises a different blend of the five Primary Colors, meaning that every product on our platform is built on the same underlying foundation.</p> \n<p>So when the product team shows up to work every day, the question we ask ourselves isn't “Which Hub or feature will we work on today?” It's: “Which Primary Color will we enhance?”</p> \n<p><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Primary%20Colors%20Help%20HubSpot%20Build%20a%20CRM%20That%20Customers%20Love.png?width=624&amp;name=How%20Primary%20Colors%20Help%20HubSpot%20Build%20a%20CRM%20That%20Customers%20Love.png\" style=\"margin-left: 0.00px;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p>As a result, when we add value to one area of HubSpot, value is automatically added across the entire CRM platform. And that allows us to deliver a steady stream of delight to all of our customers on an ongoing basis.</p> \n<p>Here are three ways in which this approach allows us to offer unique value to our customers in the crowded CRM market:</p> \n<h3><strong>1</strong><strong>. Continuous improvement across the platform.</strong></h3> \n<p><em>“HubSpot is the perfect, always-improving </em><em>marketing</em><em>&nbsp;software” – </em><em><a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/hubspot-sales-hub/reviews/hubspot-sales-hub-review-4530313\">review on G2</a></em></p> \n<p>The same five Primary Colors go into building each HubSpot product, so when we improve one Primary Color, we improve every Hub. And every customer of every HubSpot product sees an immediate benefit, whatever part of the platform they use.</p> \n<p>For instance, when we invest in making Reporting in Sales Hub more robust, this robustness ripples out to every Reporting tool across the HubSpot CRM platform. So Marketing Hub customers who use our Reporting tools benefit, Service Hub customers who use our Reporting tools benefit, as do CMS Hub customers — all because we invested in improving just one Primary Color.</p> \n<h3><strong>2</strong><strong>. Easy adoption of new products.</strong></h3> \n<p><em>“We quickly adopted the Sales Hub Pro and Marketing Enterprise for our growing needs. It has been one of the best decisions we have made” – </em><em><a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/hubspot-sales-hub/reviews/hubspot-sales-hub-review-4530313\">review on G2</a></em></p> \n<p>Since all of our Hubs are built on the same Primary Color foundation, our customers can expect a familiar, fast, and friendly user experience every time they add a new feature or product to their tech stack. This means customers can enjoy the benefits of each new addition right away, with no time lost to training, integration, or new-system frustration.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>As HubSpot's co-founder, Dharmesh Shah, puts it: \"Our customers' time-to-joy is reduced.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Once a customer learns how to use Automation in, say, Marketing Hub, they instantly know how Automation works in all of HubSpot's products across the CRM platform. So as their company scales and adds new products, features, and integrations to their tech stack, they can expect consistency, not complexity.</p> \n<p>They don't have to relearn how Messaging works or how Data is stored every time they add a new Hub — something they would likely have to do if they were working with a system that had been cobbled together through acquisitions or if they use different tools for different customer-facing teams.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. </strong><strong>The ability to run an entire business on a single platform.</strong></h3> \n<p><em>“I can manage the website, CRM, email marketing and all other efforts in one single place. This allows me to have a single location for all my data Reporting and have a single source of truth” – </em><em><a href=\"https://www.g2.com/products/hubspot-marketing-hub/reviews/hubspot-marketing-hub-review-4530415\">review on G2</a></em></p> \n<p>With HubSpot, fast-growing companies can run their whole business on a single system, because HubSpot offers the same insights and power to marketers, salespeople, and service professionals alike.</p> \n<p>And when all teams at a company are working out of the same familiar system, silos crumble, data is centralized, and information flows freely. The whole team has access to the same valuable insights, allowing them to understand their customers better and deliver a seamless experience across every touchpoint.</p> \n<p>For example, when a company's marketing team uses Marketing Hub and its sales team uses Sales Hub, both teams gain access to the same customer data in a centralized CRM.&nbsp;And because both Hubs offer identical functionality for recording and storing Data, it becomes equally easy for each team to access not only the data they generate, but also Data the other team generates.</p> \n<p>This gives marketers and salespeople a holistic view of the customer, enabling each of them to tailor their tactics and personalize their outreach. If a prospect is showing particular interest in marketing content about a certain feature, the sales team can see this information in the shared CRM and will know to focus on that feature on their next call with the prospect.</p> \n<p>They don't need to wait on a marketing report or rely on an impersonal script – they can personalize their outreach and hone in on a prospect's specific areas of interest, all as a result of both Hubs being built on the same foundation.</p> \n<h3><strong>Building Differently, Growing Better</strong></h3> \n<p>The challenges that companies face in 2021 are new, so our approach to building our products needs to be new as well. With the rise of the hybrid workplace, we're all finding our work lives intersecting our home and family lives, too. That raises the bar on what we expect from business software.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>People use HubSpot to power their businesses, to provide for their families, to help their communities thrive, and in many cases, to make the world a better place.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>It's now more important than ever that our CRM platform experience feels like something you'd use on the weekends, not just Monday morning.</p> \n<p>That's why we're fiercely committed to building software that has enterprise-grade power combined with consumer-grade&nbsp;intuitiveness and an experience as delightful as that offered by the apps we all use in our personal lives.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, our bar is set by what our customers need, not what our competitors have done in past decades. With the five Primary Colors powering our platform and our unwavering commitment to never compromise on customer experience, we are excited to continue to help our customers grow better in 2021 and beyond.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b3f6c3d6-d9d1-4855-8d6d-68ac9b57c41f&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b3f6c3d6-d9d1-4855-8d6d-68ac9b57c41f.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fprimary-colors-help-build-hubspot-crm&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 22 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/76520ae5-1a3b-4055-9e8e-95e150b90965.png","linkMd5":"9c13cfbdf5b5835485a340222717adba","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn31@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-34-689_d76cc3cb1508ee30.webp","destWidth":573,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4942,"destBytes":8720,"author":"Christopher O'Donnell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/76520ae5-1a3b-4055-9e8e-95e150b90965.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn31@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-34-689_d76cc3cb1508ee30.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20Primary%20Colors%20Help%20HubSpot%20Build%20a%20CRM%20That%20Customers%20Love.png?width=624&name=How%20Primary%20Colors%20Help%20HubSpot%20Build%20a%20CRM%20That%20Customers%20Love.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b3f6c3d6-d9d1-4855-8d6d-68ac9b57c41f.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn35@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-51-400_f1b3079c964621d4.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fprimary-colors-help-build-hubspot-crm&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-50-00-965_702b3b8dc41bc5df.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370056},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How to Generate Leads on LinkedIn, According to LinkedIn's VP of Marketing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/generate-leads-on-linkedin","description":"<p>As a marketer, you're undoubtedly aware of some of the major social media sites you can use for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-inbound-lead-generation-guide-ht?_ga=2.247234246.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">lead generation</a>. I'm willing to bet you've already heard about the importance of Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter — and if you use all three as part of your lead generation strategy, you might think you're all set.&nbsp;</p>  \n<p>However, if you're not using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/23454/the-ultimate-cheat-sheet-for-mastering-linkedin.aspx?_ga=2.251297604.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">LinkedIn</a> you could be missing out on a major opportunity to grow both brand recognition and revenue, especially if you’re a B2B business. In fact, studies have shown that LinkedIn is the <a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2020_B2B_Research_Final.pdf\">top paid and organic social channel</a> for B2B businesses, and 82% of B2B marketers report finding the <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/content/dam/me/business/en-us/marketing-solutions/cx/2020/pdfs/read-me-drive-more-leads-fa.pdf\">greatest success on the platform</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>These statistics make sense, especially if we consider platform-specific demographics. The average <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-for-business-guide?_ga=2.58489960.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">Instagram</a> user scrolls through their feed, like photos of their friends, watches their favorite celebrity’s Story, and occasionally uses the platform to find and purchase products.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Alternatively, the average LinkedIn user is on the site <em>specifically</em> for professionally-geared content. They're already seeking out information to help grow their businesses, so you should meet them where they are.</p> \n<p>Of course, it's easier said than done. Without a clear strategy in mind, the task of lead generation on LinkedIn can feel challenging. Justin Shriber, Vice President of Marketing at LinkedIn, was interviewed as part of HubSpot's campaign, \"<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/behind-the-screens?utm_source=hubspot&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=behind-the-screens&amp;utm_content=thought-leadership&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/generate-leads-on-linkedin&amp;hubs_post-cta=Advertising%2C%20a%20Look%20Behind%20the%20Screens&amp;_ga=2.217725908.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">Advertising, a Look Behind the Screens</a>.” Take a look at the full interview series <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/behind-the-screens?utm_source=hubspot&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=behind-the-screens&amp;utm_content=thought-leadership&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/generate-leads-on-linkedin&amp;hubs_post-cta=here&amp;_ga=2.58489960.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">here</a>, or keep reading to learn some of his key insights, as well as additional tips on how to use LinkedIn for lead generation.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Get the essential guide to using LinkedIn for marketing and professional  networking.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>LinkedIn Lead Generation Strategy</h2> \n<p>As a refresher, lead generation refers to all of the activities and strategies you use to attract potential customers. Generating leads is important because, with nurturing, potential customers can become paying customers that use your products and drive revenue.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>LinkedIn’s typical audience comprises professional decision-makers with purchasing power, helping you speak directly to the potential customers that can become paying customers. Below, we’ll discuss how you can use LinkedIn for lead generation.</p> \n<h3>1. Make sure your executives have a strong LinkedIn presence.</h3> \n<p>When you're first getting started on LinkedIn, it can be tricky to know how to dedicate your initial efforts. Should you create a compelling <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-company-pages?_ga=2.251297604.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">LinkedIn Page</a> and immediately begin posting content to your business's feed? Or should you start by posting all your job openings to attract new talent?</p> \n<p>Shriber suggests another strategy: \"We definitely want to fuel the growth of small businesses that have aspirations to grow to become larger, and we put together a playbook that allows them to do that. The playbook always starts with the individual LinkedIn profiles of the employees at the company, and in particular, the executives at the company.\"</p> \n<blockquote>\n \"[Executives are] trendsetters. They can make statements about what they stand for, and in many cases, develop a strong following in relatively short order.\"\n</blockquote> \n<p>Consider the leaders at your company and their current LinkedIn presence. Could they contribute more thoughtfully to <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/1164/linkedin-groups-membership-overview\">LinkedIn groups</a> within your industry or post more often to their feeds? More likely than not, your executives could be doing more to grow their LinkedIn following.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's take a look at <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/salliekrawcheck/detail/recent-activity/shares/\">Sallie Krawcheck's</a>, CEO and co-founder of Ellevest, LinkedIn activity:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Generate%20Leads%20on%20LinkedIn,%20According%20to%20LinkedIns%20VP%20of%20Marketing-1.png\" alt=\"linkedin personal profile page example\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">\n</div> \n<p>Krawcheck uses LinkedIn wisely, leveraging the platform to promote content from her own investment company while also liking or sharing other relevant financial content geared towards women. Ultimately, Krawcheck uses LinkedIn to build a personal brand and help her followers find valuable content related to investing and women in finance. Ideally, your executives should be doing the same.</p> \n<h3>2. Create a powerful LinkedIn Page for your business.</h3> \n<p>Once you've ensured your own executives have a strong LinkedIn presence, it's time to cultivate an impressive page.</p> \n<p>You'll want to ensure your page is active, with thought-provoking content and contributions to conversations already happening on LinkedIn.</p> \n<p>Shriber notes —&nbsp;\"Once you've got a strategy related to your executives and their presence on LinkedIn, step two is to think about the presence of your company on LinkedIn. We have a product called <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/blog/linkedin-news/2018/introducing-the-new-linkedin-pages\">LinkedIn Pages</a>, which has been incredibly powerful for businesses that want to establish their place in the world's professional community.\"</p> \n<blockquote>\n \"[LinkedIn Pages is] a free product,\" Shriber adds, \"and really, at the end of the day, it's a place for you to stage the content that you have to offer, and really promote all of the benefits that you have for people that want to follow you.\"\n</blockquote> \n<p>He continues, \"So, when you come to a good LinkedIn Page, you'll find information about what the company does, but beyond that, some of the thought leadership that's happening. There will be video content as well as the written word, commentary from executives, but also in many cases, information that's curated from other sources. It doesn't just need to be from the marketing group or from an internal source.\"</p> \n<h3>3. Post relevant content and updates.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>To ensure your LinkedIn page and profile are strong, consider posting various content types, including <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/83106/sharing-a-video-on-linkedin-faq\">video</a>. Featuring this industry-relevant content can help you position yourself as a knowledgeable source and establish relevance and credibility with potential customers.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>When you’re recognized as an insightful, valuable source, you’ll begin to develop connections with like-minded professionals that fit your ideal customer profile. If you post often, you’ll become a regular on their feed, and familiarity makes it easier to initiate further conversations.</p> \n<p>If you assume that the connections you have on LinkedIn are professionals within your industry, they can expose you to new audiences with the content you post. When your connections click ‘Like’ on a post you’ve made, it may show up on the feed of a new lead. This lead will see that your shared connection has liked your post, vouching for your credibility and authority, and possibly prompting them to send a request to connect.</p> \n<p>To ensure that you’re creating content that people want to see, follow your page analytics to figure out what resonates with them the most and create accordingly.</p> \n<h3>4. Join LinkedIn groups your clients and customers are in.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>LinkedIn, at its core, is a social platform like any other. Just as you can on Facebook, users can create groups centered around industry-relevant interests, and you should join these groups and have conversations with other professionals.</p> \n<p>You can post content and updates to encourage discussions about relevant topics or simply talk about the services you offer. If you’ve joined groups wisely, your potential customers can see what you say and begin to recognize you as a source of valuable information.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You can also use groups to learn more about your audience. If members are active, learn from what they say and discover common industry pain points and how leads want these issues addressed. Use this information to your advantage, and create hyper-targeted value propositions when you reach out that speak directly to your customer’s needs.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Use paid products to ensure your content reaches your intended audience.</h3> \n<p>Businesses with small marketing budgets may be wary of putting money behind paid campaigns on LinkedIn. They often ask — We have a small marketing budget, and we want to use it wisely. Where should we spend it? Given that LinkedIn is the top paid and organic channel for B2B businesses, spending your money on the platform would be worth your while.&nbsp;</p> \n<blockquote>\n Shriber told me, \"Once you've built that strong LinkedIn Page, companies tend to realize that that audience that's consuming information is incredibly valuable, and it's different than what they're finding on other platforms.\"\n</blockquote> \n<p>He adds, \"We have a series of paid products that you can then move into that allow you to insert content into the LinkedIn feed. Now you've got a series of followers or you've got a set of targeted members that you care about. Suddenly, they're seeing your content appear in the feed itself and there are some really rich ways to turn that engagement into actual activity.\"</p> \n<p>While LinkedIn has a native ads management service, you can also use HubSpot’s <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/ads?_ga=2.256464713.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">ads management tool</a> to create, organize, and execute advertising campaigns on LinkedIn. You’ll also get access to high-quality reports that explain ad performance, helping you optimize a strategy to meet your customers’ needs.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Ensure you have strong sales and marketing alignment.</h3> \n<p>You're likely all too familiar with the recent shift in consumer buying behavior. Nowadays, customers are researching online ahead of time and typically use marketing content to inform their purchasing decisions before even reaching out to a sales rep.</p> \n<p>Shriber describes the shift like this: \"What you're seeing now, is consumers are becoming more savvy about learning about products and services that they need and progressing deep into the sales process before they reach out, raise their hand, and say that they need help.\"</p> \n<p>He adds, \"It's becoming incumbent upon marketing to really meet the needs of customers that are investigating and exploring, and then seamlessly handing that off to salespeople so sales has context on the journey customers have already traveled.\"</p> \n<blockquote>\n \"I've got a number of customers that have come to me and said, my salespeople know my target customers better than my marketing group. They've been in the business for 20 years, and they know all the key people, so I'm going to use them to create awareness, build a brand in a way that historically has been reserved for marketing.\"\n</blockquote> \n<p>On the flip side, of course, marketers play a heavier role in closing a deal. Shriber told me, \"Imagine, for example, that you're procurement and you're trying to negotiate a contract. Historically, that's been the domain of a sales professional, but today, savvy marketers know that that's where you are in the sales process.\"</p> \n<p>Shriber adds, \"They're able to target that procurement person, send in some relevant content related to validation of the solution, why it's valuable, what other customers are saying about it, and all of a sudden, that marketer has played a key role in getting the deal closed.\"</p> \n<p>All of which is to say — it's critical you align your sales and marketing teams since they play equally valuable parts in finding prospects and closing deals, and they overlap more heavily now than ever before.</p> \n<p>To figure out strategies for better aligning your sales and marketing departments, take a look at this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/sales-and-marketing?_ga=2.256464713.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">Ultimate Guide to Sales and Marketing</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Leverage connections with current customers and clients.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>LinkedIn’s main draw is networking, and you should use this feature to your advantage for lead generation.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Connect with current customers and clients on LinkedIn and learn from who their industry connections are, as they may be relevant to you as well. If you have relationships with existing clients you connect with, ask for referrals, references, or simply learn how to get in contact with a connection they have that matches your customer profile.</p> \n<p>As LinkedIn is a professional network, such requests are less pushy, spammy, and salesesque than cold calling someone after finding their number online. Leads can receive your request to connect, browse your profile, and see your shared connection as a guarantee of trust.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In addition, when you connect with new leads, you’re using warm outreach. This means that you already know a bit about them and can immediately make propositions that relate to their interests, providing value to them off the bat.</p> \n<h3>8. Maintain a consistent presence on the platform.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Just like all of your other social media sites, LinkedIn requires consistency. If you post an article once a week and then log out, you’re not establishing yourself as a consistent presence with your connections. You also want to communicate consistently with your leads. Disappearing in the middle of a conversation is not a good look and does the opposite of furthering their interest in doing business with you.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As mentioned above, use platform analytics to learn about your audience’s interests, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-time-post-on-linkedin?_ga=2.256464713.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">when your posts get the most traction</a>, and create a strategy that will keep you consistently present and visible on LinkedIn.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>LinkedIn Can Help You Attract Your Ideal Customers</h2> \n<p>Ultimately, if you aren't using LinkedIn or using it often enough, you're likely missing out on significant opportunities to grow your business.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As Shriber told me, \"We've really tried to think through the full spectrum of what you might care about, from building a brand to generating leads, whether you're a small business or a large enterprise — and we built playbooks that address you where you are, and help you to get where you're going.\"</p> \n<p>Learn more from Justin Shriber and other advertising leaders by accessing an <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/behind-the-screens?utm_source=hubspot&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=behind-the-screens&amp;utm_content=thought-leadership&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/generate-leads-on-linkedin&amp;hubs_post-cta=exclusive%20interview%20series%20with%20LinkedIn%2C%20Google%2C%20and%20Facebook&amp;_ga=2.256464713.393759301.1614202868-613488095.1614202868\">exclusive interview series with LinkedIn, Google, and Facebook</a>.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"How to Use LinkedIn for Business and Marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgenerate-leads-on-linkedin&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 24 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png","linkMd5":"20b35b471d2cf17c3b6a94077f84234b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","destWidth":754,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7622,"destBytes":12106,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Generate%20Leads%20on%20LinkedIn,%20According%20to%20LinkedIns%20VP%20of%20Marketing-1.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-50-01-107_85ce3eb0b1d04252.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgenerate-leads-on-linkedin&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn97@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-02-401_dd80895da0486aa1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370060},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How Much Should Your Marketing Team Budget for 2021? [By Industry]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-budget-percentage","description":"<p>When I was hired for my first marketing role, I got really excited to pitch new, exciting ideas to my team.</p>  \n<p>And I thought — as long as I had data to support the potential success of a project — that my team would be <em>thrilled</em>&nbsp;to hear these ideas.</p> \n<p>Which they were. But they were also cautious, and one of their biggest concerns was, \"Okay, this sounds great … but how much is it going to cost?\"</p> \n<p>Ultimately, being a successful marketer isn't just about thinking strategically. It's also about adhering to a strict budget, and achieving new levels of growth while simultaneously choosing the most cost-effective option for your business.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll explore typical marketing budgets, as well as marketing budgets by industry, so you can determine how your budget matches up against competitors.</p> \n<p>Plus, we'll explore how much of your yearly revenue you should re-invest in marketing materials to see stronger long-term growth.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3e2abb94-93d9-4cf5-bd8e-6a96ecc14270&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Click here to download 8 free marketing budget templates.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e2abb94-93d9-4cf5-bd8e-6a96ecc14270.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">What's a typical marketing budget percentage?</h2> \n<p>As of February 2021, <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">Deloitte's annual CMO Survey</a>&nbsp;reports that marketing budgets are now roughly 11.7% of total company-wide budget — a <em>slight</em> decrease from the 12.6% marketers saw in June 2020, but still a record high that most marketers haven't seen over the last four years.</p> \n<p>(It's important to note, we saw record-high marketing budgets over the course of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/waking-up-in-a-digitally-transformed-world\">pandemic as companies relocated some budget towards digital marketing strategies</a>, rather than more offline tactics.)</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en/marketing/research/annual-cmo-spend-survey-research\">Gartner's 2020 CMO survey</a>&nbsp;confirms most marketing budgets rest around 11% of total company budget.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20much%20budget%20should%20I%20give%20to%20marketing%3F%20.jpg?width=1104&amp;name=how%20much%20budget%20should%20I%20give%20to%20marketing%3F%20.jpg\" alt=\"how much budget should I give to marketing? \" width=\"1104\" style=\"width: 1104px;\">While your own marketing department's budget depends on a variety of factors — including industry, company revenue performance, and business needs — this should help you ballpark a reasonable percentage of your total company-wide budget that you should allocate for your marketing teams.</p> \n<p>Of course, <em>what </em>strategies/channels marketing teams choose to invest in varies depending on individual company goals. For instance, while 73% of companies invested in website optimization in 2020, only 20% invested in machine learning and automation.</p> \n<p>Web optimization, digital media and search, and digital marketing were the <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">top three priorities for companies</a> when determining budget allocation in 2020 — with roughly 73%, 65%, and 57% of companies (respectively) investing in each.</p> \n<p>These <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-predictions-experts\">trends are predicted to continue</a> into 2021 and beyond.</p> \n<p>However, the data we've reported so far pertains to marketing budget percentage of overall company budget — but what about marketing budget as it pertains to overall company <em>revenue? </em>Let's dive into that, next.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Marketing Budget Percentage of Revenue</h2> \n<p>The U.S. Small Business Administration recommends small businesses (businesses with revenue less than 5 million) allocate between <a href=\"https://www.sba.gov/taxonomy/term/15051\">7% and 8% of total revenue to marketing</a>&nbsp;— assuming your business has margins in the range of 10-12 percent.</p> \n<p>The amount of revenue businesses allocate to marketing has increased steadily over the past 10 years, with average <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">marketing percentage of revenue landing around 13% in 2021</a>, compared to just <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">8% back in 2011</a>.</p> \n<p>B2B Product industries allocate, on average, roughly <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">10% of revenue to marketing</a>, which is similar to B2C Services (10.1%). B2B Services and B2C Product allocate <a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/topics/marketing.html\">higher numbers of 15% and 18%</a>, respectively, of total revenue.</p> \n<p>Of course, decisions related to marketing budget allocation remain largely industry-specific. To determine more accurate, industry-specific insights, let's explore marketing budgets by industry, next.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Marketing Budget Percentage by Industry [2021 Data]</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/chief-marketing-officer/articles/cmo-survey.html\">Deloitte's 2020 CMO Survey</a>&nbsp;found B2B (product-focused) companies attribute roughly 9.4% of overall budget to marketing efforts, while B2B (services-focused) companies attribute 11.4%.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, if you work for a B2C (product-focused) company, Deloitte reports 15.9% of overall budget is the average given to marketing teams — for B2C (service-focused) companies, this is closer to 12%.</p> \n<p>Of course, the type of business you work at (B2B or B2C) is only one factor when determining marketing budget percentage. Industry is a major factor, as well.</p> \n<p>For instance, marketing expenses are highest in the Education sector at 19.4% of total budget — and they're lowest in the Energy industry, at roughly 4%.</p> \n<p>If you work in the healthcare industry, you might expect to see a marketing budget around 7% of total budget.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, consulting services typically attribute 13%. Lastly, technlogy/software platforms attribute 12% of total company budget to marketing.</p> \n<p>If you're unsure how to manage your marketing budget, you're in luck. We've covered marketing budgets extensively in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-manage-marketing-budget-free-budget-templates\">How to Manage Your Entire Marketing Budget [Free Budget Planner Templates]</a>. Take a look at that post to create a marketing budget that works for you — and use templates and samples to get you started.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=fec839c8-058f-4d11-8943-c7e0c554fa27&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"download free marketing budget templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fec839c8-058f-4d11-8943-c7e0c554fa27.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-budget-percentage&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 23 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e2abb94-93d9-4cf5-bd8e-6a96ecc14270.png","linkMd5":"28732e67fd084b03d6928fc2beadd7c2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn57@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-550_ccb05f23cfee781e.webp","destWidth":526,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":5240,"destBytes":8172,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e2abb94-93d9-4cf5-bd8e-6a96ecc14270.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn57@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-550_ccb05f23cfee781e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20much%20budget%20should%20I%20give%20to%20marketing%3F%20.jpg?width=1104&name=how%20much%20budget%20should%20I%20give%20to%20marketing%3F%20.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn29@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-58-845_c8903173d74be36e.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fec839c8-058f-4d11-8943-c7e0c554fa27.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn20@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-00-261_af961930029e625f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-budget-percentage&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn2@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-55-597_c4b1dc4ca316d7e3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370057},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"21 Ways To Build Your Social Media Presence, Like HubSpot Marketers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/4663/how-to-monitor-your-social-media-presence-in-10-minutes-a-day.aspx","description":"<p>&nbsp;I was a lazy natural for most of my life. I had natural hair but I never took care of it in the way I should have.</p>  \n<p>I slicked it back in tight – albeit very cute – top buns, laid down my edges and kept it moving.</p> \n<p>Then, I discovered a natural hair stylist on Instagram who changed my outlook. She was active on the platform every day, often giving hair care advice, and spoke directly to my concerns. Within a few weeks, I was sold and ready to book an appointment.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Free Download: Social Media Calendar Template [Access Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Not every social media interaction is like that, but it's what every brand wants. To draw its target audience in, create content that resonates with them and build a connection, i.e.: social media presence.</p> \n<p>Let's dive into what social media presence is and how to build it.</p> \n<p>For brands, there's no single metric tied to social media presence. However, it can translate to a high engagement rate, a growing brand awareness, and a positive brand perception.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/krystalwu\">Krystal Wu</a>, social media community manager at HubSpot, highlights that visibility and presence are different.</p> \n<p>\"A social media channel has no presence if there is no audience who values it. Use social media to listen, monitor, and analyze your audience behavior,\" said Wu. \"That information will allow you to gain consumer feedback, improve new or existing relationships, and expand your brand's social presence.\"</p> \n<p>So, while visibility comes with having a strong presence, it's not the measure of success – resonance is.</p> \n<h2>Importance of Social Media Presence</h2> \n<p>Having a social media presence goes beyond having a profile with content. It means creating content tailored to the interests and needs of your target audience.</p> \n<p>Doing so builds trust, and once you have that, you're one step closer to earning your audience's business.</p> \n<p>Having a strong social media presence also allows you to better understand your audience.</p> \n<p>\"While there are a ton of growth 'hacks' to boost a brand's social presence, I think the greatest value goes back to knowing your audience,\" said <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ariel-boswell/\">Ariel Boswell</a>, social media analyst at HubSpot. \"The ability to know your audience so deeply to where you understand what captivates their attention and pair that with content that provides value in that moment is a recipe for success.\"</p> \n<p>Connecting with your community on this level helps you get to the core of their needs so you can better serve them with your product or service.</p> \n<h2>How To Increase Social Media Presence</h2> \n<h3>1. Engage your audience.</h3> \n<p>Social media is arguably the closest contact you have with consumers on a regular basis. Within a few hours after publishing, you can gauge your audience's response and learn something new with every post.</p> \n<p>Take it one step further by creating opportunities for your followers to connect with your brand on a deeper level. This can be inviting them to participate in discussions in the comment section, answering fun \"This or That\" quizzes, creating polls, answering Q&amp;As and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-live-download\">doing </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-live-download\">live videos</a>.</p> \n<p>You can gain invaluable insight into your audience's likes, dislikes, challenges and concerns through these activities. This will then arm you to create targeted campaigns that convert.</p> \n<h3>2. Manage your community.</h3> \n<p>Having a social media account without community management is like having a car that is always nearing empty (a.k.a my car in college). You won't make it very far.</p> \n<p>Community management is a major driver in building your social media presence. In fact, Wu says it's fundamental to a brand's growth, its image, and social success.</p> \n<p>\"Being proactive by reaching out to other brands, fans, customers and followers in similar industries really helps build that community around your brand,\" said Wu. \"People start to recognize the name, the types of conversations that brand is having and its level of knowledge in that specific market.\"</p> \n<p>This aspect of social media management requires brands to be proactive and seek out conversations that will draw audiences in.</p> \n<p>Think of it like going to a party. You showed up, but now you'll have to talk to a few people and start making some friends.</p> \n<p>\"Without doing these proactive pushes, just putting a brand on social and not tying in the community efforts won't get it very far,\" Wu added. \"Community management is the center of the customer journey, like the flywheel model, crafting the relationship between the brand and customer.\"</p> \n<h3>3. Stay active and be consistent.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever scrolled past a brand and done a double take, and thought \"<em>Oh you! I forgot you even existed.</em>\" No brand wants that kind of reaction.</p> \n<p>Social media is a game of visibility and with brands. It's often out of sight, out of mind, so it's crucial that you are active on your social media platforms and post consistently.</p> \n<p>Many brands start off strong, posting everyday and then less and less until they're only posting once in a while.</p> \n<p>\"Success doesn't usually happen on your first, second or even third try. Social media is playing the long game and once brands realize that it doesn't usually blow up overnight, that's when consistency comes into play,\" said Wu. \"In social, you need to test, experiment, analyze, and even take risks to learn what strategy your brand should move forward with to connect and build an audience.\"</p> \n<p>If you find yourself running out of content or ideas, start with a lower posting cadence and limit the platforms on which you are active. It's also helpful to plan out your content at least a month ahead of time and have your creative assets ready so that you're never left scrambling.</p> \n<h3>4. Understand that it's a long game.</h3> \n<p>A lot of the mistakes brands make on social media stem from a desire to grow quickly.</p> \n<p>You get impatient and want to generate results fast. So, you might try the social version of get-rich-quick schemes to build your following. However, those strategies are only valuable on the surface.</p> \n<p>But you soon realize that they don't actually bring you closer to meeting your goals and connecting with your audience.</p> \n<p>\"Don't take the 'easy' way out by paying for views and followers,\" Wu said, \"because you'll eventually run into a wall where you have this audience but no engagement, no one converting or signing up for your content.\"</p> \n<p>Organic growth is the most authentic and effective way of building a sustainable presence. Why? Because you'll be getting real data from your target audience and that will help you tailor your approach to serve them better.</p> \n<h3>5. Stick to your brand voice and aesthetic.</h3> \n<p>Consistency isn't only about your posting schedule, it also encompasses your brand as a whole.</p> \n<p>Your brand identity should be the same across all marketing channels. It can be confusing for consumers to understand your brand if its messaging and identity seems to switch from one day to the next. How can your audience connect to something they can't figure out?</p> \n<p>So, once you design your brand strategy, make sure it aligns with your social media strategy.</p> \n<h3>6. Track your competitors.</h3> \n<p>Your competitors are like your neighbors. It's fine to be a little nosy and see what they're up to from time to time.</p> \n<p>\"When I think of conducting a competitive analysis I go in with the expectation to be both challenged and inspired,\" said Boswell. \"The biggest thing you should look for when evaluating a competitor's social media presence is how they are positioning themselves in the market and how shared or overlapped audiences are perceiving their efforts.\"</p> \n<p>While it's good to be aware of your competitive landscape, Boswell emphasizes that it shouldn't influence your entire social strategy. What works well for one brand may not be suitable for yours, so be selective about what ideas you're adapting.</p> \n<h3>7. Leverage trends and buzzy content.</h3> \n<p>Trends make social media go round.</p> \n<p>Every few weeks or even days, there's a new trend making its way around platforms like Twitter and TikTok. Brands often ask themselves two questions: \"<em>Should we join in on this? </em>\" and \"<em>How do we make this our own? </em>\"</p> \n<p>Trends can boost your brand awareness and help you generate bursts of traffic. It's an opportunity to think outside of the box and join in on something you already know your audience will enjoy.</p> \n<p>When in doubt, always refer back to your brand strategy. Is this in alignment with your overall brand identity and messaging? If not, treat it like a school dance you're chaperoning and sit it out.</p> \n<h3>8. Adjust your posts based on current events.</h3> \n<p>These days, consumers hold brands to a higher standard.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/data/brands-creating-change/\">Companies are expected to be more vocal about social issues </a>and be more transparent on their stance. This approach should also be reflected in your social media strategy during times of social unrest, cultural events and news.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, it can be as simple as not posting anything for the day and pausing paid social ads. In other cases, it can require releasing a statement.</p> \n<p>In any case, you have to be flexible and work quickly to determine how to proceed.</p> \n<h3>9. Invest in high-quality creative assets.</h3> \n<p>Social media is one of the main sources of brand discovery.</p> \n<p>Your target persona is scrolling through Instagram, your post shows up and it garners their interest. What's one of the first things they'll do? Visit your profile.</p> \n<p>You often only have a few seconds to make an impression on a potential customer and you don't want them turned away because of bad content. This can include low-quality images, copy with grammar mistakes and use of non branded content.</p> \n<p>Your social media profile tells a story, so make sure it's the one you want to tell.</p> \n<h3>10. Listen to your audience and adjust as needed.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-listening-tools\">Social monitoring and listening </a>can be your cheat sheet to success on social media.</p> \n<p>They give you insight into not only your industry and competitors but also how your audience is perceiving your brand. Using that as leverage to inform your brand strategy can make you stand out among your competitors.</p> \n<p>\"Where we once used to live in the marketing age of brand innovation, we now live in a consumer first era. This is an exciting time, particularly on social media where brands have a direct line of communication with their audience,\" said Boswell. \"Brands that not only actively engage with but seek to deeply understand their audience are winning at social.\"</p> \n<p>Not sure where to start? Begin by searching topics relating to your brand and seeing how audiences are responding to it. Then, search your company name and see what's the general sentiment surrounding your brand.</p> \n<h3>11. Optimize your profiles for SEO.</h3> \n<p>As mentioned before, social media has made it easier than ever to discover new brands. But just because it's easier, doesn't mean there's no work to do on your end.</p> \n<p>When thinking of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-tips\">SEO</a>, it's easy to assume it's website optimization. However, you'll also want to optimize your social profiles to make it easier for your target audience to find you.</p> \n<p>One of the easiest ways to optimize your posts is with hashtags. Beyond that, you'll also want to optimize your bio page in a few ways:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Include a few keywords (identified through social media tools) in your company description bio.</li> \n <li>Have working links that lead your followers to other channels, like your website or YouTube channel.</li> \n <li>Use the same profile image and handle on all social media platforms.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>12. Own your mistakes.</h3> \n<p>If you're posting regularly on social media, you're bound to make a mistake. Not to mention, the landscape itself is always changing and evolving.</p> \n<p>Whether it's trying a strategy that didn't quite work out or writing copy that was misunderstood by your audience, it's a normal part of growing your social media presence. Wu says that it's an opportunity to discover areas for improvement.</p> \n<p>\"Strategies in social are built by experimentation and taking chances to find what fits and what doesn't. If you found out that you've made a mistake, own up to it, learn from it and evolve into something better.\"</p> \n<p>It's OK to make mistakes, as long as you take note of the experience and use that to inform your next course of action.</p> \n<h3>13. Treat each platform as its own.</h3> \n<p>What works on one platform won't necessarily work on another.</p> \n<p>One thing you may be tempted to do with social media is duplicate your own content. There's an important difference to note between <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/examples-repurposing-content\">repurposing </a>and duplicating.</p> \n<p>The former refreshes the content to extend its value while the latter keeps it the same, simply transferring it to another platform.</p> \n<p>When duplicating your content, you run the risk of missing the mark with your audience. While they may love your videos on YouTube, they may not like them on TikTok, as the context is different.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, be sure to customize your approach to the platform you're posting on.</p> \n<h3>14. Balance promotion and adding value.</h3> \n<p>There's a time to promote your product or service, and a time to add value. Find the right balance and you're golden.</p> \n<p>Most users don't go on social media to see ads. Social media is usually a place to be entertained, whether that's through funny videos or informative threads.</p> \n<p>While a certain amount of promotion is expected, you'll quickly lose your audience if the only thing you push is product. You'll have to balance this with content they can relate to.</p> \n<p>Once you've earned their trust and gained credibility, they'll be more open to trying your product or service.</p> \n<h3>15.Use tools to publish, monitor and track posts.</h3> \n<p>Social media is not a set-it-and-forget-it marketing play – it requires constant monitoring.</p> \n<p>This is where <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-tools\">social media tools</a> come in handy. Software like <a href=\"https://contentstudio.io/\">Content Studio </a>and <a href=\"http://later.com\">Later </a>allow you to schedule your posts on various platforms, track your analytics and competitors, conduct audits, and get data-driven recommendations for future posts.</p> \n<p>Social media tools become indispensable when building a sustainable presence, especially as you scale your business.</p> \n<h3>16. Prioritize accessibility.</h3> \n<p>When it comes to accessibility online, the progress on social media is slow moving.</p> \n<p>Things like captions and alt text may seem superfluous, but they actually hold more weight than you may think. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/accessible-marketing\">Accessible social content</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Makes it easier for deaf, hard of hearing and visually impaired people to engage with your content.</li> \n <li>Helps you reach audiences who may not be native speakers of your language.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>As you reach users who may have otherwise not had access to your content, you can grow your brand awareness and generate more engagement.</p> \n<h3>17. Let the data guide you.</h3> \n<p>Analytics aren't just there to tell you how your posts are currently forming, they're also meant to inform your future ones.</p> \n<p>To grow your social presence, you'll have to understand not only <em>what </em>is performing well but also <em>why</em>.</p> \n<p>\"Seek to understand what captivates and engages your audience depending on where they are in their lifecycle,\" said Boswell. \"This can be auditing historic posts to establish quantitative performance benchmarks or looking at qualitative data to understand what types of content, topics, or media formats resonate best.\"</p> \n<p>You can start finding those answers in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics\">your analytics </a>dashboard. As you track your posts' performance, you will start to notice trends and can use them to guide your strategy.</p> \n<h3>18. Invest in the right platforms.</h3> \n<p>It's easy to assume that you should be visible everywhere to increase your social media presence. However, if your audience doesn't live on certain platforms, it's a waste of time and resources.</p> \n<p>That's why you should do some research to narrow down exactly where your audience is, so you can meet them where they are. You can find this information through surveys, interviews, competitors, and perusing the platforms.</p> \n<h3>19. Leverage user-generated content (UGC).</h3> \n<p>Your own content can only take you so far on social media. The great thing is, you can reach audiences beyond your community through influencers, partners and your own followers.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-work-with-influencers\">Influencer marketing </a>is one of the best ways to attract an audience that falls within your target market but may be currently out of reach.</p> \n<p>What's more, influencers and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/user-generated-content-stats\">UGC </a>come with social proof, which sets up a solid foundation on which to build your relationship with newcomers. It's like your friend introducing you to their friend. You already trust them so naturally, there's some built-in trust with the person they're introducing you to.</p> \n<h3>20. Promote your social accounts on other platforms.</h3> \n<p>You've got awesome social media accounts. So, you'll want to make sure your audience can find them.</p> \n<p>For instance, you might have a dedicated list of subscribers who may not yet follow you on social media. As such, be sure to include links to your social platforms across all channels – both digital and offline.</p> \n<p>This includes the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Business cards</li> \n <li>Emails</li> \n <li>Website</li> \n <li>YouTube videos and your channel homepage</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>21. Embrace new features.</h3> \n<p>In recent months, Twitter introduced \"Twitter Spaces,\" YouTube released a new feature called \"Shorts\" and Instagram launched \"Guides.\"</p> \n<p>Social media platforms come out with new features all the time, and brands are often apprehensive to try them. However, don't be afraid to be an early adopter.</p> \n<p>\"Social media is an ever changing space, every few months there's a new feature, placement, or algorithm change,\" said Boswell. \"Always test assumptions and keep an eye on your performance metrics to see how these changes impact your strategy and be prepared to pivot.\"</p> \n<p>Boswell adds that you should be open to these new additions while still investing in strategies your audience already responds well to.</p> \n<h2>Companies With the Best Social Media Presence</h2> \n<p>There are countless companies who are building strong communities on social media – here are a few of them.</p> \n<h3>1. Night Owl Cookies</h3> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 375px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto; As such, they deliver high-quality images that definitely catch your attention.</p> \n<p>Night Owl Cookies is mostly active on Instagram, posting almost everyday. The brand engages its audience with delicious pictures of fresh cookies, funny memes, and fun copy. They also host giveaways on a regular basis, which is a great way to expand their reach.</p> \n<h3>2. Fanm Djanm</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://fanmdjanm.com/\">Fanm Djanm </a>is a lifestyle brand whose identity is rooted in the concept of strength, femininity and self-love. The brand keeps this messaging consistent in every post and on every social platform.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 375px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto; max-height: 272px;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n   <p>They say love makes you do crazy things, but maybe what they really mean is that when you love radically &amp; when you have radical self-love ... you become fearless ✨⁠⁠<br>⁠⁠<br>It is a bold act to love, period ❤️⁠⁠<br>⁠⁠<br>What is love to you? <a href=\"https://t.co/gjgPG49rfP\">pic.twitter.com/gjgPG49rfP</a></p>— Fanm Djanm (@FanmDjanm) \n   <a href=\"https://twitter.com/FanmDjanm/status/1361021670010605573?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 14, 2021</a>\n  </blockquote> \n </div>\n</div> \n<p>Despite having a strong base on Instagram, the brand is also highly active on Twitter as well as Pinterest where they garner 2.5 million monthly views.</p> \n<h3>3. Robert Half</h3> \n<p>Being a staffing firm, <a href=\"https://www.roberthalf.com/\">Robert Half </a>targets both businesses and job-seeking individuals.</p> \n<p>The brand's social team has struck the right balance by creating valuable content for both audiences.</p> \n<p>Job seekers can find discussions surrounding pressing topics like salary negotiation and interview prep. Hiring managers can learn about everything from employee retention to hiring mistakes.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 504px; max-height: 343px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 68.06%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe src=\"https://www.linkedin.com/embed/feed/update/urn:li:share:6766069650070495232\" height=\"343\" width=\"504\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>On top of that, the brand is constantly engaging its audience with thoughtful questions and polls that give them an insight into their needs, interests and pain points.</p> \n<h3>4. Valence Community</h3> \n<p>As we've covered in the previous section, social media requires businesses to pinpoint what content their audiences want and deliver it. Constantly promoting products or services just won't work – <a href=\"https://valence.community/\">Valence Community </a>gets that.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden;
