Valence Community also tailors its content to match the platform. While its Instagram page is filled with inspirational and motivational content, its Twitter page highlights its added value resources, like events and webinars.</p> \n<p>Building your social media presence is always a work in progress but at the root of it, it's all about staying in tune with your audience.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=8ac717e3-f0e5-4d45-ba5d-2809051062a9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"free social media content calendar\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8ac717e3-f0e5-4d45-ba5d-2809051062a9.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F4663%2Fhow-to-monitor-your-social-media-presence-in-10-minutes-a-day.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 29 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png","linkMd5":"e7e6538fdc6eadb71c0d19fc7e00c21e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn51@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-37-456_f265e6907ec7aa82.webp","destWidth":454,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5078,"destBytes":7114,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn51@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-37-456_f265e6907ec7aa82.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8ac717e3-f0e5-4d45-ba5d-2809051062a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn94@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-01-611_927af36356d0922e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F4663%2Fhow-to-monitor-your-social-media-presence-in-10-minutes-a-day.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-51-423_63bd0ee6c00ff860.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370029},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"The Plain-English Guide to Integrated Marketing Communications","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/integrated-marketing","description":"<p>I fly Southwest Airlines almost exclusively. They offer reasonable prices, make it easy to rack up points, and always have fun and kind flight attendants.</p> \n<p>One thing I’ve noticed about Southwest is their branding is on <em>point</em>. Whether I’m booking a flight on their mobile application, being served my go-to in-flight ginger ale, or walking through the terminal at Midway Airport, I’m surrounded by Southwest’s consistent brand colors, messaging, and imagery.</p> \n<p>This is an example of integrated marketing at work. If you’re interested in presenting a cohesive, consistent brand experience that leaves your products or services top-of-mind — like Southwest does — this guide is for you. Read on to learn more about integrated marketing and how to create a campaign of your own.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" /></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Imagine discovering a new brand on Instagram and visiting the company’s website to purchase one of their products. If their website promoted a different message or campaign than the one you found on their Instagram account, you’d have a hard time understanding the gist of the brand, right?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31057/the-ultimate-checklist-for-integrated-marketing.aspx\">Integrated marketing</a> exists to eliminate these disparities and differences regardless of how or when a customer interacts with your brand. It’s similar to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-multi-channel-marketing-faqs-ht\">multi-channel marketing</a>, except integrated marketing is what aligns the message you’re sharing on all of those channels.</p> \n<p>Speaking of channels, integrated marketing doesn’t apply to just your inbound or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-digital-marketing\">digital marketing</a> channels; <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/how-to-shift-your-marketing-from-traditional-to-inbound\">traditional media</a> channels are also included. Many of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/integrated-marketing#integrated-marketing-examples\">integrated marketing examples we’ll review below</a> incorporate traditional marketing channels such as print, radio, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tv-ad-business\">TV ads</a>.</p> \n<p>Now, let’s talk about integrated marketing campaigns.</p> \n<h3>Why are integrated marketing campaigns effective?</h3> \n<p>While integrated marketing campaigns can differ in their goals (e.g. converting views, building brand awareness, etc.), they should all have one component in common: to align your marketing channels to present a united marketing “front”.</p> \n<p>If your marketing channels are players, consider your integrated marketing campaign the coach in charge of running plays and helping your channels work as a unified system — not disparate ones.</p> \n<p>It’s also more effective to run integrated marketing campaigns as compared to campaigns on individual channels. Integrated marketing campaigns are impactful for a few reasons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>They reach a wider audience than a single marketing channel.</li> \n <li>They have a greater chance of being seen on multiple channels, thus keeping your brand top-of-mind and pushing visitors closer to conversion.</li> \n <li>They build trust with visitors as they see a consistent message on multiple channels.</li> \n <li>They save you money since assets can be shared between and repurposed for different marketing channels and, depending on your campaign, customers can help you market your product or service for you.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<p>So, how can you build your own integrated marketing campaign? Follow these steps to get started.</p> \n<h3>1. Establish your overarching campaign goal.</h3> \n<p>Before you consider what channels will be part of your integrated marketing campaign, you must consider the goal of the entire campaign.</p> \n<p>Maybe you’ve <strong>launched a new product, service, or initiative</strong> and want to get it in front of customers — like <a href=\"https://marketingland.com/southwest-airlines-boasts-simple-fee-structure-fun-transfarency-campaign-146092\">Southwest’s <em>Transfarency</em></a>. Maybe you’ve <strong>completely</strong> <strong>rebranded</strong> and want to broadcast your new message — like <a href=\"https://www.wk.com/work/old-spice-smell-like-a-man-man/\">Old Spice’s <em>Smell Like a Man, Man</em></a>. Perhaps you’ve simply <strong>chosen a new positioning tagline</strong> and want your audience to start associating your brand with it — like <a href=\"https://thebrandgym.com/snickers-youre-not-you-when-youre-hungry-the-best-global-campaign-ever/\">Snickers’ <em>You’re Not You When You’re Hungry</em></a>.</p> \n<p>(Don’t worry, we’ll <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/integrated-marketing#integrated-marketing-examples\">dig deeper into these examples</a> later.)</p> \n<p>Whatever your campaign goal may be, always remember to make it <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples\">SMART</a>. This will help you stay focused, track your campaign success, and learn how to improve the next time around.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>These goals should also relate to at least one of the following key performance indicators (KPIs) and their subsequent metrics, which <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/integrated-marketing#launch-measure-and-iterate-your-campaign\">you can track when you launch your campaign</a>.</p> \n<table style=\"width: 100%; border-color: #99acc2; border-style: solid; border-collapse: collapse; table-layout: fixed;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">KPI</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">related Metrics</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Traffic/reach</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Unique page views by channel and source</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Engagement</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Bounce rate; average time on page</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Top (and falling) content</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Top page views; top exits</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Impact</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Click-throughs; conversions; backlinks</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Sentiment</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Comments; social shares</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Lead generation</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Total leads; total sessions; session to lead conversion rate</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Sales</td> \n   <td style=\"width: 50%;\">Lead to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-marketing-qualified-lead-mql-under-100-sr\">marketing qualified lead</a> (MQL); MQL to sales qualified lead (SQL); customer purchase/closed-won business</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>Also, while increased engagement and new leads are always exciting, a multi-channel campaign should also consider the bigger picture: how your campaign impacts sales opportunities and business revenue. Take a moment to map out how you want your campaign to impact your bottom line, too.</p> \n<h3>2. Choose your marketing channels and set goals for each one.</h3> \n<p>Now that you know your overarching integrated marketing campaign goal, you probably have a better idea of what channels (if not all of them) can help you reach that goal.</p> \n<p>For example, if your goal is to roll out a new logo and branding suite, you don’t necessarily need to leverage radio ads. On the other hand, if you’re extending your audience to target a new geographic region or city, radio ads, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/billboard-advertising\">billboard ads</a>, TV ads, and other local channels may come in handy.</p> \n<p>When choosing your channel(s), it all boils down to what you’re trying to achieve through your integrated marketing campaign. There are 10 major marketing “channels” that you can use to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-distribution\">distribute your campaign content</a>.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/advertising\">Advertising</a> (both print and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc\">PPC</a>)</li> \n <li>Direct marketing</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-guide\">Email marketing</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/public-relations\">PR</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/personal-selling\">Personal selling</a></li> \n <li>Sales promotions</li> \n <li>Digital marketing (e.g. website, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy-guide\">content marketing</a>, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo\">SEO</a>)</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing\">Social media</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/event-marketing\">Events</a> and sponsorships</li> \n <li>Packaging</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Your integrated marketing campaign should include a variety of marketing channels in order to reach the widest audience and drive home your campaign message. If you see one or more channels plateau, don’t hesitate to add, remove, or test new ones.</p> \n<h3>3. Define your buyer personas by channel.</h3> \n<p>Every marketing channel targets its own specific <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">buyer persona</a>. For this reason, instead of defining a broad persona for your campaign, you must define your audience by channel.</p> \n<p>There will inevitably be some overlap, but it’s wise to understand exactly who you’re talking to on each medium and how you can tailor those specific assets to be the most successful.</p> \n<p><em>Note: With some campaigns, you may be targeting a specific audience. In this case, steps 2 and 3 would be flipped — you’d define your buyer persona(s) first and then decide which channels can help you reach that audience.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/persona-templates?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download our free Persona Templates to easily organize your audience segments and make your marketing stronger.</em></a></p> \n<h3>4. Identify your channel managers.</h3> \n<p>Depending on the size of your marketing team, you may have different people (or entire teams) in charge of different channels. When running a multi-channel marketing campaign, you must determine who <em>specifically</em> will be in charge of ensuring their channel(s) is aligned with the campaign.</p> \n<p>This is important for two reasons: 1) that manager is the expert on their channel (e.g. audience, posting cadence, optimization tactics, reporting strategies, etc.) and will know how to tailor the campaign content to be the most successful; and 2) putting one person in charge of all channels may be overwhelming and will cause the content and campaign to suffer.</p> \n<p>Perhaps you have a smaller marketing team where one person handles multiple channels. Regardless of your team size, do your very best to share channel management responsibilities across a few people — ideally with one person handling one or two channels.</p> \n<h3>5. Create adaptable marketing assets and messaging.</h3> \n<p>At this point, you have your campaign goal, target audience(s), and marketing channels. It’s now time to create your integrated marketing campaign content. This stage is where <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/copywriting-examples\">copywriting</a>, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design\">graphic design</a>, and other creative processes come into play.</p> \n<p>Before I dive into <em>how</em>, let’s talk about an important component of integrated marketing content: <strong>adaptability</strong>. To keep your campaign consistent (and ease your workload), you should be able to <a href=\"https://beomniscient.com/repurpose-content/\">repurpose any content</a> to be used on different channels.</p> \n<p>For example, let’s say your integrated marketing campaign is focused on the launch of a new 3-minute brand video. You could repurpose this video into:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>30-second and one-minute “trailer” videos</li> \n <li>Still images</li> \n <li>Quotes</li> \n <li>GIFs</li> \n <li>Hashtags</li> \n <li>Blog posts</li> \n <li>Soundbites</li> \n</ul> \n<p>As you develop and repurpose these creative assets, keep them aligned with your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">brand guidelines</a> <em>and</em> consistent with each other. In fact, it may be helpful to create your own set of brand guidelines for your integrated marketing campaign to share with your team and any channel managers.</p> \n<p>This documentation could include a few things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Visual guidelines (logo, color palette, typography, etc.)</li> \n <li>Any developed and repurposed assets in multiple file formats</li> \n <li>Voice and tone guidelines (taglines, preferred language, words to avoid, etc.)</li> \n <li>Messaging guidelines (pain points, goals, types of content, resources, etc.)</li> \n <li>Buyer persona information and guidelines</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Integrated marketing is all about a consistent brand experience. Be sure your campaign assets reflect that, regardless of what channel your audience visits or sees.</p> \n<h3>6. Establish your plan for collecting leads.</h3> \n<p>Whether or not you intend your campaign to collect leads, you should always be prepared to receive them. You don’t want to leave this as an afterthought once you launch your campaign. Even if you’re simply campaigning to raise awareness of your brand, consider how your visitors might convert to leads — and, eventually, customers.</p> \n<p>First, consider how a visitor might convert to a lead. Would they subscribe to your newsletter? Input their information to download a content offer? Create an account on your website? Ensure these conversion aspects of your campaign are also on-brand with the rest of your visual and messaging assets.</p> \n<p>Next, consider how your leads will be nurtured once they convert. Would they roll into an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/marketing-automation\">automated email workflow</a>? Would you pass them along to Sales? However you go about this step, make sure your leads aren’t forgotten once they willingly give over their information.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>As always, communicate with Sales to confirm that they’re aware of your campaign and on-board with your plan for new leads and customers.</p> \n<h3>7. Launch, measure, and iterate your campaign.</h3> \n<p>Ready to launch your integrated marketing campaign? It might be time to put your campaign to work … but it’s not time to rest just yet.</p> \n<p>Remember those <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/integrated-marketing#kpis-and-metrics\">KPIs and metrics from step one</a>? Whichever KPIs relate to your overarching campaign goal (e.g. boosting brand awareness, rebranding, new product, etc.), start tracking those subsequent metrics each week, month, and quarter (depending on how long your campaign is running) to see how successful it is at reaching your goal.</p> \n<p>As always, take what you learn from each integrated marketing campaign and apply it to future campaigns. With the right strategies, managers, and tools in place, you can create a never-ending cycle of integrated marketing campaigns — and wins.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Integrated Marketing Strategies and Best Practices</h2> \n<p>As you construct your integrated marketing campaign, there are a few key strategies and best practices to keep in mind. We’ve detailed them here, and they apply regardless of what media, channels, or goals you’ve chosen.</p> \n<h3>Align behind the scenes.</h3> \n<p>In order for you to successfully implement an integrated marketing approach, it’s imperative that you not only choose marketing channel managers but that all your marketing managers also communicate often about projects and campaigns.</p> \n<p>While not every integrated marketing campaign or promotion needs to be on all of your channels, they should at least complement each other to avoid a fragmented brand experience for customers.</p> \n<h3>Consider the channel transition.</h3> \n<p>Integrated campaigns receive traffic from a number of sources — and pass along those sources like a game of <em>Hot Potato</em>. Consider how a visitor may view/experience each marketing channel 1) if it was their first visit and 2) if they transitioned from another channel. Think about how each channel can help others convert.</p> \n<p>For example, say a customer saw your new billboard on their way to work and, once they arrived, visited the website that was on the billboard. Imagine if, on your website, the customer couldn’t easily find whatever your billboard was marketing. How confusing would that be? That customer would likely drop off immediately.</p> \n<h3>Don’t neglect the small overlaps.</h3> \n<p>When preparing to launch your integrated marketing campaign, it’s tempting to separately think about each channel and its respective media assets. But this thought process inherently goes against the ethos of integrated marketing. Integrated marketing exists to eradicate the silos of traditional marketing and bring together a cohesive campaign experience.</p> \n<p>For this reason, don’t neglect the places in which your campaign overlaps. Here are a few examples:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Your email signature, where you can plug your social media handles, website URL, or video links</li> \n <li>Your social media bios and posts, where you can include links to your website, <a href=\"https://beomniscient.com/content-marketing-seo/\">blog posts</a>, content offers, or other digital content</li> \n <li>Your blog and website, where you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/14624/7-ways-to-integrate-search-engine-and-social-media-marketing.aspx\">incorporate social sharing buttons</a></li> \n <li>Your standalone landing pages, where you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/27426/7-ways-to-integrate-search-engine-and-email-marketing.aspx\">optimize for relevant keywords and SEO</a></li> \n <li>Your PPC copy, where you can test subject lines to see what your audience responds to</li> \n</ul> \n<p>While these overlaps might not directly support your campaign goals, they help your audience transition seamlessly between channels, enjoy that consistent, cohesive brand experience, and ultimately find their way to a page that converts them.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Every marketer knows just how much you can learn from those who’ve come before you. In this section, we’ve pulled together a handful of well-executed integrated marketing campaigns to give you an example of just how successful this tactic can be.</p> \n<h3>1. <em>Smell Like a Man, Man</em> by Old Spice</h3> \n<p>For years, I associated Old Spice with something only my dad or grandfather would wear. I can remember the old, white bottle of aftershave — the one with the faded pirate ship — that used to sit in my dad’s cabinet.</p> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20old%20bottle.jpg?width=570&amp;name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20old%20bottle.jpg\" alt=\"integrated marketing example old spice old bottle\" width=\"570\" style=\"width: 570px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<div>\n  &nbsp; \n</div> \n<div>\n  I don’t think I’m the only one who held this association, so it’s no surprise that, in 2010, Old Spice launched a major rebranding campaign to give its products a more youthful, playful feel — and ultimately attract a younger audience. Not only did Old Spice change the design of their packaging, but they also renamed their products and crafted a new tagline (“Smell Like a Man, Man”). \n</div> \n<p>The initial campaign launch featured one 30-second TV spot, <em>The Man Your Man Could Smell Like</em>, that was so beloved that Old Spice launched a handful of others.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/owGykVbfgUE\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>But Old Spice didn’t stop at the TV commercial. They also included their website, product pages, Instagram, YouTube, and other channels in their campaign.</p> \n<p>No, they don’t all feature the specific characters or taglines from the original TV spots (remember, the campaign launched almost 10 years ago), but they do reflect the same tone, theme, and brand, thus giving customers a consistent brand experience across all media.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20website.png?width=600&amp;name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20website.png\" alt=\"integrated marketing example old spice website\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<h3>2. <em>Transfarency </em>by Southwest Airlines</h3> \n<p>I discussed Southwest Airlines' consistent branding at the beginning of this article. One campaign that stands out is their <em>Transfarency</em> movement, which introduced a brand new word that marketed Southwest as an airline with straightforward pricing and no hidden fees.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/AiBZTnk5c44\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>The campaign originally launched in 2015, but Southwest has since been rolling out phases to release new elements and <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/behind-every-seat-is-a-story-southwest-airlines-launches-next-phase-of-transfarency-consumer-campaign-300524643.html\">introduce more themes and stories</a>. This tactic has helped elongate the campaign message and truly solidify the association between flying Southwest and saving money on fares.</p> \n<p>Southwest has used almost every possible marketing channel to broadcast this campaign: a dedicated landing page on which you can purchase tickets, print advertisements posted along airport walls and tucked behind airplane seats, a slew of video spots, and plenty of user-generated content on their social media.</p> \n<h3><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20southwest%20instagram.png?width=600&amp;name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20southwest%20instagram.png\" alt=\"integrated marketing example southwest instagram\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></h3> \n<h3>3. <em>You’re Not You When You’re Hungry</em> by Snickers</h3> \n<p>Snickers is one of my favorite chocolate bars, so I paid close attention when I started to see commercials for their <em>You’re Not You When You’re Hungry</em> advertisements.</p> \n<p>Launched at the 2010 Super Bowl, this Snickers campaign has remained top-of-mind for chocolate and candy lovers everywhere.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/VLy4qzV1gL0\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>One reason for this is the campaign’s humor, but the other, more pertinent reason is that Snickers pasted this movement <em>everywhere</em> … on its website, social media, TV, print ads, and more, and they included plenty of celebrities to boot. By presenting an aligned, cohesive integrated marketing campaign, customers now think of Snickers when craving a sweet snack — and <a href=\"https://www.campaignlive.com/article/case-study-fame-made-snickers-youre-not-when-youre-hungry-campaign-success/1413554\">the company has benefitted as a result</a>.</p> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20snickers%20billboard.jpg?width=600&amp;name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20snickers%20billboard.jpg\" alt=\"integrated marketing example snickers billboard\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<h3>4. Share<em> a Coke</em> by Coca-Cola</h3> \n<p>Coca-Cola's Share a Coke campaign was unique in that the company put their customers front and center by featuring names and fun phrases on their product. Not only did this create endless advertising angles, but it led to endless user-generated content from customers wanting to share products with their own name. The #ShareaCoke hashtag was shared via <a href=\"https://www.investopedia.com/articles/markets/100715/what-makes-share-coke-campaign-so-successful.asp#:~:text=Consumers%20shared%20more%20than%20500%2C000,Facebook%20followers%20that%20same%20year.\">500,000+ customer photos</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Share-a-Coke-with-even-MORE-jpg.jpeg?width=600&amp;name=Share-a-Coke-with-even-MORE-jpg.jpeg\" alt=\"coke share a coke integrated marketing campaign\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>When this campaign was at its height, I found myself taking pictures of and even buying Cokes featuring the names of my friends and family. It seems that others did the same — the campaign resulted in an increase in Coke consumption from <a href=\"https://mayecreate.com/blog/3-marketing-lessons-from-the-share-a-coke-campaign/\">1.7 billion to 1.9 billion</a> daily servings.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\"> \n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.5%; margin: 0px;\"> \n   <iframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/sGjQnGio5mw?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>5. <em>Grow Better</em> by HubSpot</h3> \n<p>HubSpot has countless digital properties — its blog, website, social media channels, and SaaS products. This level of variety requires a lot of consistency in messaging and marketing.</p> \n<p>HubSpot recently set its ultimate vision to <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/grow-better\">help customers grow better</a> — all customers, on all channels. To promote this messaging, it updated all content to reflect this vision.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-02-08%20at%208.43.32%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-02-08%20at%208.43.32%20PM.png\" alt=\"integrated marketing communications hubspot grow better\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>The message may be short, but the impact is big. However and wherever customers interact with HubSpot, its integrated marketing has ensured that they know how HubSpot operates — and why they should become a customer.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\"> \n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.5%; margin: 0px;\"> \n   <iframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/XrLyMDBt0Ps?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<h2>Integrated Marketing Helps You Grow Better</h2> \n<p>Integrated marketing turns your marketing campaigns into multi-channel movements. In today’s omnichannel world — with consumers encountering your brand online, on social media, and on their daily commutes — integrated marketing is more important than ever to capture new customers and build brand recognition and loyalty.</p> \n<p>Implement these steps and strategies for your next integrated marketing campaign, and it will surely be a success.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\" /></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fintegrated-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 24 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"3b86d2cd4c59b3154c3f797fd8873714","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"adecker@hubspot.com (Allie Decker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20old%20bottle.jpg?width=570&name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20old%20bottle.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn47@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-56-038_abd29905f85f19e2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20website.png?width=600&name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20old%20spice%20website.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn97@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-412_10ce3117a1bbd4bd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20southwest%20instagram.png?width=600&name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20southwest%20instagram.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn19@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-55-656_d4bc897786334ae9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/integrated%20marketing%20example%20snickers%20billboard.jpg?width=600&name=integrated%20marketing%20example%20snickers%20billboard.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn57@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-52-651_6fa7dbb3a3036739.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Share-a-Coke-with-even-MORE-jpg.jpeg?width=600&name=Share-a-Coke-with-even-MORE-jpg.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn65@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-55-105_8ecd5fc3bc75b835.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-02-08%20at%208.43.32%20PM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-02-08%20at%208.43.32%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn16@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-54-693_164307d9c8f0adf3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn3@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-54-880_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fintegrated-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn2@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-418_05cdb617609183af.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370132},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","title":"What Is Market Share & How Do You Calculate It?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-calculate-market-share","description":"<p>Growing up, I used to play \"grocery store\" with my sister. We'd go into our pantry, take out all the food, and set up a grocery store in our living room. I would typically \"buy\" goldfish.</p> \n<p>You might be thinking, <em>\"What does this have to do with market share?\" </em></p> \n<p>Well, let's say that I bought 10 bags of goldfish from various \"companies\" that my sister, mom, and dad owned. If three of those bags were my sister's goldfish, that would mean that she had a 30% market share of my goldfish.</p> \n<p>Put simply, that is market share. But how does that impact marketers?</p>  \n<p>As marketers, it's important to understand market share so you know how your company ranks against competitors and can develop new marketing strategies to reach more potential customers. In this post, we’ll outline what market share is, how to calculate it, give real life examples, and explain how you can increase yours.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Market Research Templates [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>What is market share?</h2> \n<p>Market share is the percentage of an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/total-addressable-market\">industry's sales</a> that a particular company owns. Essentially, it is the share of total industry revenue that your business has generated from selling your products and services. Businesses with larger market shares are industry leaders and competition for smaller companies.</p> \n<p>You can think of it like this: if consumers buy 100 t-shirts and 70 of them are from company A, 25 from company B, and 5 are from company C, Company A owns a market share of 70% and is the leading industry <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/competitive-analysis-kit?_ga=2.142252277.691120071.1613660624-1549707591.1613660624\">competitor</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Market share is typically calculated for a specific time period, like yearly or quarterly sales, and is sometimes separated by region.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>Market Share Formula</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ms%20formula.png?width=600&amp;name=ms%20formula.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"formula that you can use to find your business market share\"></p> \n<p>Calculating your market share will give you an overall understanding of your position in the industry, but it’s also helpful to understand how you measure up to your direct competitors.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Relative Market Share</h3> \n<p>Relative market share is a way to compare your performance to industry leaders.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Rather than using total industry revenue, you’re dividing your market share by your top industry competitors market share, and multiplying the result by 100. The result will show you the portion of the market you own in relation to your largest competitor. The image below shows the relative market share formula.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4>Relative Market Share Formula</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rms%20formula.png?width=600&amp;name=rms%20formula.png\" alt=\"mathematical formula that is used to calculate your business relative market share\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h2>&nbsp;</h2> \n<h2>Market Share Examples</h2> \n<p>It may be easier to understand market share with real-life examples, so we’ll go over some below for businesses you may already be familiar with.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Nike Market Share</h3> \n<p>Nike is part of the athletic footwear and apparel industry selling a wide variety of sports equipment, casual shoes, and accessories.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>With footwear alone, Nike’s global market share is estimated to be <a href=\"https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5a2aa0f99f07f5a1339d0569/t/5a5e5a78e2c48341149c61d7/1516132986505/Landscape+Analysis+-+Nike+PDF.pdf\">29.25%</a>. The brand is an industry competitor for Adidas and Under Armour.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Tesla Market Share</h3> \n<p>Tesla is part of the automotive industry and it produces electric vehicles (EV). Within the EV industry, Tesla holds an <a href=\"https://electrek.co/2020/10/30/tesla-tsla-market-share-global-ev-sales-change/\">18% </a> market share.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>While that number may seem small, it’s important to recognize that the market for EV worldwide is significantly smaller than standard vehicles. EV’s market share in the automobile industry is <a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mckinsey-electric-vehicle-index-europe-cushions-a-global-plunge-in-ev-sales\">2.8% </a> and Tesla’s is <a href=\"https://www.torquenews.com/1083/here-s-what-tesla-s-current-market-share-looks-globally-us-china-and-europe\">.8% </a>. These differences are significant, which is why it is important to analyze relative market share to compare your business to your direct competitors, rather than just the market as a whole.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Google Market Share</h3> \n<p>Google has a market share of <a href=\"https://gs.statcounter.com/search-engine-market-share\">91.86%</a>, making it the most popular search engine in the world. It dominates the competition, as the second-largest industry leader is Bing with a market share of just 2.71%.</p> \n<p>Once you’ve calculated your market share and understand how you relate to your industry competitors, you can begin strategizing how to increase your overall revenue.</p> \n<h2>How To Expand Your Market Share</h2> \n<p>Below are a few strategies your company can use to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-increase-market-share\">expand your market share</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>1. Lower prices.</h3> \n<p>A great way to compete in your industry is to offer low prices. This is the low-hanging fruit of expanding your market share because consumers typically look for lower cost products.</p> \n<p>However, it's also important to note being the cheap option isn't the right move for every brand. You want to ensure that you’re <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/pricing-strategy?_ga=2.163188859.691120071.1613660624-1549707591.1613660624\">pricing products </a> appropriately in terms of providing value to customers, but not losing out on revenue opportunities for the sake of beating out the competition.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Innovate new products and features.</h3> \n<p>Companies that are innovating and bringing new technology to the table often see their market share increase.</p> \n<p>New products and features attract new customers, a.k.a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-acquisition?_ga=2.231037272.691120071.1613660624-1549707591.1613660624\">acquisition </a>, which is a driving factor for generating revenue. New customers make new purchases and, in turn, contribute to higher profit margins and larger contributions to overall industry revenue. Larger contributions directly translate to increased market share.</p> \n<h3>3. Delight your customers.</h3> \n<p>One of the best ways to grow your market share is to work on existing customer relationships.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>By delighting current customers by providing exceptional experiences, you can inspire <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-loyalty?_ga=2.231037272.691120071.1613660624-1549707591.1613660624\">customer loyalty </a>. Loyal customers are more likely to make repeat purchases, which increases your business revenue and contribution to total industry revenue. As mentioned above, higher revenue contributions equals a higher market share percentage.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>4. Increase brand awareness.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/brand-positioning-strategy\">Branding awareness</a> and national marketing play a large role in capturing market share. It's important to get your name out there so customers know who you are. Becoming a household name and the preferred brand in an industry will help increase your market share.</p> \n<p>Generally, larger companies have the highest market share because they can provide products and services more efficiently and effectively.</p> \n<p>But, why is this so important? Below, let's figure out what impact market share can have on your company.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Market share is more important in industries that are based on discretionary income. In industries that are constantly growing, market share doesn't always have a large impact. However, it's important to keep in mind that a company can have too much market share — also known as a monopoly.</p> \n<p>For example, with growing industries, which have a growing available market share, companies can still increase their sales even if they are losing market share.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, with discretionary income industries, such as travel or non-essential goods like entertainment and leisure, the economy can have a major impact on market share. Sales and margins can vary depending on the time of year, meaning that competition is always at an all-time high.</p> \n<p>Higher competition often leads to risky strategies. For instance, companies might be willing to lose money temporarily in order to force competitors out of the industry and gain more of the market share. Once they have more market share, they can raise prices.</p> \n<h2>Understand Your Market Share to Increase Business Success</h2> \n<p>Lower market shares can let you know that you need to focus on customer acquisition, marketing to raise brand awareness, and overall strategies to increase revenue. Higher percentages indicate that your current strategy is effective, and you should focus your efforts on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-retention?_ga=2.242572741.691120071.1613660624-1549707591.1613660624\">customer retention </a> and product innovation.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Whether your company is well-established or just starting out, it’s important to understand your business’ industry standing as it will help you meet business objectives and achieve desired success.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=560aa80b-9e0b-4615-851c-f23e4f49b62f&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/560aa80b-9e0b-4615-851c-f23e4f49b62f.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-calculate-market-share&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 25 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da.png","linkMd5":"038f7fd7cfa532c548e26430779a749e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn8@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-715_3c323ccea639359f.webp","destWidth":486,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":5174,"destBytes":7456,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn8@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-715_3c323ccea639359f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ms%20formula.png?width=600&name=ms%20formula.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rms%20formula.png?width=600&name=rms%20formula.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn69@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-52-973_e619c9ad07700135.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/560aa80b-9e0b-4615-851c-f23e4f49b62f.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn98@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-58-608_56bafbfb62a605be.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-calculate-market-share&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn34@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-52-616_c6d8af48f0522757.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425369989},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"The Plain English Guide to Writing a Business Case","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-case","description":"<p>Have you ever heard the age-old classic story of a company that got its start from a back-of-the-napkin idea? Or about the start-ups that started in someone's garage?</p> \n<p>While all those stories are, of course, inspirational, a huge element that they leave out is that every business started because someone felt the project justified spending time and money on it.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>That's why some projects require you to write a business case. Whether you want to start a company, pitch a new product, or perhaps you just want your business to use a new project management tool. Either way, a project that requires time and resources will also require justifying those expenses in the form of a business case.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review what a business case is, plus an example and template to inspire your own business case.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=e9d2eacb-6b01-423a-bf7a-19d42ba77eaa&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Business Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/e9d2eacb-6b01-423a-bf7a-19d42ba77eaa.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>In a business case, you might include the background on a project, expected benefits, costs, risks, and opportunities. This document will justify taking on a certain project. So, how do you develop a business case? Let's dive in below.</p> \n<h2>Business Case Development</h2> \n<p>To develop a business case, you'll need to write several key components, including a proposal, strategy, budget, SWOT analysis, and project plan. With these documents, you should be able to prove that the project you're pitching is worth doing.</p> \n<p>Let's dive into the steps for how you'll develop a business case below:</p> \n<h3>1. Research</h3> \n<p>Before you can write a business case, you need to do your research. First, you should have a goal in mind for your project, whether it's to create a new product, help drive more traffic/leads, or improve user experience.</p> \n<p>Write down your goal and then conduct research to prove that your project is the way to achieve your goal.</p> \n<p>You can begin by researching what competitors are doing and look for gaps that your project solves.</p> \n<p>Start to brainstorm what this project's strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats are. Additionally, you'll want to learn about your market -- whoever will be the consumer of the project, even if that's your own team.</p> \n<p>Finally, you should start to look into what a budget would look like for your proposed solution.</p> \n<h3>2. Focus on one component at a time.</h3> \n<p>A business case will usually include several documents. Focus on one at a time, while keeping your notes organized.</p> \n<p>Start with your proposal, then move on to your SWOT analysis, the competitive analysis, the project plan, overall strategy, and then the budget. It can be easy to get lost in just one of these tasks, so focus on one thing at a time to complete the bigger picture business case.</p> \n<h3>3. Write an implementation plan.</h3> \n<p>Once you've gathered your research and you're working through each component, it's time to start thinking about implementation.</p> \n<p>How will you implement your project? Once you've made the business case that your project should be done, stakeholders will wonder how you'll execute it.</p> \n<p>To do this, write an implementation plan that discusses how you'd complete the project and metrics that you'd track to measure success.</p> \n<p>Once you're done writing your business case, look at the whole document and ask yourself whether it's comprehensive, measurable, and adaptable.</p> \n<p>A business case doesn't need to be an entire business plan for a new product. Sometimes it will be less formal due to the size of the project. Either way, you want to make a strong case for your project, so it should be easy to understand and implement.</p> \n<p>Now, let's look at an example of what a business case might look like.</p> \n<h2>Business Case Example</h2> \n<p>Now that you've seen what it takes to write a business case and what the process looks like, let's look at an example for inspiration.</p> \n<p>In the example below, the project is about getting a new phone system to help the sales staff. Because this is a fairly small project, the business case isn't several pages long with exhaustive research.</p> \n<p>However, it's important to keep in mind that while your business case might look something like this for a small scale project, it might include several pages of information if you're pitching something like a new product or a new UI to improve user experience.</p> \n<p>The point in the business case is that it's adaptable to be whatever you need. However, the components of the business case will be the same regardless of how long it is. Every business case should include why a project should be done, the benefits, costs, risks, and budget.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"A business case example.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Plain%20English%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Business%20Case.png?width=600&amp;name=The%20Plain%20English%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Business%20Case.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 600px; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://expertprogrammanagement.com/2017/06/project-business-case/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h2>Simple Business Case Template</h2> \n<h3>Proposal</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Project details</li> \n <li>Strategic context</li> \n <li>Vision, goals, objectives</li> \n <li>Benefits</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats)</h3> \n<h3>Competitive Analysis</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>See if competitors are doing the same thing</li> \n <li>Look for gaps in their offerings, if applicable</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Risk Analysis</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>What risks are involved?</li> \n <li>Will these risks present opportunities?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Market Assessment</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Do your consumers want this?</li> \n <li>How will this help your stakeholders?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Budget</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Economic analysis</li> \n <li>ROI</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Implementation/Project Plan</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Roles/Team</li> \n <li>Duties/Responsibilities</li> \n <li>Stakeholders</li> \n <li>Specs and Requirements</li> \n <li>Timeline</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you have a new project idea for your company that requires a budget and resources, it might be a good idea to develop a business case to show your superiors that the project is worth taking on.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9ce704de-19f2-4fd0-8041-22dc3c021b87&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Business Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9ce704de-19f2-4fd0-8041-22dc3c021b87.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbusiness-case&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
