//cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-58-881_54bca6256a9a007b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ted-mission-statement.png?width=600&name=ted-mission-statement.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn62@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-50-02-100_2ec4fed4b931cffa.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9dbb6b2a-959e-401f-b57b-e77d3b99e9c8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-08-557_f134fd4b7561102c.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7d6729c4-6dba-43ab-98a4-742fe7f417d4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn77@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-01-282_9ac2e8dff55fd36a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finspiring-company-mission-statements&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn44@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-55-894_fa4d282dc74c1321.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370014},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"What is a Marketing Plan & How to Write One [+Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-plan-examples","description":"<p>You did it.</p> \n<p>You've been spearheading your organization's content marketing efforts for a while now, and your team's performance has convinced your boss to fully adopt content marketing. There's one small problem, though.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Your boss wants you to write and present a content marketing plan to them, but you've never done something like that before. You don't even know where to start.<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Fortunately, we've curated the best content marketing plans to help you write a concrete marketing plan that's rooted in data and produces real results.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll discuss what a marketing plan is and how some of the best marketing plans implement strategies that serve their respective businesses.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>The purpose of a marketing plan is to write down your tactics and strategies in an organized fashion. This will help keep you on track, and measure the success of your campaigns.</p> \n<p>Writing a marketing plan will help you think of each campaign's mission, buyer personas, budget, tactics, and deliverables. With all of this information in one place, you'll have an easier time staying on track with a campaign, noticing what works and what doesn't, and measuring the success of your strategy.</p> \n<h3>Featured Resource: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=bottom\">Free Marketing Plan Template</a></h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mkt-pl-cover-1.png?width=280&amp;name=mkt-pl-cover-1.png\" alt=\"mkt-pl-cover-1\" width=\"280\" style=\"width: 280px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p>Looking to develop a marketing plan for your business? Click here to download HubSpot's free <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">Marketing Plan Template</a> to get started.</p> \n<h2>Types of Marketing Plans</h2> \n<p>Depending on the company you work at, you might want to leverage a variety of different marketing plans. Here are just a few:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Quarterly or Annual Marketing Plans:</strong> These plans highlight the strategies or campaigns you'll take on in a certain period of time.</li> \n <li><strong>Paid Marketing Plan:</strong> This plan could highlight paid strategies, such as native advertising, PPC, or paid social media promotions.</li> \n <li><strong>Social Media Marketing Plan:</strong> This plan could highlight the channels, tactics, and campaigns you intend to accomplish specifically on social media.</li> \n <li><strong>Content Marketing Plan:</strong> This plan could highlight different strategies, tactics, and campaigns in which you'll use content to promote your business or product.</li> \n <li><strong>New Product Launch Marketing Plan:</strong> This plan will be a roadmap for the strategies and tactics you'll implement to promote a new product.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Keep in mind that there's a difference between a marketing plan and a marketing strategy.</p> \n<h3>Marketing Strategy vs. Marketing Plan</h3> \n<p>A <strong>marketing strategy</strong> describes how a business will accomplish a particular mission or goal. This includes which campaigns, content, channels, and <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing\">marketing software</a> they'll use to execute on that mission and track its success.</p> \n<p>For example, while a greater plan or department might handle social media marketing, you might consider your work on Facebook as an individual marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>A <strong>marketing plan</strong> <em>contains</em> one or more marketing strategies. It is the framework from which all of your marketing strategies are created, and helps you connect each strategy back to a larger marketing operation and business goal.</p> \n<p>Let's say, for example, your company is launching a new software product it wants customers to sign up for. This calls for the marketing department to develop a marketing plan that'll help introduce this product to the industry and drive the desired signups.</p> \n<p>The department decides to launch a blog dedicated to this industry, a new YouTube video series to establish expertise, and an account on Twitter to join the conversation around this subject -- all of which serve to attract an audience and convert this audience into software users.</p> \n<p>Can you see the distinction between the business's marketing plan versus the three marketing strategies?</p> \n<p>In the above example, the business's <em>marketing plan</em> is dedicated to introducing a new software product to the marketplace and driving signups to that product. The business will execute on that plan with three <em>marketing strategies</em>: a new industry blog, a YouTube video series, and a Twitter account.</p> \n<p>Of course, the business might also consider these three things one giant marketing strategy, each with their own specific content strategies. How granular you want your marketing plan to get is up to you. Nonetheless, there are a certain set of steps every marketing plan goes through in its creation. Learn what they are below.</p> \n<h3>1. State your business's mission.</h3> \n<p>Your first step in writing a marketing plan is to state your mission. Although this mission is specific to your marketing department, it should serve your business's main mission statement. Be specific, but not too specific. You have plenty of space left in this marketing plan to elaborate on how you'll acquire new customers and accomplish this mission.</p> \n<p>For example, if your business's mission is \"to make booking travel a delightful experience,\" your marketing mission might be \"to attract an audience of travelers, educate them on the tourism industry, and convert them into users of our bookings platform.\"</p> \n<h3>2. Determine the KPIs for this mission.</h3> \n<p>Every good marketing plan describes how the department will track its mission's progress. To do so, you'll need to determine your key performance indicators, or \"KPIs\" for short. KPIs are individual metrics that measure the various elements of a marketing campaign. These units help you establish short-term goals within your mission and communicate your progress to business leaders.</p> \n<p>Let's take our example marketing mission from the above step. If part of our mission is \"to attract an audience of travelers,\" we might track websites visits using organic page views. In this case, \"organic page views\" is one KPI, and we can see our number of page views grow over time.</p> \n<p>These KPIs will come into the conversation again in step 4, below.</p> \n<h3>3. Identify your buyer personas.</h3> \n<p>A buyer persona is a description of whom you want to attract. This can include age, sex, location, family size, job title, and more. Each buyer persona should be a direct reflection of your business's customers and potential customers. Therefore, it's critical that business leaders all agree on what your buyer personas are.</p> \n<p>You can develop buyer personas for free <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-buyer-persona-makemypersona\">right here</a>.</p> \n<h3>4. Describe your content initiatives and strategies.</h3> \n<p>Here's where you'll include the main points of your marketing and content strategy. Because there are a laundry list of content types and channels available to you today, it's critical that you choose wisely and explain how you'll use your content and channels in this section of your marketing plan.</p> \n<p>A content strategy should stipulate:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Which types of content you'll create.</strong> These can include blog posts, YouTube videos, infographics, ebooks, and more.</li> \n <li><strong>How much of it you'll create.</strong> You can describe content volume in daily, weekly, monthly, or even quarterly intervals. It all depends on your workflow and the short-term goals you set for your content.</li> \n <li><strong>The goals (and KPIs) you'll use to track each type.</strong> KPIs can include organic traffic, social media traffic, email traffic, and referral traffic. Your goals should also include which pages you want to drive that traffic to, such as product pages, blog pages, or landing pages.</li> \n <li><strong>The channels on which you'll distribute this content.</strong> Some popular channels at your disposal include Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube, Pinterest, and Instagram.</li> \n <li><strong>Any paid advertising that will take place on these channels.</strong></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Clearly define your plan's omissions.</h3> \n<p>A marketing plan explains what the marketing team is going to focus on. However, it also explains what the marketing team is <em>not</em> going to focus on.</p> \n<p>If there are other aspects of your business that you aren't serving in this particular plan, include them in this section. These omissions help to justify your mission, buyer personas, KPIs, and content. You can't please everyone in a single marketing campaign, and if your team isn't on the hook for something, you need to make it known.</p> \n<h3>6. Define your marketing budget.</h3> \n<p>Your content strategy might leverage many free channels and platforms, but there are a number of hidden expenses to a marketing team that need to be accounted for.</p> \n<p>Whether it's freelance fees, sponsorships, or a new full-time marketing hire, use these costs to develop a marketing budget and outline each expense in this section of your marketing plan.</p> \n<h3>7. Identify your competition.</h3> \n<p>Part of marketing is knowing whom you're marketing against. Research the key players in your industry and consider profiling each one in this section.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind not every competitor will pose the same challenges to your business. For example, while one competitor might be ranking highly on search engines for keywords you want your website to rank for, another competitor might have a heavy footprint on a social network where you plan to launch an account.</p> \n<h3>8. Outline your plan's contributors and their responsibilities.</h3> \n<p>With your marketing plan fully fleshed out, it's time to explain who's doing what. You don't have to delve too deeply into your employees' day-to-day projects, but it should be known which teams and team leaders are in charge of specific content types, channels, KPIs, and more.</p> \n<p>Ready to make your own marketing plan? Get started using <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template-generator?hubs_post-cta=anchor&amp;_ga=2.17785081.1722133554.1556546702-983944916.1546275206\">this free template</a> and take some inspiration from the real examples below.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>6 Marketing Plan Examples to Help You Write Your Own</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy-guide#sm.000006kcb7al12e6hrf3ntbljlejv\">HubSpot's Comprehensive Guide for Content Marketing Strategy</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: Content Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>At HubSpot, we've built our marketing team from two business school graduates working from a coffee table to a powerhouse of hundreds of employees. Along the way, we've learned countless lessons that've shaped our current content marketing strategy, so we decided to illustrate our insights in a blog post to teach marketers how to develop a successful content marketing strategy, regardless of their team's size.</p> \n<p>In this comprehensive guide for modern marketers, you'll learn:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What exactly content marketing is.</li> \n <li>Why your business needs a content marketing strategy.</li> \n <li>Who should lead your content marketing efforts.</li> \n <li>How to structure your content marketing team, based on your company's size.</li> \n <li>How to hire the right people for each role on your team.</li> \n <li>What marketing tools and technology you'll need to succeed.</li> \n <li>What type of content your team should create, and which employees should be responsible for creating them.</li> \n <li>The importance of distributing your content through search engines, social media, email, and paid ads.</li> \n <li>And finally, the recommended metrics each of your teams should measure and report to optimize your content marketing program.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://contently.com/2018/05/02/formula-optimize-marketing-campaign/\">Shane Snow's Marketing Plan for His Book Dream Team</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: Content Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>A successful book launch is a prime example of data-driven content marketing. Using data to optimize your content strategy spreads more awareness for your book, gets more people to subscribe to your content, converts more subscribers into buyers, and encourages more buyers to recommend your book to their friends.</p> \n<p>When Shane Snow started promoting his new book <em>Dream Team, </em>he knew he had to leverage a data-driven content strategy framework. So he chose his favorite one: the content strategy waterfall, which is defined by <a href=\"https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/definition/waterfall-model\">Economic Times</a> as a model used to create a system with a linear and sequential approach. To get a better idea of what this means, take a look at the diagram below:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/5%20Marketing%20Plan%20Examples%20to%20Help%20You%20Write%20Your%20Own.png?width=600&amp;name=5%20Marketing%20Plan%20Examples%20to%20Help%20You%20Write%20Your%20Own.png\" alt=\"Contently's content strategy waterfall.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Snow wrote a blog post about how the content strategy waterfall helped him successfully launch his new book. After reading it, you can use his tactics to inform your own marketing plan. More specifically, you'll learn how he:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Applied his business objectives to decide which marketing metrics to track.</li> \n <li>Used his ultimate business goal of earning $200,000 of sales or 10,000 purchases to estimate the conversion rate of each stage of his funnel.</li> \n <li>Created buyer personas to determine which channels his audience would prefer to consume his content on.</li> \n <li>Used his average post view on each of his marketing channels to estimate how much content he had to create and how often he had to post on social media.</li> \n <li>Calculated how much earned and paid media could cut down the amount of content he had to create and post.</li> \n <li>Designed his process and workflow, built his team, and assigned members to tasks.</li> \n <li>Analyzed content performance metrics to refine his overall content strategy.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can use Snow's marketing plan to cultivate a better content strategy plan, know your audience better, and think outside the box when it comes to content promotion and distribution.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.chiefoutsiders.com/blog/go-to-market-plan-template\">Chief Outsiders Go-To-Market Plan for a New Product</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: New Product Launch Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>When you're looking for a marketing plan for a new product, the Chief Outsiders template is a great place to start. Marketing plans for a new product will be more specific because they're targeted to one product versus an entire company's marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>After reading this plan, you'll learn how to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Validate a product</li> \n <li>Write strategic objectives</li> \n <li>Identify your market</li> \n <li>Compile a competitive landscape</li> \n <li>Create a value proposition for a new product</li> \n <li>Consider sales and service in your marketing plan</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.dropbox.com/s/rkokpejolafiqmy/ContentMarketingStrategyTemplate.docx?dl=0\">Buffer's Content Marketing Strategy Template</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: Content Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>Writing a content plan is challenging, especially if you've never written one before. Buffer decided to help out the content marketing community.</p> \n<p>By sifting through countless content marketing strategy templates and testing the best, they crafted a content marketing plan template with instructions and examples for marketers who've never documented their content strategy.</p> \n<p>After reading Buffer's marketing plan template, you'll learn how to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Answer four basic questions that'll help you form a clear executive summary.</li> \n <li>Set SMART content marketing goals.</li> \n <li>Create highly accurate audience personas by interviewing real content strategists.</li> \n <li>Solve your audience's problems with your content.</li> \n <li>Do competitive research by analyzing your competitors' and industry thought leaders' content.</li> \n <li>Evaluate your existing content strategy by examining the topics and themes of your highest and lowest performing pieces.</li> \n <li>Determine which types of new content to craft, based on your team's ability and bandwidth.</li> \n <li>Establish an editorial calendar.</li> \n <li>Develop a promotional workflow.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Buffer's template is an incredibly thorough step-by-step guide, with examples for each section. The audience persona section, for example, has case studies of real potential audience personas like \"Blogger Brian\". If you're feeling overwhelmed by the process of creating a marketing guide, this can help ease you into it.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://contently.com/strategist/2016/09/28/4-questions-content-plan/\">Contently's Content Plan</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: Content Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>Contently's content methodology works like a flywheel. Instead of applying an entirely new strategy to each new marketing campaign, they leverage the strategy of their previous marketing campaign to drive the next one. Similar to a flywheel, their content methodology needs an initial push of energy to get the gears in motion.</p> \n<p>What supplies this energy? Their content plan.</p> \n<p>Contently fleshed out their entire content plan in a blog post to help marketers develop a self-sustaining <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing\">marketing process</a>. After reading it, you'll learn how to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Align your content objectives and KPIs with your business goals.</li> \n <li>Create highly detailed buyer personas using psychographics instead of traditional demographics.</li> \n <li>Craft content for each stage of your marketing funnel, based off your prospects' pain and passion points.</li> \n <li>Identify your most effective marketing channels.</li> \n <li>Discover the content topics your audience actually craves.</li> \n <li>Assess your organization's need for resources.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>By applying a flywheel-like strategy to your own marketing efforts, you essentially take away the burden of applying new strategies to each individual marketing campaign. Instead, your prior efforts gain momentum over time, and dispel continual energy into whatever you publish next.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/davelavinsky/2013/09/30/marketing-plan-template-exactly-what-to-include/#2df9855f3503\">Forbes' Marketing Plan Template</a></h3> \n<h4>Main objective: Content Marketing Plan</h4> \n<p>An oldie, but a goodie -- Forbes published a marketing plan template that has amassed almost four million views since late 2013. To help you sculpt a marketing roadmap with true vision, their template teaches you how to fill out the 15 key sections of a marketing plan, which are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Executive Summary</li> \n <li>Target Customers</li> \n <li>Unique Selling Proposition</li> \n <li>Pricing &amp; Positioning Strategy</li> \n <li>Distribution Plan</li> \n <li>Your Offers</li> \n <li>Marketing Materials</li> \n <li>Promotions Strategy</li> \n <li>Online Marketing Strategy</li> \n <li>Conversion Strategy</li> \n <li>Joint Ventures &amp; Partnerships</li> \n <li>Referral Strategy</li> \n <li>Strategy for Increasing Transaction Prices</li> \n <li>Retention Strategy</li> \n <li>Financial Projections</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you're truly lost on where to start with a marketing plan, this guide can help you define your target audience, figure out how to reach them, and ensure that audience becomes loyal customers.</p> \n<p>These marketing plans serve as initial resources to get your content marketing plan started -- but to truly deliver what your audience wants and needs, you'll likely need to test some different ideas out, measure their success, and then refine your goals as you go.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in April 2019, but was updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-plan-examples&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 23 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"647e04e928b0299a4bcb6db72681f204","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mkt-pl-cover-1.png?width=280&name=mkt-pl-cover-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn46@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-50-01-230_291ab45a3dabaa75.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/5%20Marketing%20Plan%20Examples%20to%20Help%20You%20Write%20Your%20Own.png?width=600&name=5%20Marketing%20Plan%20Examples%20to%20Help%20You%20Write%20Your%20Own.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn54@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-52-619_e1d55a29f887911a.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn3@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-54-880_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-plan-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn92@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-57-595_93289b2d53aa78d1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370118},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","title":"30 YouTube Channel Ideas to Help You Choose Your Own","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas","description":"<p>Starting a YouTube channel is a lot of work. Not only do you have to spend time scripting, producing, and editing videos, but you also have to find a topic you’re passionate about and make sure it resonates with people.</p> \n<p>To help inspire you, we found thirty popular YouTube categories that you can start a channel about. Read on to learn why viewers love to engage with these types of YouTube videos, and<a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/youtube-marketing\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/youtube-marketing?_ga=2.23647098.1117465120.1616791718-1796479782.1616791718\">start ideating your YouTube channel</a>&nbsp;today.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Free Templates: How to Use YouTube for Business [Download Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<h2>YouTube Channel Ideas</h2> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#comedy-sketches\">Comedy Sketches</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#web-series\">Web Series</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#music\">Music</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#album-reviews\">Album Reviews</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#tutorials\">Tutorials</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#software-tutorials\">Software Tutorials</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#photography\">Photography</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#video-editing\">Video Editing</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#self-help\">Self Help</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#cleaning-and-org\">Cleaning and Organization</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#minimalism\">Minimalism</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#style\">Style</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#cooking\">Cooking</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#baking\">Baking</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#fitness-training\">Fitness Training</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#home-workouts\">Home Workouts</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#yoga\">Yoga</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#strength-training\">Strength Training</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#dance\">Dance</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#travel\">Travel</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#product-reviews\">Product Reviews</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#movie-reviews\">Movie Reviews</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#show-reviews\">Show Reviews</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#gaming\">Gaming</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#game-playthroughs\">Game Playthroughs</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#information-based-gaming\">Information Based Gaming</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-channel-ideas#channel-ideas-for-beginners\">Channel Ideas For Beginners</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>1. Comedy Sketches</h3> \n<p>When you’re in the midst of a two hour YouTube binge fest, you can probably blame the endless amount of funny videos that flood the platform. Some of the most successful YouTubers create comedy sketches, like<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/JennaMarbles\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/JennaMarbles\">Jenna Marbles</a>, a blogger turned YouTube sensation who has over 19 million subscribers, and<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/LifeAccordingToJimmy\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/LifeAccordingToJimmy\">Jimmy Tatro</a>, a college kid who made hilarious videos for fun, but ended up turning it into a career, amassing over 3 million subscribers to this day.</p> \n<p>Jenna and Jimmy both built their YouTube followings with low-production videos, but they completely nailed the humor and storytelling in most of their videos, too. With this in mind, if you can write a funny script, building a successful comedy channel with a low budget is definitely possible.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"famous YouTuber Jenna Marbles and boyfriend filming comedic video\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-33-59-PM.png?width=624&amp;name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-33-59-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"> <em><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KHCfr7qvkJs&amp;t=638s\" style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Source</a></span><a></a></em></img></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>2. Web Series</h3> \n<p>The human brain is wired to respond to well-crafted narrative.<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-strange-thing-that-happens-in-you-brain-when-you-hear-a-good-story-and-how-to-use-it-to-your-advantage\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/the-strange-thing-that-happens-in-you-brain-when-you-hear-a-good-story-and-how-to-use-it-to-your-advantage?_ga=2.19986552.1117465120.1616791718-1796479782.1616791718\">Neuroscience</a> proves that storytelling is the best way to capture people’s attention, bake information into their memories, and forge close, personal bonds. We’re programmed to crave and seek out great stories — that’ll never change.</p> \n<p>If you can structure your YouTube channel like a season of television and weave your videos into a narrative-driven series, then you can get viewers hooked on your content -- just like your favorite Netflix show.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>3. Music</h3> \n<p>Covers of songs are some of the most entertaining videos on YouTube. People love listening to aspiring artists’ personal twists on their favorite songs. So if you can sing or play instruments, consider covering your favorite, trending, or hit songs and upload them to YouTube. Who knows, maybe you could even get discovered and become the next<a href=\"https://www.teenvogue.com/story/best-artists-discovered-on-youtube\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.teenvogue.com/story/best-artists-discovered-on-youtube\">Justin Bieber or Tori Kelly</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>4. Album Reviews</h3> \n<p>This highly popular channel idea is full of endless possibilities as new music is made everyday. Famous YouTuber <a href=\"https://www.theneedledrop.com/articles?category=Reviews\">Anthony Fantano</a>&nbsp;has been consistently reviewing both prominent and underground albums over a wide range of music genres for the past decade and earned a cult following for sharing his opinions. While his videos have reached millions, they are relatively easy to record yourself. If you have an ear for music, you’d be surprised to find just how many people would like to hear what you have to say.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>5. Tutorials</h3> \n<p>Whether they’re guitar lessons, beauty lessons, or how-to videos about<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6v6RLUb2TQQ\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6v6RLUb2TQQ\">making popsicle stick houses for your hamster</a>, people love learning how to enjoy their lives more. If you can cover topics that people are passionate about and teach them how to get better at these things, they’ll be able to live better lives. This’ll grow your channel’s brand loyalty and sentiment, retaining your viewers’ attention and attracting their friends’ attention by way of word-of-mouth marketing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>6. Software Tutorials</h3> \n<p>You don’t have to be a software engineer to make software tutorials, but having a good grasp on how to use them can make for some good YouTube tutorials. Software can encompass subjects like application and system software, YouTube viewers could benefit from learning how to accurately put theirs to use, or how to install newer versions of it.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>8. Photography</h3> \n<p>Photography is considered an artform that takes many different forms. Photos can capture a landscape, family portraits, or more creative editorial content. YouTube is a great website to share tutorials on how to take the best photos for different purposes and equipment. Likewise, you don’t even need expensive cameras or software to create great photos as some photography videos teach people how to take great <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RRbnOWNDtlA\">iPhone photos.</a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"YouTuber filming photography tutorial for iPhone portraits\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-34-10-PM.png?width=624&amp;name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-34-10-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RRbnOWNDtlA\">Source</a></em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>8. Video Editing</h3> \n<p>There are dozens of editing software available to users, but many may be overlooked as videographers may not know how to use them to their full capability. If you know how to use Premiere Pro or other quality softwares, posting a tutorial could engage your viewers to experiment with their content in ways they haven’t thought of before.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>9. Self Help</h3> \n<p>Another way you can grow your channel’s brand loyalty and sentiment is by helping people solve their personal problems. Whether it’s about their career or personal life, you can give people advice about common issues that you’ve experienced or that they ask about. But make sure you have extensive knowledge, education, or personal experience surrounding these topics. Otherwise, people will think you’re a quack and lose trust in you.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>10. Cleaning and Organization</h3> \n<p>Usually marketed toward large family households, even single living people can enjoy the benefits of house cleaning tips and reorganization to make a home more attractive. Making videos tackling tough to clean messes or untidy clothing bins can motivate viewers to the the same.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>11. Minimalism</h3> \n<p>The world dealt while immense change last year, among those changes were increased time periods spent at home. The rise of decluttering and minimalism skyrocketed as people strived to make their houses more enjoyable, and filming your minimalist tips could help people in their own journeys. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/c/CoreyJones3/videos\">Corey Jones</a>&nbsp;shares minimalism tips from home decorating, wardrobe, and even down to the equipment he uses to film his content.<img alt=\"YouTuber filming minimalist home decor video\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-45-PM.png?width=624&amp;name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-45-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=80p_6rEEiVE&amp;t=182s\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>12. Style</h3> \n<p>Everyone wants to look good. And by evaluating new clothing, keeping people updated on new trends and styles, and teaching them how to always look their best, you can build a dedicated YouTube following. If your YouTube channel is popular, you can also attract sponsors who will pay you to review their clothing and offer deals to your audience.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>13. Cooking</h3> \n<p>Humans’ love for cooking is primal. I mean, we need food to survive, so it makes complete sense that people are always trying to master certain dishes and learn about new ones. To help them do this, guide them through your recipes, delve into the techniques you use, and show them what their food should look like at each stage of your recipe. This will help them make the best dish possible. When sharing your techniques, don’t be afraid to add a little humor into your cooking like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChBEbMKI1eCcejTtmI32UEw\">Joshua Weissman</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>14. Baking</h3> \n<p>Another part of YouTube that has significantly gained popularity are baking videos. As people scrambled to look for ways to use their freetime in 2020, many found ways to make baked goods a fun and enjoyable pastime. You don’t have to be a professional chef to share a recipe you’ve adapted, and chances are if it’s simple or quick, people will be more inclined to tune in because they can see themselves trying it out.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>15. Fitness Training</h3> \n<p>Personal trainers are expensive. Fortunately, though, you don’t need one to stay in shape. People are starting to resort to free personal trainers or yoga instructors on YouTube to stay active. So if you have a lot of expertise on weight lifting, yoga, or other fitness methods, consider creating workout videos for specific goals, like losing weight, gaining muscle, or improving cardiovascular health.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>16. Home Workouts</h3> \n<p>For many people, the idea of going into a gym may leave them feeling nervous because they don’t know how to use the equipment, or don’t know what a fitness routine includes. By making home workout videos, you make fitness more accessible and feasible for the everyday viewer.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>17. Yoga</h3> \n<p>Another form of fitness to explore is guided yoga videos. Yoga is a wonderful way to actively engage your body and mind, and sharing your expertise on how to properly do it will benefit viewers. By demonstrating how to do different versions of yoga like Ashtanga or Hatha, you’re helping people to calm and stay fit during their busy lives.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>18. Strength Training</h3> \n<p>Strength training videos are great for people of all backgrounds who are looking to build muscle and learn how to do it the right way. If you have a solid routine that others may want to learn and follow, sharing it on YouTube would be a good idea.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>19. Dance</h3> \n<p>Whether you're a professional dancer, or just somebody who likes to move, making dance videos to your favorite songs can make great entertainment. Choreographed numbers or freestyle moving to the latest charting hits can keep your content relevant and inspire others to dance along. Or get even more creative like the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/c/KukuwaFitness/featured\">Kukuwa Fitness </a>channel and embrace your cultural heritage, dancing to African beats.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"three Youtubers filming dance videos outdoors\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-91-PM.png?width=624&amp;name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-91-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shC59uCMCFg&amp;t=17s\">Source</a></em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>20. Travel</h3> \n<p>Humans are<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brain-triggers-copywriters-use-to-drive-sales\">&nbsp;</a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brain-triggers-copywriters-use-to-drive-sales\">biologically driven to investigate the world</a>&nbsp;rather than respond to it. That’s why people love exploring so much. But before they shell out thousands of dollars to travel someplace they saw on Instagram, people like to do a little research first. So if you have the funds to travel, consider recording your adventures in destination cityscapes or landscapes. Your viewers can actually get an inside look at the location, helping them decide to take a vacation they’ll never forget or save money on a trip they’d regret.</p> \n<h3>Reviews</h3> \n<p>The category of review videos is incredibly expansive. Review category videos can cover different forms of media, items and experiences of your choosing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>21. Product Reviews</h3> \n<p>With websites like Amazon selling millions of different products, a good way to help consumers pick the right products would be to create product reviews. YouTubers can demonstrate the functionality, versatility, and their overall satisfaction with any product they find. While most websites have sections for written reviews, many prefer watching and listening to a trustable consumer like themselves for advice on which product they should choose.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>22. Movie Reviews</h3> \n<p>If you just watched the latest action movie, or smaller indie film, you can take your thoughts straight to YouTube and be amongst the first to share your viewing experience with the world. Movie review videos give viewers the opportunity to see if it’s worth the money to buy a movie that’s been buzzing through social media through YouTubers they can trust.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>23. Show Reviews</h3> \n<p>Similar to movie reviews, with the prevalence of streaming services and their constant new series releases, reviewing seasons of highly favored television is a good route to go on YouTube.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>24. Gaming</h3> \n<p>Some people still think that video games are just for children, but the reality is that it's projected to become a <a href=\"https://techjury.net/blog/gaming-industry-worth/#gref\">$256.97 billion industry</a>&nbsp;by 2025.&nbsp;With fans of all ages, gender and backgrounds, it’s no wonder why YouTube is full of gaming related videos.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>25. Game Playthroughs</h3> \n<p>If you’re already an avid gamer, why not record your game playthroughs? Whether it’s a classic franchise or the newest storyboard, chances are that someone is on YouTube looking for a playthrough. These videos help gamers decide whether they should purchase a game themselves, get past a tough quest, or just enjoy it like any other web series. Don’t be intimidated by the most popular gamers, because smaller channels like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-R8ghoWcuny0CUB3hmm9XA\">Narcissa Wright</a>&nbsp;have a steady stream of subscribers tuning into her playthroughs weekly.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>26. Information Based Gaming</h3> \n<p>Much like those who enjoy watching playthroughs, there is a large audience of gamers who go to YouTube for gaming guides. People that find themselves stuck in a tough quest, or unsure how to reach achievement know they can go to YouTube for visual, instructional videos to help them beat the games they enjoy.</p> \n<p>If these channel ideas seem a bit intimidating, then don’t feel discouraged! For those who are just starting out and want to begin making simplistic and fun videos, then keeping reading.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>YouTube Channel Ideas for Beginners</h2> \n<h3>1. ‘Favorites’ Video</h3> \n<p>People that use YouTube on a daily basis are all consumers of some form. Beginning your channel with something as simple as showing off your favorite games, collectibles, or more could help viewers choose what they invest their money into. These videos are particularly good for small channels as there is more trust in the YouTuber honestly sharing versus making sponsored content for brands.</p> \n<h3>2. Trending News Discussion</h3> \n<p>long as there’s news in pop culture or world events, making a channel solely for news commentary can grow rather quickly if done consistently. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/c/DAngeloWallace/videos\">D’Angelo Wallace</a> became a famous YouTuber in under 3 years for sharing his interpretation of headlining news or culture happenings. If you have a camera and a good microphone, beginning a channel on trending news discussion could be a good start.</p> \n<h3>3. Reaction Videos</h3> \n<p>you’re watching the latest sporting program or the grand finale of a suspenseful television series, chances are you’re not the only viewer brimming with excitement. This video category is popular because viewers want to connect or feel like they're sharing the experience with someone else. So if you’re looking for an easy way to start a channel, look into filming your initial reaction to a media you enjoy.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"YouTuber filming reaction video to popular tv show\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-31-94-PM.png?width=624&amp;height=348&amp;name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-31-94-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"348\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-iC-f30K6YE\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h3>4. Food Reviews</h3> \n<p>Foodies have the opportunity to share all their favorite restaurant orders to a wide audience on YouTube. People are always on the lookout for the best food in town, and starting a channel with honest reviews of places worth visiting can both help you get views and help the businesses you love gain new customers.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=7e8681b3-9162-45a4-b6a1-f33ff244a78a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7e8681b3-9162-45a4-b6a1-f33ff244a78a.png\" /></a> </p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-channel-ideas&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 02 Apr 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485.png","linkMd5":"b81555b242a3bd230a648bcf895ea173","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn80@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-610_cf13f3171c1652e5.webp","destWidth":625,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":6230,"destBytes":9478,"author":"ttaylor@hubspot.com (Tristen Taylor)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn80@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-610_cf13f3171c1652e5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-33-59-PM.png?width=624&name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-33-59-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn94@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-337_2a8579c393e7a38b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-34-10-PM.png?width=624&name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-34-10-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn34@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-53-960_b0e378370c91518c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-45-PM.png?width=624&name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-45-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-59-886_70103a6e2695d233.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-91-PM.png?width=624&name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-32-91-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn64@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-51-402_c3986afeff1c5e31.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-31-94-PM.png?width=624&height=348&name=30%20YouTube%20Channel%20Ideas%20to%20Help%20You%20Choose%20Your%20Own-Mar-26-2021-08-52-31-94-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn78@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-57-439_878adb58147e5dbb.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7e8681b3-9162-45a4-b6a1-f33ff244a78a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn99@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-57-791_61f66f8328bd53cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-channel-ideas&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn75@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-51-403_936e6d54ac73a4f4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425369943},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"Deconstructing 7 Famous Brands' Color Palettes","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/color-palette-famous-websites","description":"<p>Pablo Picasso once said, \"Why do two colors, put one next to the other, sing? Can one really explain this? No. Just as one can never learn how to paint.\"</p> \n<p>Ladies and gentlemen, Picasso was wrong.</p> \n<p>You actually&nbsp;<em>can</em>&nbsp;figure out why “two colors, put one next to the other, sing.”<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=a6b4ed0b-1a8e-4f76-9a8b-7416dc0d7f26&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Download 195+ visual marketing design templates to use for social media posts,  infographics, and more.&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/a6b4ed0b-1a8e-4f76-9a8b-7416dc0d7f26.png\"></a> Or, more accurately, you can figure out why some color combinations work (i.e., look good) and why other color combinations don’t work (i.e., look terrible).&nbsp;</p> \n<p>I realize that Picasso probably meant “one can never learn how to paint” in a less literal, more philosophical way. As in, you can’t teach someone to have a sense of style or how to develop artistic sensibilities; that there is some innate, incomprehensible trait that some people have and some people don’t.</p> \n<p>It would seem, according to Picasso’s quote, that being able to determine what colors look good next to each other is a talent you’re born with, and not something you can learn.</p> \n<p>Again, I would disagree.</p> \n<p>From a scientific standpoint, it’s certainly plausible that some people are genetically predisposed to being good at art and design. But I’d argue that the \"10,000 hours theory” makes that notion irrelevant.&nbsp;For those unfamiliar with <a href=\"http://www.wisdomgroup.com/blog/10000-hours-of-practice/\">the 10,000&nbsp;hours theory</a>, it states that anyone can become a master of a particular skill provided that they practice that skill for, approximately, 10,000&nbsp;hours during their lifetime.</p> \n<p>So, while Picasso may have been born with some level of predisposition toward being good at painting, the primary reason why he was so good is quite simple: he painted a lot.&nbsp;And if you practice a lot, you can get better at picking the right color palettes, too.</p> \n<h2>Practice Makes a Perfect Palette</h2> \n<p>Now that we’ve thoroughly ripped apart a quote from one of history’s most famous artists, let’s get practicing!</p> \n<p>In the rest of this article, I’ll walk you through seven, real-word examples of color palettes on the web.&nbsp;For each example, we’ll see if you can guess which company or brand the color palette comes from. Then, we’ll dive into the color theory behind what makes a particular color palette work (or not work, if that happens to be the case).</p> \n<p>Note: <strong>Be sure to scroll down nice and slow so you have a chance to guess before revealing the answer!</strong></p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#1: Understanding Different Color Models</h3> \n<p>Alright, here we go: Which website does the color scheme below come from?</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2258431695-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example1.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example1.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example1\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2258431690-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/google-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=google-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"google-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Of course, that blue, green, yellow, and red color palette belongs to none other than the great Google.</p> \n<p>Even without having any previous education around color theory, there are some basic lessons we can take away from this palette on how different color models work.</p> \n<p>For starters, you may have noticed that the&nbsp;red, blue, and yellow&nbsp;in Google's palette are primary colors -- colors you can mix together to form all of the other colors. So, to create green -- the only secondary color in Google’s color palette -- one simply needs to mix blue and yellow together.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2257250656-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/CMYK_color_model.png?width=250&amp;name=CMYK_color_model.png\" alt=\"CMYK_color_model\" width=\"250\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 10px 20px; float: right;\">Now, if we were mixing blue and yellow paint, that idea of \"mixing\" would hold true. But that’s because the world of painting (and printing) adheres to the CMYK — cyan (blue-ish),&nbsp;magenta (reddish), yellow, and key (black) — color model. Essentially, this color model is comprised of the three primary colors plus black, the latter of which is used for creating darker versions of colors.</p> \n<p>Here’s where things can get a little confusing: CMYK is a subtractive color model, which means colors are created through absorbing, or subtracting, particular wavelengths of visible light. The wavelengths of light that don’t get absorbed are reflected, and that reflected light ends up being the color we see.</p> \n<p>So, using this model, you could argue that a green object isn’t really green at all: it’s simply an object that’s reflecting the wavelength for green and absorbing the wavelengths for all the other colors.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259292717-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/rgb_color_model.png?width=150&amp;name=rgb_color_model.png\" alt=\"rgb_color_model\" width=\"150\" style=\"margin: 0px 20px 10px 0px; float: left;\">With me so far? Great! Because the colors you saw in the above example weren’t created using the CMYK color model: they were created using the RGB (red, green, blue) color model, which is the model that computers, televisions, and other electronic devices use.&nbsp;Unlike CMYK, RGB is an&nbsp;additive model. Red, green, and blue light waves are added together in particular combinations in order to produce colors.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2255102263-jpg/00-Blog_Thinkstock_Images/color_blocks.jpg?width=250&amp;name=color_blocks.jpg\" alt=\"color_blocks\" width=\"250\" style=\"float: right; margin: 10px 0px 10px 20px;\"></p> \n<p>So while the green in Google's color palette is a secondary color in the CMYK system, it’s actually a primary color in the RGB system. And overall, Google’s color scheme does feel very primary; or basic. Like preschool or kindergarten. (I always think of those wood blocks with the letters painted on them when I see Google’s colors.)</p> \n<p>Alright, that’s enough with the CMKY / RGB stuff -- it's just to give you a reference point for later on in the post.&nbsp;Let's move on to the next example.</p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#2: Hue, Shade, Tint, Tone &amp; Saturation</h3> \n<p>What company's website does the color palette below belong to?&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259317752-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example2.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example2.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example2\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2257265871-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/twitter-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=twitter-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"twitter-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Twitter’s color palette provides us with a superb example of a monochromatic color scheme. Instead of thinking of the gray, dark blue, and light blue in Twitter’s palette as separate colors, think of them as different flavors of the same color. Or more accurately, different flavors of the same hue.</p> \n<p>Let’s run&nbsp;through some terminology real quick&nbsp;and this&nbsp;will all start to make a lot more sense:</p> \n<p><strong>Hue:</strong> What we usually mean when we talk about color. The hue is the&nbsp;overarching, discerning quality of a color (e.g. “red” or&nbsp;“blue”).</p> \n<p><strong>Shade:</strong> What you get when you add black to a&nbsp;particular&nbsp;hue (e.g. dark blue is a shade of blue).</p> \n<p><strong>Tint:</strong> What you get when you add white to a&nbsp;particular&nbsp;hue (e.g. light blue is a tint of blue).</p> \n<p><strong>Tone:</strong> What you get when you add both black and white&nbsp;— a.k.a.&nbsp;gray&nbsp;— to a particular hue (e.g. pastel blue is a tone of blue).</p> \n<p><strong>Saturation:</strong> While&nbsp;“tone”&nbsp;is a popular painting term, in the world of graphic design you’ll be more likely to encounter the term&nbsp;“saturation” when dealing with adding gray to color.&nbsp;More specifically, saturation defines a range of color starting with gray (0% saturation) and ending with a pure, gray-less form of the color (100% saturation).&nbsp;Desaturated colors are softer, and&nbsp;potentially&nbsp;duller in comparison to their highly saturated&nbsp;counterparts, which are more vivid.</p> \n<p>Now, back to Twitter: Let’s use the blue from the logo, the lighter blue, as our reference point. That’s our hue. That’s&nbsp;“Twitter blue.”&nbsp;The darker blue is simply a shade of that Twitter blue, yet it has a higher saturation, making it a bit more vivid&nbsp;and eye-catching (which makes a whole lot of sense considering Twitter is using that blue to draw attention to their&nbsp;primary&nbsp;CTA:&nbsp;“Tweet”).</p> \n<p>The gray used for the icons is also a shade of the Twitter blue, but it has a&nbsp;considerably&nbsp;lower saturation&nbsp;(around 20%).</p> \n<p>All said and done, we can&nbsp;describe Twitter’s color scheme as being monochromatic. The colors all look good&nbsp;next to each other because they all have the same root color in them: it’s just the shading, tinting, and&nbsp;saturation levels that make them different.</p> \n<p>This is in stark contrast to Google’s polychromatic color scheme, where there are four&nbsp;distinct hues and no root color&nbsp;binding them all together. So, why do Google’s colors still seem to mesh and look good next to each other? A key reason is because they all have similarly high saturation levels.</p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#3: Determining a Color Scheme</h3> \n<p>Aright, on to our next example. Whose website does this color palette come from?</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259327907-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example3.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example3.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example3\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span></p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2258552110-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/ups-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=ups-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"ups-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>This one was a bit trickier. While most of us are familiar with UPS’s famous (and trademarked) brown, that blue&nbsp;may -- at first glance -- seem to come out of left field.&nbsp;But regardless of whether or not you <em>like</em> that blue color, there's a clear reason why UPS chose it: It's complementary to the brown.</p> \n<p>In the world of color theory, complementary colors are pairs of colors that sit directly across from each other on the color wheel. When you put complementary colors next to each other in a design, they create a high degree of contrast (i.e., both colors really stick out) and the result is usually quite harmonious.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259205824-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-wheel-complementary-colors.png?width=200&amp;name=color-wheel-complementary-colors.png\" alt=\"color-wheel-complementary-colors\" width=\"200\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px; float: right;\">Now, there's one more piece to this UPS complementary color&nbsp;puzzle: Where the heck do you find brown on the color wheel?</p> \n<p>The answer: brown is actually just a shade -- or darker version -- of reddish-orange. So&nbsp;to find brown's complement, you first need to find reddish-orange on the color wheel. And when you do that, you'll see that blue appears right across from it.</p> \n<p>Of course, complementary colors aren't the only combination of colors&nbsp;that can make for a pleasing palette. There are also ...</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Analogous colors</strong>, which are colors that appear next to each other on the color wheel.</li> \n <li><strong>Triadic colors</strong>, which are three colors that are evenly spaced around the color wheel.</li> \n <li><strong>Split-complementary colors</strong>, which consist of a base color plus the two colors that are adjacent to the base color's complement on the color wheel.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Here's a little diagram to help you understand these better:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2257994091-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/split-complementary-analogous-triadic.png?width=761&amp;name=split-complementary-analogous-triadic.png\" alt=\"split-complementary-analogous-triadic\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Now,&nbsp;truth be told, there are several other types of color combinations that are based on the color wheel -- these are just the most basic. (If you're looking for a deeper dive, check out&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.tigercolor.com/color-lab/color-theory/color-harmonies.htm\">the&nbsp;Tiger Color website</a>.)</p> \n<p>The main takeaway here is that the observable qualities of colors (e.g., hue, shade, tint, etc.) aren't the only factors that affect how colors interact. By understanding how different colors are oriented on the color wheel, you'll&nbsp;be able to make more harmonious&nbsp;color choices.</p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#4: Color&nbsp;and Branding</h3> \n<p><span>Which company's&nbsp;</span><span>website does the color palette below come from?</span></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2258713446-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example5.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example5.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example5\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span></p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259864520-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/fedex-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=fedex-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"fedex-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Whereas UPS added a new color (blue) to its typical brown and yellow color palette when designing their website, rival FedEx did the opposite: FedEx removed the&nbsp;orange that we usually&nbsp;see on their trucks&nbsp;and instead doubled down on the purple.</p> \n<p>As a result, UPS's and FedEx's website color palettes couldn't be more different. While UPS has this whole earth-tone vibe going on, using colors that could appear in nature, FedEx has more of a \"strictly business\" vibe. Their monochromatic scheme uses purple as the sole&nbsp;accent color, which also adds to this palette's inorganic, corporate feel, as the color purple rarely occurs in nature (some folks even claim that <a href=\"http://deron.meranda.us/ruminations/purple/\">purple is an artificial color</a>).</p> \n<p>The takeaway here: Remember that your website's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-does-your-logo-color-really-mean-infographic\">color palette can affect how people perceive you and your business</a>. Different colors correlate to different emotions. Brown, for example, is commonly associated with ruggedness and dependability. Purple, meanwhile, is associated with authority and&nbsp;sophistication.</p> \n<p>We'll explore&nbsp;the relationship between color and psychology a bit further in the examples to follow.</p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#5: Pairing Complementary Colors</h3> \n<p><span>Which popular</span><span>&nbsp;news website does the color palette below come from?</span></p> \n<p><span><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2256263778-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example6.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example6.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example6\" width=\"761\"></span></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span></p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2260691782-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/huffpo-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=huffpo-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"huffpo-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>Ah yes, HuffPost green. From a psychological perspective, the color green is associated with balance, harmony, and reassurance (making it a good choice for a news website, no doubt).&nbsp;</p> \n<p>However, HuffPost's green is notably dark and desaturated -- like a pine green -- which&nbsp;means it's also associated with wealth and ambition.</p> \n<p>Now, how about that red? Red is the most emotionally charged color, tied to passion and love and hate and all that good stuff. So, when we look at HuffPost's homepage, it's not surprising that our eyes are immediately drawn to those two red call-outs: the \"Watch Live\" call-out on the left and the \"HuffPost Live\" call-out on the right.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Another reason why the red really pops in this situation? It's complementary to the green.</p> \n<p>Interestingly, it's a general rule in design that you should avoid pairing red with green, despite their complementary relationship on the color wheel. For starters, this is because seeing red adjacent to green creates a Christmasy feel that most designers try to avoid. Unless, ya know, they're designing Christmas stuff.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259810518-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/red-and-green-bad.png?width=250&amp;name=red-and-green-bad.png\" alt=\"red-and-green-bad\" width=\"250\" style=\"margin: 0px 20px 0px 0px; float: left;\">A second reason why you should avoid pairing red with green: People suffering from color blindness -- specifically&nbsp;<span>deuteranopia, which is the most common form of color blindness&nbsp;--</span>&nbsp;can have trouble distinguishing between the two colors.</p> \n<p>A third reason: Red and green often \"compete\" with each other for visual attention when they're paired together,&nbsp;which results in both colors appearing brighter than usual (see left).</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2263688819-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/red-and-green-huffpost.png?width=250&amp;name=red-and-green-huffpost.png\" alt=\"red-and-green-huffpost\" width=\"250\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 0px 20px; float: right;\">The designers behind HuffPost's color palette were certainly aware of these phenomena, which is why A) they use the red very sparingly in the design, and B) they chose a dark, desaturated green, which plays nicer with the red (see right).&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Example&nbsp;#6: Deep Saturation and Primary Colors</h3> \n<p><span>Which popular&nbsp;website does the color palette below come from?</span></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2255861923-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example4.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example4.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example4\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span></p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259537725-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/buzzfeed-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=buzzfeed-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"buzzfeed-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>The first few words&nbsp;that come to mind when looking at BuzzFeed's color palette include \"bright,\" \"vivid,\" \"in-your-face,\" and \"stop-what-you're-doing-right-now-and-read-this-OMG-OMG-OMG!!!\"</p> \n<p>Clearly, BuzzFeed's goal with this color palette&nbsp;is to attract our attention.&nbsp;But in terms of color theory, what's going on here?</p> \n<p>For starters, BuzzFeed -- like Google -- uses primary colors: red, yellow, and blue. But BuzzFeed's red, yellow, blue are brighter and more deeply saturated, and thus more&nbsp;eye-catching.</p> \n<p>Also, if we ignore that black (<a href=\"http://www.colormatters.com/color-and-design/are-black-and-white-colors\">which isn't really a color, per se,</a> but is rather what&nbsp;results from the total absence -- or total absorption -- of visible light waves), we could say that BuzzFeed uses a triadic color scheme, as red, yellow, and blue are spaced out evenly around the color wheel.</p> \n<p><span>In terms of color psychology,&nbsp;red (as I mentioned in the previous example) is the most emotionally charged color around, so it's not surprising&nbsp;that BuzzFeed employs it in their logo: They want you to feel&nbsp;energized and excited.</span></p> \n<p><span><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2263749409-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/smiley-faces.jpg?width=333&amp;name=smiley-faces.jpg\" alt=\"smiley-faces\" width=\"333\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0px 20px 0px 0px;\">Yellow, another prominent color in BuzzFeed's palette, is associated with both energy and happiness. And speaking of happiness&nbsp;... doesn't that row of yellow circles with the black text at the top of BuzzFeed's homepage&nbsp;remind you of a row of smiley faces?</span></p> \n<p><span>The blue in BuzzFeed's color palette is reserved exclusively for links and call-to-action buttons, which is a smart move. Blue, you see, is associated with calmness and trustworthiness. So, amidst&nbsp;all the emotional chaos of BuzzFeed's red and yellow, the blue links feel inviting, as if to say, \"Don't worry, we know it's crazy here, but you can trust us! Go ahead, give us a click!\"</span>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Lesson&nbsp;#7: Desaturated Palettes</h3> \n<p><span>Alright, it's time for our final example: Which popular</span><span>&nbsp;website does the color palette below come from?</span></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259849400-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example7.jpg?width=761&amp;name=color-scheme-example7.jpg\" alt=\"color-scheme-example7\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p><span>Scroll down to see if you’re right!</span></p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p>.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2260671557-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/facebook-color-palette.jpg?width=761&amp;name=facebook-color-palette.jpg\" alt=\"facebook-color-palette\" width=\"761\"></p> \n<p>If you had trouble figuring out that the above palette was from Facebook, don't feel bad: I deliberately made it a little tricky by including the red and the yellow.</p> \n<p>Truth be told, if you scroll around Facebook, you'll see that they employ a variety of colors, especially when it comes to sidebar icons. (For our purposes, I focused specifically on the icons near the top of the page in order to extract the yellow and the red.)</p> \n<p>Now, this is where my master plan comes together: Take a look at the&nbsp;Facebook color palette, then scroll back up to BuzzFeed's. Both sites employ&nbsp;yellow, red, and blue in their colors schemes ... yet the schemes couldn't feel more different!</p> \n<p>By now, you're probably able to explain why this is. But let's run through it together just for funsies.</p> \n<p>For starters, Facebook employs a few different shades of its iconic blue (just like Twitter does). It's an easy way to add some contrast to a design without veering off into an entirely different stylistic direction.</p> \n<p>However, the main culprit here is saturation: Facebook's yellow, red, and blue are all&nbsp;desaturated to a similar degree. And as a result, they all feel calm and relaxed. Whereas seeing BuzzFeed's color palette feels like taking a shot of&nbsp;espresso, seeing Facebook's palette feels like getting wrapped up in a&nbsp;cozy blanket.</p> \n<p>Of&nbsp;course, the way the two sites employ their colors is very different. With BuzzFeed, blue -- a color that instills trust and calmness -- only appears on links. With Facebook,&nbsp;there's a&nbsp;fixed&nbsp;blue bar running right across the top of the site, so those feelings of trust and calmness are ever-present.</p> \n<p>All said and done,&nbsp;Facebook's muted, blue-centric color palette makes us want to kick off our shoes and relax&nbsp;a while. And considering <a href=\"http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-07-23/heres-how-much-time-people-spend-on-facebook-daily\">the average American spends about 40 minutes each day checking Facebook</a>, those color choices seems to be working out.</p> \n<p><em>Have some color theory wisdom you'd like to share? Sound off in the comments section below!</em></p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=30da96db-0967-4f26-b865-5aa4728dfe4f&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"download 195+ free design templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/30da96db-0967-4f26-b865-5aa4728dfe4f.png\"></a> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n <a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=cec53a7e-e1d3-48c0-85d3-6770a8933472&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/cec53a7e-e1d3-48c0-85d3-6770a8933472.png\"></a>\n</div>  \n<img
