.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259810518-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/red-and-green-bad.png?width=250&name=red-and-green-bad.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-51-970_c24a30b60ff5ee8a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2263688819-png/00-Blog-Related_Images/red-and-green-huffpost.png?width=250&name=red-and-green-huffpost.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn28@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-17-767_8c5e3703d7da97d4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2255861923-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example4.jpg?width=761&name=color-scheme-example4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-55-494_760387edd8f77d2b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259537725-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/buzzfeed-color-palette.jpg?width=761&name=buzzfeed-color-palette.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn26@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-54-732_e6c3f670bc42a582.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2263749409-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/smiley-faces.jpg?width=333&name=smiley-faces.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn30@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-01-794_f39da42a82a68d3c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2259849400-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/color-scheme-example7.jpg?width=761&name=color-scheme-example7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn25@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-57-075_35933b9a607d18a6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-2260671557-jpg/00-Blog-Related_Images/facebook-color-palette.jpg?width=761&name=facebook-color-palette.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn25@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-52-047_53cc128468736d3a.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/30da96db-0967-4f26-b865-5aa4728dfe4f.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn64@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-56-140_59c208bd44cc3f7b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/cec53a7e-e1d3-48c0-85d3-6770a8933472.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn73@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-50-01-236_168fbf5d4a51255f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcolor-palette-famous-websites&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn27@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-00-304_8a93b552a82805ee.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370035},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How to Identify Your Core Marketing Message","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-message","description":"<p>As a marketer, you know how important it is to have a marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>You also know how important it is for your strategy to align with your audiences’ needs and interests, and the required approach for each channel you use, whether it’s <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media?_ga=2.73689810.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">social media</a>&nbsp;or <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/email-marketing?library=true\">email</a>. Having a marketing strategy also helps you create the content your audiences want to see and share it where they’re most likely to see it.</p> \n<p>But, when you have this strategy, how do you figure out what to say in the content you share with them? What you need is a marketing message, and it’s just as important as your overall strategy.</p> \n<p>You can think of it like this: if you know you want to post about a new product launch on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-for-business-guide?_ga=2.27018109.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">Instagram</a>, how will you prove to your audience that they need to buy this new product? Your marketing message. Essentially, no marketing message means no way to execute your strategy.</p> \n<p>In this post, we’ll define what a marketing message is, give real-life examples from businesses, and explain how you can create your own.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Brand Building Guide\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Because of this, you should craft your marketing message with care, specifically for the audiences you’re trying to reach. It should also address their pain points and present your business as a solution.</p> \n<p>When your message speaks to their needs, you’ll build trust with your audience and inspire <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-retention?_ga=2.32901118.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">customer retention</a>.</p> \n<p>Every business engaging in marketing needs a marketing message, whether you sell B2C or B2B, software as a service (SaaS), or clothing.</p> \n<h3>Marketing Message Examples</h3> \n<p>Successful marketing messages attract leads and convert them to paying customers. Below we’ll go over some real-life examples of effective marketing messages.</p> \n<h4>Nike</h4> \n<p>As a clothing and apparel brand, <a href=\"http://nike.com\">Nike</a>&nbsp;is committed to providing equipment to everyone who needs it, regardless of the sport they play and who they are.</p> \n<p>Their marketing message is “Where All Athletes Belong,” and it speaks to their target audience and lets them know that they have something for everyone —from professional athletes to first-time players.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/nike-message.jpg?width=536&amp;name=nike-message.jpg\" alt=\"nike homepage 'where all athletes belong' marketing message\" width=\"536\" style=\"width: 536px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h4 style=\"color: #666666; font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/content/42081960859?_preview=true&amp;benderPackage=InpageEditorUI&amp;cacheBust=1614376215557&amp;cssPath=bundles%2Fapp.css&amp;inpageEditorUI=true&amp;localAssets=false&amp;portalId=53&amp;preview_key=oAbekNQD&amp;scriptPath=bundles%2Fapp.js&amp;staticVersion=static-1.27380&amp;injectedScripts=hubspot-dlb%2Cbundle.production.js%2Cfalse%2Cstatic-1.129#h.qubwej2bmin2\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></h4> \n<h4>Black Girl Sunscreen</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.blackgirlsunscreen.com/\">Black Girl Sunscreen</a>&nbsp;targets an audience often left out of sun safety discussions: women of color. Their message lets that market know they’re there for them: “Protect your melanin. Sunscreen is always in season.”</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/black%20girl%20sunscreen.jpg?width=555&amp;name=black%20girl%20sunscreen.jpg\" alt=\"black girl sunscreen homepage marketing message &quot;protect your melanin. sunscreen is always in season.&quot;\" width=\"555\" style=\"width: 555px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/content/42081960859?_preview=true&amp;benderPackage=InpageEditorUI&amp;cacheBust=1614376215557&amp;cssPath=bundles%2Fapp.css&amp;inpageEditorUI=true&amp;localAssets=false&amp;portalId=53&amp;preview_key=oAbekNQD&amp;scriptPath=bundles%2Fapp.js&amp;staticVersion=static-1.27380&amp;injectedScripts=hubspot-dlb%2Cbundle.production.js%2Cfalse%2Cstatic-1.129#h.rxibzmk2h06\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h4>Chipotle</h4> \n<p>People with dietary restrictions or food preferences that don’t align with mainstream ideas of nutrition are often unable to find food they can eat at fast-food restaurants.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://chipotle.com\">Chipotle’s</a>&nbsp;marketing message, shown in the image below, reads “Find your plant power.” The brand is speaking directly to those with diverse needs, inviting them to try their expanded menu with plant-based options and letting them know that they recognize the gap in the market for their needs.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chipotle.jpg?width=574&amp;name=chipotle.jpg\" alt=\"chipotle plant-based marketing message &quot;find your plant power&quot;\" width=\"574\" style=\"width: 574px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.chipotle.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4>Lab Muffin</h4> \n<p>Ingredients in beauty and cosmetic products can be hard to understand if you don’t have a scientific background or relevant experience.<a href=\"https://labmuffin.com/\">&nbsp;Lab Muffin’s </a>marketing message speaks to those who want to understand the chemistry behind the products they use: “The science of beauty, explained simply.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lab%20muffin-message.jpg?width=565&amp;name=lab%20muffin-message.jpg\" alt=\"lab muffin logo with marketing message that reads &quot;the science of beauty, explained simply.&quot;\" width=\"565\" style=\"width: 565px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/content/42081960859?_preview=true&amp;benderPackage=InpageEditorUI&amp;cacheBust=1614376215557&amp;cssPath=bundles%2Fapp.css&amp;inpageEditorUI=true&amp;localAssets=false&amp;portalId=53&amp;preview_key=oAbekNQD&amp;scriptPath=bundles%2Fapp.js&amp;staticVersion=static-1.27380&amp;injectedScripts=hubspot-dlb%2Cbundle.production.js%2Cfalse%2Cstatic-1.129#h.1t7t897zh\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4>Zoom</h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://zoom.com\">Zoom</a>&nbsp;is a virtual meeting tool that allows users to connect virtually. It markets to an audience who wants to continue having fulfilling conversations, regardless of their physical location: “Meet OnZoom. A marketplace for immersive experiences.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/zoom-message.jpg?width=569&amp;name=zoom-message.jpg\" alt=\"zoom homepage slider marketing message that reads &quot;meet onzoom. a marketplace for immersive experiences.&quot;\" width=\"569\" style=\"width: 569px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.zoom.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>All in all, these marketing messages capture attention and, in just a couple of words, explain why their business is the best fit to meet their audience’s needs.</p> \n<h2>How to Craft a Marketing Message</h2> \n<p>As mentioned above, a well-crafted marketing message converts your audience into customers. All businesses should aim to have one, and below we’ll discuss how to create a compelling marketing message for your own business.</p> \n<h3>Know your target audience.</h3> \n<p>Just as with most marketing practices, you can’t begin creating your marketing message without identifying your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/target-audience?_ga=2.94793692.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">target audience</a>. When you know who they are, you’re not marketing to customers you think are interested in you, but rather to those you know are interested in you.</p> \n<p>In brief, your target audience is a group of consumers with similar characteristics and purchasing intent, and stand to gain the most value from your products. While your overall target audience is probably defined by the industry you’re in, it’s important to have a deeper understanding.</p> \n<p>To learn more about your target audience and narrow down who they are, you can conduct <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">buyer persona research</a>, analyze your competitors, practice <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-listening\">social listening</a>, and invite people to participate in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-focus-group\">focus groups</a>&nbsp;or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-interviews?_ga=2.94793692.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">interviews</a>.</p> \n<p>Overall, what you want to learn from identifying your target audience is understanding what they “look” like. This can be simple demographic information, like age and location, to what they like, desire, and want from the businesses they buy from.</p> \n<p>Having this information then makes it easier to personalize your strategies and create a marketing message that will resonate with them, especially when addressing their pain points.</p> \n<h3>Understand your audience’s pain points.</h3> \n<p>Your persona research should tell you about your audience’s pain points and challenges.</p> \n<p>As a refresher, pain points are issues that affect your target audience’s day-to-day routines, business tasks, or general life desires. These challenges are typically things that your audience is actively seeking solutions for.</p> \n<p>For example, if you’re a business selling marketing SaaS, you may discover that your audience has trouble managing their campaigns because they use multiple platforms throughout their process. When you create your marketing message, you should speak to your ability to streamline their efforts with your easy-to-use, all-in-one platform.</p> \n<p>If you’re a B2C business that sells eco-friendly clothing, a customer pain point could be that they struggle to find brands without significant environmental impact. In your marketing message, you should speak to their desire to minimize environmental pollution through sustainable shopping opportunities.</p> \n<p>When you understand pain points, you don’t have to guess why your customers need you — you’ll know why they need you. As a result, you can create a marketing message that addresses their needs.</p> \n<p>The first two steps on this list involve gathering the necessary background information, and the following steps will help you begin crafting your message.</p> \n<h3>Make value propositions.</h3> \n<p>Value propositions highlight your product or service’s unique value and tell customers that your brand is tailor-made to meet their needs. It clearly says why they should do business with you instead of a competitor, and that is precisely the point of a marketing message.</p> \n<p>When creating your message, present your product or service as a cure for their pain points, and prove it. Continuing with the eco-friendly business example, you can specifically mention that your clothing is locally produced, separating you from the competition that mass produces its goods abroad.</p> \n<p>This message tells consumers that you’re solving their pain point, which is a lack of sustainable clothing brands, because you design ethically produced and environmentally friendly products.</p> \n<h3>Prioritize clarity and concision.</h3> \n<p>Even though your marketing message needs to say a lot, you need to say a lot while saying a little. You shouldn’t beat around the bush. Instead, get to the point and explain how your product is a solution.</p> \n<p>Customers should read your message and find answers to their questions without needing to overanalyze your statements. Prioritize being clear, concise, and easily understood, as you want your words to speak for themselves. To reiterate, get to the point.</p> \n<p>You can think of it like this: I said a lot in this explanation just to tell you to get to the point. If this were a marketing message, you would’ve moved along already. However, if I wanted to follow the tips I’ve mentioned, I would simply say, “Tell me why you’re the best – no ifs, ands, or buts.”</p> \n<h3>Use familiar, conversational language.</h3> \n<p>Even though your customers are in your industry, you shouldn’t assume that they know or understand the technical jargon related to what you sell. Therefore, it’s important to sound conversational and use language that is familiar and palatable to most audiences. Your message copy should be simple, straightforward, and not require an industry-specific dictionary.</p> \n<p>For example, you can use technical terms to describe the features in your latest automobile model. Still, car enthusiasts would be the only ones that genuinely understand what it means to have a 600 horsepower engine and AAA uniform tire quality grading (I certainly don’t know what this means). &nbsp;</p> \n<p>Aim to write as people speak during conversations, maintain a friendly tone, and make customers feel welcomed. Robotic and technical language may be confusing and lead them to think that doing business with you will be complicated and confusing as well.</p> \n<p>In sum, by being conversational and familiar, you’re reaching everyone, from first-time industry customers to seasoned CEOs.</p> \n<h3>Showcase your brand's originality. &nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Your marketing message’s overall intent is to attract your target audience, but it’s also to set you apart from your competitors. Given this, a key pillar of your final message is originality.</p> \n<p>Run-of-the-mill marketing messages seem like they could belong to any of your competitors, and original ones showcase what makes you unique. This can be your brand's personality, the features that set you apart from your competitors, or a combination of the two.</p> \n<p>Your marketing message is unique to your business, your solutions are unique to your business, and your words should prove that.</p> \n<h3>Use user-generated content (UGC).</h3> \n<p>Consumers are 14% more likely to trust recommendations from <a href=\"https://www.edelman.com/sites/g/files/aatuss191/files/2020-06/2020%20Edelman%20Trust%20Barometer%20Specl%20Rept%20Brand%20Trust%20in%202020.pdf\">someone like them</a>&nbsp;(another consumer) over a brand employee. With that in mind ,using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/user-generated-content-stats\">UGC</a>&nbsp;in your messaging, like testimonials and reviews, can help you support your products’ value.</p> \n<p>As your target audience likely shares the same challenges, seeing that someone like them has benefited from your product can help them make their final decision. For example, you could say, “95% of our customers love [xyz], and you will too.”</p> \n<h3>Appeal to customer emotions and logic.</h3> \n<p>There are a variety of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/consumer-behavior-model?_ga=2.94793692.1944277943.1614376295-1637944583.1614376295\">consumer behavior models</a>&nbsp;that explain how people make purchasing decisions. Some models say that it’s through logical reasoning, and others say that it’s purely emotional. In reality, it’s probably a combination of the two, and you should use this to your advantage.</p> \n<p>Through tactics like humorous copy, you can showcase your brand's uniqueness to appeal to customer emotions, and use value propositions to appeal to logical reasoning and show customers how you’ll solve their problems.</p> \n<h2>Use Your Marketing Message to Speak to Your Customers</h2> \n<p>The key takeaway here is that your marketing message should convince your audience to do business with you.</p> \n<p>Focus on showcasing your brands’ individuality, creating an emotional connection, and clearly showing your customers what’s in it for them. If you do this, you’ll likely find yourself with a marketing message that speaks directly to your target audience and helps you grow your list of clients.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ddbf2eb7-04e8-44b2-9e05-b21264e09b65&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddbf2eb7-04e8-44b2-9e05-b21264e09b65.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-message&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 17 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1.png","linkMd5":"1ebc0cf1d0ab0e19203e25445f55eb9b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn10@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-30-610_eac7fa40866dc905.webp","destWidth":382,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4555,"destBytes":6088,"author":"fneedle@hubspot.com (Flori Needle)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/814dd420-0d49-40e0-b59c-f01066e186c1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn10@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-30-610_eac7fa40866dc905.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/nike-message.jpg?width=536&name=nike-message.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn56@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-50-00-819_ad8da0d0e76e79dc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/black%20girl%20sunscreen.jpg?width=555&name=black%20girl%20sunscreen.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn30@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-51-330_2a295f621ba6b738.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chipotle.jpg?width=574&name=chipotle.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-51-306_518178afc591fee1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lab%20muffin-message.jpg?width=565&name=lab%20muffin-message.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn34@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-01-891_22141b351ce6ab21.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/zoom-message.jpg?width=569&name=zoom-message.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn74@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-55-265_ac5246ef56d9eae0.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddbf2eb7-04e8-44b2-9e05-b21264e09b65.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn22@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-52-647_f4156d3bc1379fd0.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-message&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn4@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-51-443_3e142d7383c708ef.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370113},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"A Marketer's Short & Sweet Guide on Diversification","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/diversification-marketing","description":"<p>To consider the potential payoff of product diversification, let's start with an example.</p> \n<p>Lululemon, an athletic apparel company, was founded in <a href=\"https://info.lululemon.com/about/our-story/history\">1998 with one core product</a><span>: yoga clothing for women. </span></p> \n<p>If you've been to a store recently, you've likely seen how far beyond women's yoga-clothing Lululemon has grown.</p> \n<p>For instance, my brother now buys <em><span>all</span></em><span>&nbsp;his button-down shirts and work pants from Lululemon.</span></p> \n<p>Additionally, last week I bought a bathing suit from the shop.</p> \n<p>On their Our Story page, Lululemon states: \"Our first designs were made for women to wear during yoga. Through plenty of feedback from our guests, ambassadors and elite athletes, we now design for yoga, running, cycling, training and most other sweaty pursuits for women and men.\"</p> \n<p>This is an example of effective diversification in-action. Here, we'll explore what diversification marketing is, and how it pertains to your marketing strategy.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<p></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Why diversify your product offerings?</h2> \n<p>There are three reasons a business might choose to diversify its existing product line:</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li>You've reached the 'limit' on the amount of people you can convert in a market segment.</li> \n <li>You've identified a new product or service that complements the needs of your existing customers.</li> \n <li>You've decided a new level of growth can only be achieved through addressing new market segments.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Let's dive into the difference between the three of these reasons, now.</p> \n<p>First, perhaps you've reached the limit of the amount of people you can reach in a market segment. If you created a niche product or service, you might've spent the last few years marketing your product to your core audience demographic.</p> \n<p>Eventually, you'll reach your limit of potential people you can reach and convert within that audience segment.</p> \n<p>For instance, <a href=\"https://gopro.com/en/us/shop/cameras\">GoPro</a><span>&nbsp;started out selling HD cameras for sports and adventure. However, there are only so many people they can target with GoPro cameras — which is likely why they expanded to camera accessories, and even lifestyle gear, including backpacks and clothing. </span></p> \n<p>With an expanded product line, GoPro can now target audiences who are looking for outdoor gear, along with audiences who are searching for HD cameras.</p> \n<p>Second, perhaps you've identified a complementary product or service to the one you currently offer. To identify complementary products or services, consider what goal(s) your products help your customers achieve, and what other tools or services they need to achieve those goals even faster.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/\">Mailchimp</a><span>, as an example, started as an email marketing tool. Now, the company has diversified its product offerings and expanded into social media tools and even website builders. </span></p> \n<p>Mailchimp created an email marketing tool to help customers reach new audiences and convert those audiences faster. Social media tools and website builders, then, are natural extensions of that primary goal.</p> \n<p>Finally, a third reason you might diversify your product offerings is simply to reach and convert new segments of customers. This is less of a brand-new product or service, and more of a tier-method in which you have the same product with varying features depending on audience segment.</p> \n<p>An example of this is a software company that initially targeted small businesses, and is now expanding into the enterprise audience segment.</p> \n<p>To successfully expand, you'll need to ensure your new product features accurately address enterprise users' needs — which will be drastically different from your small business clients'.</p> \n<p>Another example is a sports shoe company that continues to create sports shoes, and doesn't diversify its products or services beyond sports shoes. However, the company does start creating different lines of sports shoes to address different audience segments: including tennis players, golfers, and joggers.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Advantages and Disadvantages to Product Diversification</h2> \n<p>There are a few major benefits to diversification, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Minimizing losses</strong>: Ever heard the term, \"Don't put all your eggs in one basket\"? That's the premise of this advantage. Basically, if one of your products underperforms, you'll be able to minimize company revenue loss if your other products are performing well or better than expected.</li> \n <li><strong>Increasing brand recognition</strong>: If Apple only sold computers, it probably wouldn't be the well-known brand it is today. But since the company has expanded into smartphones and music players, it's expanded the amount of customers who use an Apple product. As customers increase, so does brand recognition.</li> \n <li><strong>Increasing customer lifetime value</strong>: By expanding your offerings, you're increasing opportunities for customers to find value in your brand — which could increase brand loyalty. For instance, if Lululemon <em>just</em>&nbsp;offered yoga pants, I probably wouldn't be such a big fan. But since I can get workout clothes, work clothes, and even swimwear from them, my loyalty towards them is high.</li> \n</ul> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">If you create a tier-program in which you offer additional product features for varying phases of a business, you're minimizing the risk that your customers will outgrow you. </span></p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>However, there are also risks associated with diversification. A few major risks include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Brand dilution</strong>: People no longer associate your brand with the product or service you your were initially known for, and they're unsure how your new products relate to your business mission or values.</li> \n <li><strong>Resourcing limitations</strong>: You don't have the budget or headcount to effectively create new products or services, or your marketing team doesn't have the resources to properly target a new market audience.</li> \n <li><strong>&nbsp;Inconsistent support for additional products</strong>: If your support team isn't prepped to handle the new complaints or challenges prospects and customers are facing with your new product, the industry's overall satisfaction with your brand could decrease.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Marketing's Role in Diversification</h2> \n<p>If your company is diversifying its product portfolio, your marketing team plays a major role in the success of that expansion.</p> \n<p>Among other things, your marketing team is likely in charge of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide\">market research</a><span>&nbsp;(including your new segment's unique challenges and pain points), <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-marketing\">product development</a><span>&nbsp;(i.e. ensuring your product successfully meets your target audience's needs, especially as those needs evolve over time), and creating a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-launch-checklist\">successful product launch</a><span>.</span></span></span></p> \n<p>Ultimately, your marketing team needs to learn how to target your new market segment — which might be difficult if your brand hasn't targeted that audience in previous marketing campaigns. (To learn more about audience segmentation and targeting, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/segmentation-targeting-positioning\">The Marketer's Guide to Segmentation, Targeting, &amp; Positioning</a><span>.)</span></p> \n<p>And, just as importantly, your marketing team needs to mitigate some of the risks associated with diversification.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>For instance, marketers can minimize brand dilution by telling a comprehensive story to the public that outlines <em><span>why</span></em><span> these new products or services make sense to your business' vision, goals, or overall mission.</span></p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Lastly, when marketing your new products, services, or expanding into new market segments, consider how you might <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-strategy-guide\">diversify your marketing </a><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-strategy-guide\">strategy</a></em><span>&nbsp;to achieve growth with these new product offerings. </span></p> \n<p><span>A marketing strategy that worked well for one product won't necessarily work well for another — so it's critical, as a marketer, you remain flexible and open-minded to pivoting to properly address the needs of these new customers. </span></p> \n<p>When done properly, diversification is an incredibly exciting opportunity to fuel long-term growth ... Just consider the growth Lululemon has seen since making the courageous leap into apparel beyond women's yoga clothes.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdiversification-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 02 Apr 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"6b696b3fc2005772c14f667f230fb6ab","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn3@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-54-880_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdiversification-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn56@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-56-021_cfb46a45f1dd08f1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370091},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:29","title":"What is LinkedIn Live? [+How to Leverage It in Your Marketing Strategy]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-live","description":"<p>Every week, I use LinkedIn to talk about current events and connect with other content creators.</p> \n<p>And I'm not the only one. In fact, LinkedIn has nearly <a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/april/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy20-q3-earnings\">700 million active users</a> and has become one of the top social media platforms.</p>  \n<p>In the last year, companies have started to use the social network's new live-streaming technology.</p> \n<p>While <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/06/zuckerberg-put-employees-on-lockdown-to-launch-facebook-live-wsj.html#:~:text=Facebook%20Live%20was%20launched%20to,the%20ability%20to%20go%20Live.\">Facebook</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Instagram#:~:text=Instagram%20started%20insta%2Dstories%20in,later%20added%20in%20November%202016.\">Instagram</a> launched live streaming features in 2016, LinkedIn just recently decided to join the live streaming platforms.</p> \n<p>In February 2019, LinkedIn Live was launched to individual users. In 2020, it was <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/100225/broadcast-with-the-linkedin-live-feature\">announced that LinkedIn Live would also become available to business pages</a>.</p> \n<p>With this <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/blog/linkedin-company-pages/2020/introducing-linkedin-virtual-events-solutions\">announcement</a>, LinkedIn decided \"to bring you a tighter integration between LinkedIn Events and LinkedIn Live, by turning these two products into a new virtual events solution that enables you to stay connected to your communities and meet your customers wherever they are.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-live-stream-checklist\">Live streaming</a> continues to gain popularity among audiences. In fact, <a href=\"https://cdn.streamelements.com/static/Q4_December.pdf\">in 2019, internet users watched 1.1 billion hours of live video</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, according to <a href=\"https://www.go-globe.com/live-streaming-statistics/\">Go-Globe</a>, live streaming is expected to account for 82% of all internet traffic.</p> \n<p>Plus, <a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/april/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy20-q3-earnings\">LinkedIn Live streams have increased by 158% since February 2020</a>.</p> \n<p>Although LinkedIn Live isn't available to all businesses right now, it might be time to start thinking about live streaming.</p> \n<p>To get started with LinkedIn Live, you can <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/ask/lv-app\">complete an application online to become a Live broadcaster.</a></p> \n<p>In this post, let's review how you can leverage LinkedIn Live in your marketing strategy to attract new audiences.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Get the essential guide to using LinkedIn for marketing and professional  networking.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png\"></a></p> \n<h2>LinkedIn Live</h2> \n<p>LinkedIn Live is the live streaming feature that allows you to stream live video to your audience so you can drive engagement and build deeper connections.</p> \n<p>In fact, LinkedIn Live videos get, on average, <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/linkedin-live\">seven times more reactions and 24 times more comments</a> than native video produced by the same broadcasters.</p> \n<p>LinkedIn, known as the professional social media network, is a great place to stream live videos because you can truly get to know your audience and engage with them in a way that companies haven't been able to do before.</p> \n<p>Now that you know what LinkedIn Live is and why you should use it, let's dive into the logistics.</p> \n<h3>1. Apply for LinkedIn Live.</h3> \n<p>To get started with LinkedIn Live, you'll need to <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/ask/lv-app\">apply</a> to have the feature added to your profile.</p> \n<p>The application will ask you where you want to live stream (from a personal profile or a business page) and the link to the page you want to stream from.</p> \n<p>If you want to stream from a business page, you'll also need to include the profile URLs of the page admins. Only up to three page admins can have the ability to stream from your business page.</p> \n<p>Once you've applied, it's time to wait for approval. Be sure to keep checking on this, because you don't want to miss the notification that you've gained access to LinkedIn Live.</p> \n<h3>2. Sign up for a third-party streaming tool.</h3> \n<p>Before you can go live on LinkedIn, you'll need to sign up for a third-party streaming tool because LinkedIn doesn't offer native streaming currently.</p> \n<p>You can use tools like <a href=\"https://streamyard.com/\">StreamYard</a> or <a href=\"https://www.socialive.us/\">Socialive</a>. These tools are also helpful for going live on a desktop computer. They can make it easier to see comments and actually interact with your audience during the stream.</p> \n<h3>3. Connect LinkedIn to third-party tool.</h3> \n<p>Now that you've signed up for your streaming tool and you've received approval for LinkedIn Live, it's time to connect the two platforms.</p> \n<p>To do this, log in to your third-party tool and navigate to the area where you can add streaming destinations (this will change depending on the tool you're using).</p> \n<p>Once you find the right place to add a streaming destination, you should be able to click LinkedIn profile and connect from there.</p> \n<h3>4. Write a title and description for the stream.</h3> \n<p>After the tools are connected, you're ready to go live. Just click the button that says go live or start streaming. Before the platform actually starts live streaming, you'll see an area to write a title and description for the stream.</p> \n<p>Be sure to accurately describe what's going on in the video and what users can expect. This will help get your audience interested in the live stream.</p> \n<h3>5. Go live on your third-party tool.</h3> \n<p>Now all you need to do is go live. Before you do, make sure your camera and mic are all set up. You'll also want to double check the camera position, lighting, camera quality, audio, and background. It's important that your set up looks professional, especially given that LinkedIn is the professional social network.</p> \n<p>So, we know what LinkedIn Live is and how to get started, but you might be wondering, <em>\"How can I use this tool?\"</em> Let's dive in below.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Virtual Events</h3> \n<p>With the recent integration of LinkedIn Live and LinkedIn Events, the social media platform is a great place to host your virtual events.</p> \n<p>LinkedIn virtual events allow you to meet your audience where they are and host your event in a trusted environment.</p> \n<p>Additionally, hosting a virtual event on LinkedIn Live will help you attract the right professional audience.</p> \n<p>You can share your events with your business page followers, plus you can send event invitations to your first-degree profile connections.</p> \n<p>Instead of taking videos during your virtual conference and posting them on LinkedIn later, LinkedIn Live allows you to connect with your audience in real-time.</p> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/blog/linkedin-company-pages/2020/introducing-linkedin-virtual-events-solutions\">LinkedIn</a>, LinkedIn Live is seeing 23 times more comments per host and six times more reactions per post than native video.</p> \n<p>With LinkedIn Live, you can engage and connect with your followers in real-time during your virtual events.</p> \n<h3>2. Recruiting</h3> \n<p>LinkedIn is one of the main hubs for recruiters and job-seekers alike. In fact, recruiting is one of the top benefits of having a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-stats\">LinkedIn</a> profile for individuals and brands.</p> \n<p>With LinkedIn Live, you can support your recruiting efforts by showing off your workplace culture, introducing team members, and answering questions from your audience.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can host a live panel with employees on what it's like to work for your company. Team members can discuss what their hiring journey looked like and give tips to people who want to work for your company one day.</p> \n<p>You can also host a Q&amp;A with different people on your team to highlight their specific roles. For example, you can have them introduce themselves and their role, and then take questions about their day-to-day tasks and duties.</p> \n<p>If you want to use LinkedIn Live to support your recruiting efforts, think about other social media tactics you've implemented, and then strategize how those can convert into a live stream.</p> \n<h3>3. Thought Leadership</h3> \n<p>One of the central <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-myths\">LinkedIn strategies</a> for most companies is to use the social media platform to position yourself as an industry leader.</p> \n<p>To do this with LinkedIn, you can discuss current events in your industry and boost your content creation strategy.</p> \n<p>Using LinkedIn Live, you can host a panel for industry thought leaders, including those at your company, to talk about industry trends and issues.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can host a live stream dedicated to interviewing industry professionals and experts.</p> \n<p>Amplifying thought leaders and participating in industry discussions is a great way to use LinkedIn Live to attract new audiences.</p> \n<h3>4. Showcase Expertise</h3> \n<p>Not to be redundant, but becoming an authority in your industry is an important part of your marketing strategy.</p> \n<p>LinkedIn Live presents an excellent opportunity to showcase your expertise.</p> \n<p>Using live streaming technology, you can share your tips and tricks with your audience. To do this, brainstorm how-to topics that your audience is interested in.</p> \n<p>If you're struggling to come up with ideas, consider repurposing old content like blog posts or YouTube videos.</p> \n<p>Producing live streaming content will help you boost your content marketing strategy.</p> \n<h3>5. Announce a New Product or Partnership</h3> \n<p>As a professional social media platform, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-stories\">LinkedIn</a> is a great place to announce a new product or partnership.</p> \n<p>In fact, you might consider doing this on LinkedIn Live. You can bring on representatives from your company and partner company to discuss what the new partnership entails.</p> \n<p>This is also a great opportunity to educate and interact with your audience.</p> \n<p>By launching a product during a live stream, you can get immediate feedback from your audience, answer questions, and conduct a live demonstration.</p> \n<p>The announcement of LinkedIn Live proves that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/live-video-stats\">live streaming</a> will continue to be an important tactic in your marketing strategy. In fact, this feature shows that consumers are interested in interacting with brands in real-time.</p> \n<p>If you've already used Facebook and Instagram Live, LinkedIn Live might be another platform to use and experiment with -- especially if your audience is more likely to be on LinkedIn than other platforms.</p> \n<p>To learn more about how real brands are using LinkedIn Live, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-live-examples\">check out this blog post on LinkedIn Live examples</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"How to Use LinkedIn for Business and Marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flinkedin-live&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 29 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png","linkMd5":"801dfaf88348361c4982fc65db17d660","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","destWidth":754,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7622,"destBytes":12106,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-537_a5901e98cb60ea43.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-50-01-107_85ce3eb0b1d04252.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flinkedin-live&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425369986},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"8 Image SEO Best Practices to Make Your Content More Discoverable","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/image-seo","description":"<p>To consider the importance of visual search in 2021, let's start with an example.</p> \n<p>The other day, I Googled \"how to conduct a vlookup in Excel\". I skimmed a few articles but still felt dissatisfied — I didn't want to read about vlookups, I wanted to <em>see </em>it.</p> \n<p>Enter: The power of images.</p> \n<p>Once I clicked on \"Images\", I found what I needed quickly:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20conduct%20a%20vlookup%20in%20excel%20image%20results%20page.png?width=1774&amp;name=how%20to%20conduct%20a%20vlookup%20in%20excel%20image%20results%20page.png\" alt=\"how to conduct a vlookup in excel image results page\" width=\"1774\" style=\"width: 1774px;\"></p> \n<p>I know I'm not alone. In fact, nowadays, <a href=\"https://searchengineland.com/now-more-50-of-google-searches-end-without-a-click-to-other-content-study-finds-320574#:~:text=The%20update%20includes%20data%20from,Anti%2Dcompetitive%20behavior%3F\">half of all Google searches end on the search results</a>&nbsp;page, without the user clicking through to any results.</p> \n<p>In 2021 and beyond, it's critical marketers begin paying attention to the importance of visual images as a powerful opportunity to reach new audiences on the SERPs.</p> \n<p>Plus, as HubSpot's Marketing Manager Kristen Baker told me, \"After running an image experiment on the HubSpot Blog, I discovered that ranking in Google's image packs increases impressions and clicks to our content.\"</p> \n<p>But ... easier said than done, right?</p> \n<p>Here, let's explore what image SEO is, and the best practices you'll want to follow to make your webpages more discoverable in image search results.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: SEO Starter Pack [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Image SEO Best Practices</h2> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. Use relevant, accurate alt text for user accessibility and SEO.</span></h3> \n<p>As a quick refresher: Alt text is written copy that describes an image. For instance, if you click on <a href=\"https://www.pipsnacks.com/\">Pipcorn's popcorn product</a> and inspect the page, you'll see the alt text describes the product image accurately as \"Popcorn Family Pack Popcorn Pipsnacks LLC\":</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the%20alt%20text%20of%20popcorn%20family%20pack%20pipsnacks%20product.jpg?width=2534&amp;name=the%20alt%20text%20of%20popcorn%20family%20pack%20pipsnacks%20product.jpg\" alt=\"the alt text of popcorn family pack pipsnacks product\" width=\"2534\" style=\"width: 2534px;\"></p> \n<p>Alt-text plays two critical roles in SEO.</p> \n<p>First, alt text — also known as alt tags, or alt descriptions — helps search engine crawlers index your website more effectively, which has a positive effect on search results.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p style=\"font-weight: normal;\">In fact, Google <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/google-images\">states on its Developers page</a>, \"You can aid in the discovery process by making sure that your images and your site are optimized for Google Images … [and] increase the likelihood that your content will appear in Google Images search results.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Second, alt text improves the user experience. Alt text can describe an image to a visually impaired reader, and also helps if a reader can't load or see the image correctly on their device.</p> \n<p>To get a full run-down of how to write high-quality alt text, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/image-alt-text\">Image Alt Text: What It Is, How to Write It, and Why It Matters to SEO</a>.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. Consider using captions to describe an image.</span></h3> \n<p>Captions aren't typically necessary if the context of the page can help readers understand what the image is depicting — for instance, in this blog post I haven't used any captions because I've used text to introduce each image I've shown.</p> \n<p>However, if you have a visual-heavy website, consider using captions to help readers understand an image in context. For instance, on <a href=\"https://tomhull.co.uk/projects\">Tom Hull's photography portfolio</a>, he captions his images so viewers can contextualize where, or what, the image represents:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tom%20Hulls%20photography%20portfolio.png?width=1358&amp;name=Tom%20Hulls%20photography%20portfolio.png\" alt=\"Tom Hulls photography portfolio\" width=\"1358\" style=\"width: 1358px;\"></p> \n<p>Use good judgment when it comes to adding captions, but if you feel it can help readers (and bots) better discern an image, then it might be a worthwhile addition to a page.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. Compress images for faster load time.</span></h3> \n<p>Compressing images is a vital component of any good website optimization strategy.</p> \n<p>Why?</p> \n<p>Because, simply put, it helps your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-reduce-your-websites-page-speed\">web pages load faster</a>, which provides a better user experience and also helps boost your website's search engine rankings.</p> \n<p>To compress your images effectively, try a tool like <a href=\"https://compressjpeg.com/\">Compress JPEG</a>&nbsp;or <a href=\"https://squoosh.app/\">Squoosh</a>.</p> \n<p>Typically, less than 100 KB is ideal in terms of good file size.</p> \n<p>However, it's important to note — Google doesn't look at each individual image size. Instead, it looks at <em>total</em>&nbsp;page size.</p> \n<p>So, if you have a small image where quality differences are less substantial, then you might try compressing that image to 30-50 KB … which gives you extra room to keep another image 30 KB bigger, particularly if that image loses quality after compression.</p> \n<p>If you're still worried about image quality after compression, take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/high-resolution-image-guide\">How to Ensure Your Images are High Resolution</a>.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">4. Post original images — not just stock photos.</span></h3> \n<p>Ultimately, Google (and readers) prioritize original content — which means, if you're hoping your images will rank on image results pages, it's vital you use original, unique images.&nbsp;<span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"></span></p> \n<p>This is particularly important if you work for an ecommerce website and you're posting visuals of your product. Many shoppers use images to shop for consumer goods. In fact, <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/marketing-strategies/search/online-shopping-image-statistics/\"><span>50% of online shoppers say images</span></a> helped them decide what to buy.<span style=\"font-weight: normal;\"></span></p> \n<p>If your image doesn't accurately demonstrate your product, it will get buried under better, higher-quality images from competitors.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Consider using products like <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\"><span>Canva</span></a> to design in-house infographics, graphs, or animated images to help your brand stand out on search results pages and make your images more shareable.</span></p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">5. Name your file images before uploading them.</span></h3> \n<p>Your file name can impact how easy it is for search engine crawlers to interpret your image, so it's helpful to rename your file <em>before </em>uploading it onto your webpage.</p> \n<p>Rather than keeping the name a generic \"IMG_0883\", try using relevant keywords to describe what's in the image, similar to your alt text. This can also help ensure your image appears on the image search results page, which will increase traffic to your site.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">6. Use responsive images.</span></h3> \n<p>Responsive images are critical for ensuring your readers can see your images on any type of device. Nowadays, it's vital your pages are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/optimize-website-mobile-experience\">optimized for mobile</a>&nbsp;to impact search engine rankings, as well as user experience.</p> \n<p>If your images aren't responsive, the page won't appear as clean on mobile as it does on desktop — which negatively affects SEO, as well as your reader's perception of your brand.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, some website hosting services, including HubSpot, automatically ensure your images are responsive.</p> \n<p>However, if need be, you can make your images responsive by using quick code. For instance, you can add this code to your HTML:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&lt;img src=\"nature.jpg\" alt=\"Nature\" class=\"responsive\"&gt;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Or this code to your CSS:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">.responsive {</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&nbsp; width: 100%;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&nbsp; height: auto;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">}</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">7. Leverage images as a backlinking opportunity.</span></h3> \n<p>Creating high-quality, unique, original images isn't just great for your own website — it's also a fantastic opportunity to earn backlinks when <em>other</em>&nbsp;websites use your image for their own pages.</p> \n<p>For instance, consider the following graph created by Broadband Search:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mobile%20share%20of%20organic%20search%20visits%20graph.png?width=1802&amp;name=mobile%20share%20of%20organic%20search%20visits%20graph.png\" alt=\"mobile share of organic search visits graph\" width=\"1802\" style=\"width: 1802px;\"></p> \n<p>The image currently ranks in the first spot on the image search results page for the keywords, \"how many people use mobile to search\".</p> \n<p>Additionally, according to Ahrefs, this blog post has over <a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://ahrefs.com/site-explorer/overview/v2/prefix/live?target%3Dwww.broadbandsearch.net%252Fblog%252Fmobile-desktop-internet-usage-statistics&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1614801047073000&amp;usg=AOvVaw3beWeQSowox42-X4snYT9n\">3,000 backlinks</a>. I'm willing to bet that those backlinks are, in part, due to other companies wanting to use Broadband Search's unique graphs for their own content.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">If you create high-quality images, other companies may want to showcase those images on their own sites — with links back to your business. This means, ultimately, images can have a direct impact on the amount of traffic, leads, and customers you get for your business through your marketing efforts.</span></p> \n</blockquote> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">8. Add images to an existing sitemap.</h3> \n<p>Google <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/sitemaps/image-sitemaps\">suggests adding images to an existing sitemap</a>&nbsp;— or creating a separate sitemap just for images — to help search engines discover your images. In particular, this is helpful for images Google can't find through crawling, such as those accessed via JavaScript forms.</p> \n<p>Here's a <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/sitemaps/image-sitemaps\">sample sitemap</a>, with two images included:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/code%20to%20add%20images%20to%20an%20existing%20sitemap.png?width=1248&amp;name=code%20to%20add%20images%20to%20an%20existing%20sitemap.png\" alt=\"code to add images to an existing sitemap\" width=\"1248\" style=\"width: 1248px;\"></p> \n<p>Fortunately, if you don't want to add images to a sitemap manually, you're in luck — there are tools, such as <a href=\"https://www.angeldigital.marketing/image-sitemap/\">Angeldigital.Marketing</a>&nbsp;(one of the only free ones available!), that will automatically generate an image sitemap once you input a URL.</p> \n<p>Hopefully, you can use these best practices to level up and earn new traffic through search image results pages. Remember, a picture is worth a thousand words ... so just imagine the value of an <em>SEO-optimized</em> picture.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimage-seo&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\"
