\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 16 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"cb309a00584a90ba023bce1d7db2aa83","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20conduct%20a%20vlookup%20in%20excel%20image%20results%20page.png?width=1774&name=how%20to%20conduct%20a%20vlookup%20in%20excel%20image%20results%20page.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-54-579_935aa8c37f227a58.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1d7211ac-7b1b-4405-b940-54b8acedb26e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-30-734_ac504860637ee534.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the%20alt%20text%20of%20popcorn%20family%20pack%20pipsnacks%20product.jpg?width=2534&name=the%20alt%20text%20of%20popcorn%20family%20pack%20pipsnacks%20product.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn39@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-00-323_e18d347b102384ab.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tom%20Hulls%20photography%20portfolio.png?width=1358&name=Tom%20Hulls%20photography%20portfolio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-55-783_7eedbcbe26e0c408.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mobile%20share%20of%20organic%20search%20visits%20graph.png?width=1802&name=mobile%20share%20of%20organic%20search%20visits%20graph.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn73@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-02-411_b33b5eaae822c83f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/code%20to%20add%20images%20to%20an%20existing%20sitemap.png?width=1248&name=code%20to%20add%20images%20to%20an%20existing%20sitemap.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn2@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-58-621_eae0f22a4ea5fea3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05aa9467-4eda-4dd6-8b7f-ad9855abfe33.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn38@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-01-228_339ca67d143927cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimage-seo&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn87@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-50-00-769_137f82ec96d135ea.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370154},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"Media Buying 101: What It Is and How It Works [+15 Platforms to Use]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/media-buying","description":"<p>Ever wonder who is behind those <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/banner-ad-clicks?_ga=2.159081978.1709370357.1613508418-1939712723.1613508418\">banner ads </a>on the sites you visit the most? Or the Super Bowl ads we talk about for weeks after they've aired? The answer is media buyers.</p>  \n<p>When a brand gets a marketing budget, a portion of that typically goes to paid advertising. That's where media buying comes in.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=8ba68133-b408-456b-a531-171a91d2b38e&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Access Now: Free Media Planning Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8ba68133-b408-456b-a531-171a91d2b38e.png\"></a></p> \n<p>It doesn't get much buzz in the marketing industry, but this process is responsible for the targeted ads we see today.</p> \n<p>Let's dive into this process of which so many of us are on the receiving end.</p> \n<p>Whether they're watching a TV show or scrolling through a website, media buyers get brands in front of their target market.</p> \n<p>It's not like social media where users come and find you. It's an outbound strategy that is only effective if you have a well thought-out strategy. <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/rex-gelb-43445b1b/\">Rex Gelb</a>, director of advertising and analytics at HubSpot, says one of the biggest mistakes brands make is not thinking through their marketing goals.</p> \n<p>\"Some ad placements might be good for one set of goals, but bad for another. Let's say you're an airline and your focus is impressions and awareness, rather than an immediate sale, you can buy a placement that is known to get cheap impressions,\" he said.</p> \n<p>Gelb continued,\"Now, let's say you're a CEO who wants to promote a 'letter to our customers.' In this instance, what you'll care about is cheap clicks. Buying cheap impressions, which made sense in the previous example, no longer helps you accomplish your goal.\"</p> \n<p>That's why media planning is such an important step, as it helps you get the most out of your ads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Nowadays, media buying is done in one of two ways:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Direct buy </strong>– Media buyers forge relationships with publishers to negotiate ad inventory, e.g., working with a newspaper to have an ad placed in the upcoming issue.</li> \n <li><strong>Programmatic buy </strong>– The buying process is done using automated technology.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Media Buying vs. Media Planning</h2> \n<p>Media buying and media planning fall into the same category but are two different processes. While media buying focuses on getting the most impressions from the right audience at the lowest cost, media planning focuses on the strategy behind the campaign.</p> \n<p>During the planning phase, you determine what media will be most effective to reach a particular audience. So once media planning is complete, media buying follows. It's also important to note that media planning isn't solely for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/advertising\">advertising</a>, it's for any media a brand puts out there.</p> \n<p>However, in a small to medium-sized business, the job may be done by the same person or team.</p> \n<h2>How Digital Media Buying Works</h2> \n<p>With digital media buying, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/programmatic-advertising-glossary\">programmatic buying</a>, buying impressions is automated. The negotiation still technically happens but it's done at a much quicker rate through open and private marketplaces.</p> \n<p>The traditional approach, on the other hand, involves negotiations and relationship building with publishers.</p> \n<p>There are three components to this automated buying structure:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Demand-side platforms (DSP) </strong>where advertisers and ad agencies set up their campaigns, bid on ad inventory, and optimize their ads based on performance.</li> \n <li><strong>Supply-side platforms (SSP)</strong> where publishers sell their ad inventory. It's the publisher version of the DSP.</li> \n <li><strong>The ad exchange </strong>marketplace where advertisers and publishers buy or sell ad inventory through real-time bidding (RTB).</li> \n</ul> \n<p>RTB is not the only way to purchase impressions, you can also use private marketplaces, in which publishers limit who can participate in the auction. Another option is called programmatic direct, in which ad inventory is sold at a fixed cost per thousand impressions (CPM) with no bidding.</p> \n<p>So what about ad networks? Well those platforms aggregate ad inventory from various publishers and match them to advertisers' needs, serving as intermediaries. Think <a href=\"https://www.google.com/adsense/start/\">Google Adsense</a> and <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/audiencenetwork\">Facebook Audience Network</a>.</p> \n<p>Digital media buying can be more cost-effective and allow teams to focus on ad performance instead of back-and-forth negotiations. However, with the latest restrictions on cookies and <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/documentation/apptrackingtransparency\">Apple's AppTrackingTransparency</a> (ATT) rollout on iOS 14, it's unclear how that will affect the media buying space.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<p>\"With the upcoming release, Apple will be asking all of its users for permission to track when they open an app, and big ad networks like Facebook won't be exempt,\" said Gelb. \"Needless to say, a lot of iOS users are going to opt out, which will have negative implications in terms of targeting and conversion tracking.\"</p> \n<p>\"Nobody knows exactly what the impact will look like yet,\" he added, \"but we, in the industry, are crossing our fingers and hoping for the best.\"</p> \n<h2>Media Buying Tips</h2> \n<h3>1. Strategize.</h3> \n<p>Before you launch your ad campaign, you'll have to figure out a few things.</p> \n<p>The first question is, what's the goal of your campaign? Do you want more website traffic, brand awareness, social engagement? Aligning your team on one goal will help focus your efforts and better track your campaign's success.</p> \n<p>This leads us to key progress indicators (KPIs). You'll need them to monitor your campaign and determine if any adjustments need to be made. Lastly, your campaign will need a budget. If it's a long-running campaign, you may set a daily budget.</p> \n<p>These steps are typically completed during the media planning phase. However, in some cases, media planners are also responsible for buying ads as well.</p> \n<h3>2. Identify your target and where to find them.</h3> \n<p>Your next step is determining who the campaign will target and which networks will be most appropriate to reach them.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say a health-focused vegan dessert company wants to run an ad campaign next quarter and they want to target health-conscious, vegan consumers. The marketing team may want to advertise on YouTube videos with vegan-friendly content, fitness and nutrition websites, or even cooking and recipe pages.</p> \n<p>When buying media, you can target audience by device, location, behaviors, interests, web browser, and more.</p> \n<h3>3. Set up your campaign.</h3> \n<p>This step will vary depending on which media buying platform you are using.</p> \n<p>However, when typically using a DSP, you will input your campaign details, such as campaign type, creative assets, budget, target audiences, and bidding strategies. So, once that process is complete, all there is to do is launch and wait for results to come in.</p> \n<p>If you're taking a direct approach, this will likely be a collaborative process between your team and your publisher's account manager.</p> \n<h3>4. Track the results and optimize.</h3> \n<p>The most exciting (and possibly scariest) part of launching an ad campaign is tracking its performance.</p> \n<p>As soon as it launches, you can start gathering data on how your ads are performing. In this stage, it's important not to make decisions too quickly. You'll want to gather enough data to get a full picture before switching gears.</p> \n<p>Using the same vegan dessert company, let's say they launched an ad campaign through Google's ad network. They are using two static image ads and one video ad. After one week, they notice that the video ad is significantly outperforming the banner ads. The media buyer can decide to reallocate funds to that ad type and placement as it is generating better results.</p> \n<p>A media buyer's job is to maximize ad potential while staying within the budget. As such, if the ad isn't delivering on expectations, adjustments can and should be made during the length of the campaign.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/display-video-360/\">Google Display &amp; Video 360</a></h3> \n<p>Inside the Google Marketing Platform, you'll find Display &amp; Video 360. Originally DoubleClick Bid Management, DV360 integrates seamlessly with Google Analytics and other Google products. So, if your team is already using those tools, this may be the right media buying tool for you.</p> \n<p>There are five modules in DV360 to build your campaign, manage your audience and creative assets, analyze your data, and access ad inventory from top publishers. It also offers automated bidding and custom targeting using first and third-party data, making it easier to reach the right audience.</p> \n<p>Lastly, the platform allows advertisers to not only reach users on websites and YouTube but also TV.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.thetradedesk.com/us\">The Trade Desk</a></h3> \n<p>If you want access to premium publishers, the Trade Desk is one place you'll want to look.</p> \n<p>The platform has ad inventory from some of the biggest publishers, including Spotify, ABC, Wall Street Journal, and ESPN.</p> \n<p>One of the platform's key features is the AI-driven \"Koa,\" which uses data from over 600 billion daily queries to determine the smartest and most cost-effective way to run your digital campaign. The Trade Desk also has cross-device targeting capabilities to optimize your campaign's reach.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.adcolony.com/\">AdColony</a></h3> \n<p>AdColony helps brands reach mobile app users on both IOS and Android.</p> \n<p>The platform offers multiple video formats and placements, including full-screen, interactive, banner, and interstitial. This allows marketers to test various formats to see which garners the best results.</p> \n<p>AdColony also has over 90K direct app integrations and a reported 450 million supply of app users.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/solutions/products/amazon-dsp\">Amazon DSP</a></h3> \n<p>Every time you think Amazon has capped, it comes out with another vertical.</p> \n<p>Amazon DSP is one of the most used DSPs by brands and ad agencies, according to <a href=\"https://www.adexchanger.com/online-advertising/ad-buyers-starting-to-use-the-trade-desk-dsp-over-google-according-to-advertiser-perceptions-report/\">an article by Ad Exchanger</a>. With this DSP, you can reach users on Amazon-owned websites like Audible and IMDb, and other Amazon partners.</p> \n<p>They also make brand safety a top priority to ensure ads don't appear in risky or unsuitable environments.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.adcritter.com/\">AdCritter</a></h3> \n<p>AdCritter is a DSP made for small to medium-sized businesses.</p> \n<p>The platform has an ad builder and a library of pre-designed templates for businesses that may not have their own creative assets.</p> \n<p>With AdCritter, media buyers can even hand-select the websites they'll appear on to ensure their ads reach their intended audience. They can also reach consumers based on demographics and behavior.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.adobe.com/advertising/adobe-advertising-cloud.html\">Adobe Advertising Cloud</a></h3> \n<p>In 2017, Adobe launched a powerful DSP to tie with Adobe Audience Manager and Adobe Analytics.</p> \n<p>Similar to Google, Adobe's platforms integrate seamlessly, which makes collaboration easier and cross-data analysis simpler.</p> \n<p>Adobe also has powerful performance optimization features to maximize return on ad spend (ROAS).</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.verizonmedia.com/\">Verizon Media</a></h3> \n<p>If you're like me, any mention of Verizon automatically brings \"<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OPwPo-IAQ-E\">Can you hear me now?</a>\" to mind.</p> \n<p>Well, turns out, Verizon does offer way more than just cell phone coverage. In 2019, they reported that their DSP generated a 71% higher average conversion rate from campaigns compared to third-party segments.</p> \n<p>Their platform uses omnichannel strategies to engage consumers, such as digital out-of-home ads (i.e. billboards and on-car ads), audio streaming platforms, and connected TVs.</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.criteo.com/\">Criteo</a></h3> \n<p>This platform has access to a large network of premium retailers, making it a great DSP for brands who want to reach online shoppers. Think Best Buy, CVS pharmacy, Macy's, and Kohls.</p> \n<p>They rely on first-party data, instead of third-party cookies, to optimize ads and determine the right time and place to engage shoppers.</p> \n<p>Criteo's flexible attribution models also make data analysis easier for teams.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.stackadapt.com/\">StackAdapt</a></h3> \n<p>If your brand is in the alcohol, cannabis, gambling industry, it can be difficult to navigate ad regulations and compliance guidelines. StackAdapt helps brands strengthen their messaging and maneuver around those challenges.</p> \n<p>Some of their key features include dynamic retargeting, machine learning optimization, and cross-device capabilities.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://www.acuityads.com/\">AcuityAds</a></h3> \n<p>AcuityAds's best feature is its intuitive interface.</p> \n<p>With this DSP, your team can build an ad storyboard for any campaign and visualize the customer journey.</p> \n<p>There is a drag-and-drop feature that streamlines the media planning process. AcuityAds also has a journey map that allows brands to quickly visualize how a campaign is performing.</p> \n<h3>11. <a href=\"https://simpli.fi/home/\">Simpli.fi</a></h3> \n<p>Some DSPs offer pre-segmented audiences for ad campaigns, which can be limiting depending on who your team wants to reach. Simpli.fi offers custom targeting options to guarantee accuracy.</p> \n<p>The platform also promotes cost and analytics transparency. Marketers can see a detailed breakdown of where their ad dollars are going and how much of it goes toward platform fees.</p> \n<p>Another standout feature in Simpli.fi is the localization capabilities to reach audiences at the most granular level.</p> \n<h3>12. <a href=\"https://www.adelphic.com/\">Adelphic</a></h3> \n<p>If customer support is important to your team, consider Adelphic. This omnichannel DSP reports consistently having a client satisfaction rate above 95%.</p> \n<p>Unlike other DSPS, Adelphic offers a flexible pricing model, offering a subscription-based structure. This means media buyers pay one set monthly fee for unlimited media.</p> \n<p>Additional features include advanced reporting tools and data integrations.</p> \n<h3>13. <a href=\"https://www.amobee.com/\">Amobee</a></h3> \n<p>With Amobee, you can design digital campaigns on various platforms and across multiple browsers and devices.</p> \n<p>This DSP identifies potential consumers on a person-by-person level using their proprietary identity graph called \"Amobee ID.\" Using this tool, brands can forecast their campaign's performance across multiple devices and channels.</p> \n<p>The platform can also access APIs from social channels, such as Facebook and Instagram, for social campaign automation.</p> \n<h3>14. <a href=\"https://www.centro.net/solutions/basis/dsp\">Basis by Centro</a></h3> \n<p>With over 9,000 vendors and 11,000 contacts, Basis has one of the largest inventories in the market.</p> \n<p>Its <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/affordable-ai\">artificial intelligence </a>(AI) tool can also review over 30 campaign parameters and make optimization suggestions to get the best results. Basis also has scalable features, catering to both small and large businesses.</p> \n<h3>15. <a href=\"https://www.xandr.com/platform/invest/\">Xandr Invest</a></h3> \n<p>Zandr Invest specializes in reaching audiences through connected TV advertising.</p> \n<p>The platform is built on AT&amp;T's first-party data, giving brands unique insight to deploy targeted campaigns. Marketers can segment users by lifestyle, interest, intent, demographic, and viewership.</p> \n<p>Xandr also offers a sleek user interface to plan, launch and track campaigns.</p> \n<p>When buying media, no ad placement is accidental. It does involve some trial and error as you get started and the optimization process will last throughout the campaign. However, once you have a strategy to follow and an intuitive platform to track performance, this will result in effective ads that meet your marketing objectives.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=42d905a8-656c-41d8-8c20-b93c7c9c5a12&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"paid media template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/42d905a8-656c-41d8-8c20-b93c7c9c5a12.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmedia-buying&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 02 Apr 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8ba68133-b408-456b-a531-171a91d2b38e.png","linkMd5":"2579c7488b28972a03d641a46a9ec9c1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn17@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-691_dd5e75e818f84a1f.webp","destWidth":389,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4641,"destBytes":6192,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8ba68133-b408-456b-a531-171a91d2b38e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn17@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-30-691_dd5e75e818f84a1f.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/42d905a8-656c-41d8-8c20-b93c7c9c5a12.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn26@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-53-705_b0fecfde2c648704.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmedia-buying&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-58-951_8eba36e73b555e83.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370090},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"The Definition of SEO in 100 Words or Less [FAQs]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-seo","description":"<p>Search engine optimization (SEO) seems pretty straightforward. You pick a few keywords, and voilà! Your page is optimized for SEO, right?</p> \n<p>Not yet.</p>  \n<p>Many people understand the basic principles of SEO, but a lot has changed in the last decade.</p> \n<p>The SEO that we know and love today is not the same SEO that we knew and loved (or hated) 10 years ago. And that's why SEO is something marketers should continue to define, and redefine. Here's a brief definition in under 100 words:</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing Report [2020 Version]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>What Is SEO?</h2> \n<p>SEO stands for search engine optimization -- that much has stayed the same. It refers to techniques that help your website rank higher in search engine results pages (SERPs). This makes your website more visible to people who are looking for solutions that your brand, product, or service can provide via search engines like Google, Yahoo!, and Bing.</p> \n<p>What hasn't stayed the same are the techniques we use to improve our rankings. This has everything to do with the search algorithms that these companies constantly change.</p> \n<p>Here are some other frequently asked questions about this critical practice today.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How Does SEO Work?</h2> \n <p>SEO works by optimizing a website's pages, conducting keyword research, and earning inbound links. You can generally see results of SEO efforts once the webpage has been crawled and indexed by a search engine.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> There are a ton of ways to improve the SEO of your site pages, though. Search engines look for elements including title tags, keywords, image tags, internal link structure, and inbound links (also known as backlinks). And that's just to name a few.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://app.hubspot.com/l/blog\">HubSpot customers: you can check out the SEO panel in your HubSpot account to see how well you're optimized for those things.</a></p> \n<p>Search engines also look at site structure and design, visitor behavior, and other external, off-site factors to determine how highly ranked your site should be in their SERPs.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is an Organic Search?</h2> \n <p>Organic search refers to someone conducting a search through a search engine and clicking on a non-paid result. Organic search is a search marketing channel that can be used as part of inbound marketing to increase website traffic.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> In present-day SEO, you can't simply include as many keywords as possible to reach the people who are searching for you. In fact, this will actually hurt your website's SEO because search engines will recognize it as keyword stuffing -- or the act of including keywords specifically to rank for that keyword, rather than to answer a person's question.</p> \n<p>Nowadays, you should use your keywords in your content in a way that doesn't feel unnatural or forced. There isn't a magic number -- it all depends on the length of your keyword and article -- but if you feel like you're forcing it, it's better to ignore it and continue writing naturally.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is SEO Strategy?</h2> \n <p>An SEO marketing strategy is a comprehensive plan to get more visitors to your website through search engines. Successful SEO includes on-page strategies, which use intent-based keywords; and off-page strategies, which earn inbound links from other websites.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> Before you create a new site page or blog post, you'll probably be thinking about how to incorporate your keywords into your post. That's alright, but it shouldn't be your only focus -- or even your primary focus. Whenever you create content, your focus should be on the <em>intent</em> of your audience, not how many times you can include a keyword (whether it's long tail or short tail) in your content.</p> \n<p>To satisfy intent and rank well in the long term, build your SEO marketing strategy around <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy\">topics, not keywords</a>. If you do that, you'll find you can naturally optimize for important keywords, anyway. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-questions\">Understanding your target audience</a> (aka buyer personas) and what interests them is key to attracting relevant visitors to your website through search engines.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is Organic Traffic?</h2> \n <p>Organic traffic is unpaid traffic that comes from search engines such as Google or Bing. Paid search marketing does not increase your organic traffic numbers, but you can optimize your website using inbound marketing software to gain more visitors.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> One of the biggest changes in the last decade is the way other user behaviors shape the SERPs a user sees on search engines. And today, social media can have a big impact on your organic traffic trend line. Even just a few years ago, it didn't make a difference who was finding your content through social search. But now SEO takes into account tweets, retweets, Google+ authorship, and other social signals.</p> \n<p>Social search also prioritizes content and people that are connected to you. That could mean through a Facebook friend, Twitter follower, or connection through another social network. Sometimes social search will even prioritize content that has been shared by an influencer. Social search understands that you may be interested in content that your network feels is important to share, and therefore it'll often get surfaced to you.</p> \n<p>This all means when you're thinking about your SEO strategy, you need to think about how your social media strategy fits into the puzzle, too.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is Direct Traffic?</h2> \n <p>Direct traffic consists of website visitors that come to your website by typing the URL into their browser, rather than coming from another website, a search engine, or social media.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> Think of search engine optimization as \"search experience optimization.\" It's not just important for your users to find your website -- it's important for them to stay on your website, interact with your content, and come back later. Direct traffic doesn't just increase your \"page authority\" in the eyes of Google; it creates more opportunities to turn someone, who first discovered you organically, into a customer.</p> \n<p>SEO actually takes into account whether or not your visitors are staying on your website and engaging with other content. If you rank well for a keyword and attract a visitor who isn't relevant, it won't actually help your website.</p> \n<p>Think about your visitors and the content they are looking for more than how many people you can attract to your website.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>The Importance of SEO</h2> \n <p>SEO is important because it helps people find information and discover pages on the world wide web. SEO is especially important for businesses as it ensures they're answering their audience's biggest questions on search engines, while driving traffic to their products and services.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> In the past, SEO success was measured by whether or not you were ranked high on the first page of Google. But even if you ranked well for a term, does that actually mean you're going to see results?</p> \n<p>Not always. You might rank really well for terms that aren't ideal for your business. So you appear high on search engines, get a ton of traffic, but then your website visitors realize your company isn't what they were looking for. You don't convert customers from this traffic, and ranking high for this particular keyword is essentially fruitless.</p> \n<p>Also, you don't necessarily need to be in the top three slots to be successful. In fact, if you rank well on subsequent pages, you may still have a <a href=\"https://searchenginewatch.com/sew/study/2276184/no-1-position-in-google-gets-33-of-search-traffic-study\">high clickthrough rate</a>, albeit less traffic. That's great news for marketers who can't seem to bring pages into those top slots or off the second page.</p> \n<p>We said it before and we'll say it again: The amount of traffic to your page is less important than how qualified that traffic is.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How Much Does SEO Cost?</h2> \n <p>SEO can cost between $100 and $500 per month if you do it yourself with a keyword research tool. It can cost between $75 and $150 per hour for a consultant, and up to $10,000 per month if you hire a full-service marketing agency. Small businesses generally spend less on SEO than big brands.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> An SEO cost can mean one of two things: the investment in your organic search strategy, or how much you pay for paid search engine marketing (SEM) services like Google AdWords. If you're paying for a tool, consultant, or marketing agency to help you optimize your web content, your bill can vary wildly with the depth of the services you're receiving.</p> \n<p>Yes, $10,000 sounds scary, but <a href=\"https://searchengineland.com/much-seo-cost-277110\">40% of businesses</a> today are actually spending less than $1,000 a month on SEO.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is Paid Search Engine Marketing?</h2> \n <p>Paid search engine marketing refers to pay-per-click (PPC) advertising. This enables you to pay a search engine for text ads shown at the top and bottom of search engine results pages after someone conducts a search. It is used to increase website traffic and gain more customers.</p> \n</div> \n<p><strong>Looking deeper:</strong> You can actually pay for top rankings on Google SERPs by registering for a free account on Google AdWords. You'll then select various keywords you'd like to rank under, and pay Google each time a user clicks on your result. This is called PPC search engine marketing, and your ads will be noticeably different in their appearance than the organic results below them.</p> \n<p>The average cost of a paid search campaign on Google can be less than $1 per click, but, naturally, the more popular the keyword, the more you might pay.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Do SEO</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Conduct an audit of your website content.</li> \n  <li>Use keyword research tool to identify the keywords with which people are finding you.</li> \n  <li>Target new keywords you'd like to rank for.</li> \n  <li>Develop new content and optimize existing content.</li> \n  <li>Monitor your website's performance.</li> \n  <li>Purchase inbound marketing or SEO software.</li> \n  <li>Examine the web pages that are performing well.</li> \n  <li>Look for opportunities to earn inbound links from similar websites.</li> \n  <li>Monitor your change in rankings and traffic.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p>It's still the same thing it was 10 years ago -- a bunch of tactics that, if you employ them, will help you rank better in search engines. It's just the tactics we now use that have changed. If you're new to SEO or would like a refresher course, you might be interested in our free <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/seo-training\">SEO training</a>.</p> \n<p>It's up to us to stay on top of the rapidly changing trends, and remember that ultimately, the goal of search engines is to deliver the best experience possible to their end-user -- searchers. If you keep that goal in mind with your SEO strategy, you'll find your choices pay off, even if you're not totally up to date on every single nuance of search engine algorithms.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-seo&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Apr 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png","linkMd5":"df0ec0aaef48ee93f4a2565e6aaf5ec3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-34-687_0a6311d55189482b.webp","destWidth":373,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4265,"destBytes":5992,"author":"rleist@hubspot.com (Rachel Leist)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6baeae42-e710-4ecd-beb9-ceb2fb9f0877.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-34-687_0a6311d55189482b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-51-333_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-seo&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn93@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-53-126_31962217d5d178ce.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370091},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"A Beginner’s Guide to Web Analytics","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms","description":"<p>Views, new visitors, returning visitors — they sound similar but these metrics are not the same. If you don’t know the difference, you could be misinterpreting your website data and making some ill-informed decisions. &nbsp;</p> \n<p>We’re going to cover everything you need to know about web analytics so you can truly understand what's what, interpret your website analytics correctly, and make well-informed, data-backed decisions for your website and business.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=f01b80a4-709a-45fb-9327-679474f3d6da&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Guide: How to Run a Technical SEO Audit\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/f01b80a4-709a-45fb-9327-679474f3d6da.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<p>In this post, we’ll cover the following. You can click on any of the jump links to skip to that section:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms#what-is-web-analytics\">what web analytics is and why it's important</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms#web-analytics-examples\">web analytics examples</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms#web-analytics-best-practices\">web analytics best practices</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms#web-analytics-tools\">web analytics tools</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-web-analytics-traffic-terms#web-analytics-api\">web analytics api</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>There is tons of data you can collect to understand how people interact with your website and identify opportunities for improvement. You can track overall traffic, bounce rate, traffic sources, new and returning visitors, time spent on site, and much more.</p> \n<p>The amount of data can be overwhelming at first. That’s why it’s important to identify a few key metrics, particularly as you’re getting started. For example, you might start by focusing on bounce rate on a few key pages on your site. If visitors are quickly bouncing from your homepage, then that indicates they’re not finding the information they’re looking for quickly or easily enough. From there, you can identify possible next steps, like redesigning your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/main-website-navigation-ht\">website navigation</a>.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a closer look at why web analytics is important below.</p> \n<h3>Importance Of Web Analytics</h3> \n<p>Web analytics is critical to the success of your business. It enables you to better understand your site visitors and use those insights to improve the experience on your site. For example, if you discover that the majority of users on your site are using a mobile device, then you can focus on making your website more mobile-friendly.</p> \n<p>Web analytics can also shape your content and SEO strategy. Looking at your top viewed posts, you can begin to identify what types of content and topics perform best with your audience. If you notice how-to WordPress tutorials make up the majority of your top viewed posts, for example, then you might shift and narrow your focus from definition articles about anything web-related to how-to WordPress tutorials. Or maybe you look at your site’s traffic sources and notice that organic and email traffic are your top drivers and paid channels are your lowest. In that case, you might shift resources to invest more in your organic strategy than paid.</p> \n<p>Now that we have an idea of what web analytics is and why it’s important, let’s look at some key metrics you might track to measure progress against — and eventually meet — overarching business objectives, like increasing website traffic, leads, and revenue.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>Before you read on, it's important to note that various analytics tools may have slightly different definitions of the following terms. It's best to consult your particular tool's documentation to understand exactly how each is calculated.</p> \n<h3>Pageviews</h3> \n<p>Pageviews is the total number of times a page was viewed on your site. A pageview (or view) is counted when a page on your site is loaded by a browser. So if a person were to view a page on your site and reload the page in their browser, that would count as two views. If a person viewed one page, viewed a second page on your website, and then returned to the original page, that would count as three views.</p> \n<p>Pageviews can give you an idea how popular a page on your site is —&nbsp;but it’s important to look at in context of other metrics. A page with a high number of views for a post isn’t necessarily popular since a small group of visitors could be responsible for a lot of those views. A high number may also indicate that a page was confusing and required visitors to return to it multiple times.</p> \n<h3>Unique Pageviews</h3> \n<p>Unique pageviews is the total number of times a page was viewed by users in a single session. In other words, a unique pageview aggregates pageviews that are generated by the same user during a session (which we’ll define below). So if a person viewed the same page twice (or more times) during an individual session, unique pageviews would only count that pageview once.</p> \n<p>Since this metric discounts instances in which a user reloads or visits the same page in the same session, unique pageviews help you get a better understanding of how many visitors are viewing pages on your site and how popular individual pages are.</p> \n<h3>Sessions</h3> \n<p>A session is a group of interactions — including not only page views, but activities such as CTA clicks and events — that take place on your website within a given time frame.</p> \n<p>The timeframe of a session varies by web analytics tool. For example, sessions in Google Analytics and HubSpot’s traffic analytics tools last 30 minutes by default. A session ends and a new session starts for a user when either A) there has been 30 minutes of inactivity and the user becomes active again, B) the clock strikes midnight, or C) a user arrives via one traffic source, leaves, and then comes back via a different source.</p> \n<p>That means, if a user lands on your site, leaves, and returns within 30 minutes, Google Analytics and HubSpot will count it as one session, not two. On the other hand, if a user is inactive on your site for 30 minutes or more but then clicks on a CTA or takes another action, Google Analytics and HubSpot will count it as two sessions, not one, even if the user never left your site.</p> \n<h3>New Visitors</h3> \n<p>New visitors — also termed new users, unique visitors, or new visitor sessions, depending on the web analytics tools —&nbsp;is the number of unique visitors on your website.</p> \n<p>As the name implies, a new visitor is an individual who visits your site for the first time. These individuals are identified by a unique identifier. For example, when using HubSpot, the <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/reports/where-do-i-find-my-hubspot-tracking-code\">HubSpot tracking code</a>&nbsp;is installed on your site. Then, visitors on your site are tracked by the cookie placed in their browser by this tracking code.</p> \n<p>Two important notes to keep in mind. A single visitor can have multiple sessions and pageviews on your site. And unique visitors is not an entirely accurate metric. That’s because most web analytics tools use cookies to track visitors, which doesn’t always distinguish new visitors from returning ones (which we’ll define below). For example, if a person visits your site via their mobile phone and then on their personal computer, they'll be counted as new visitors on both occasions.</p> \n<h3>Returning Visitors</h3> \n<p>Returning visitors (or users) is the number of visitors on your website who have visited before. Not all web analytics tools include this metric, but some —&nbsp;including Google Analytics — do. In Google Analytics’s Audience reports, you can look at behaviors to see the ratio of new to returning users on your site.</p> \n<p>Looking at both new and returning visitors metrics are great for getting a sense of how well you're retaining your visitors, and how effective you are in attracting net new visitors at the top of the funnel.</p> \n<p>Again, just keep in mind that this metric won’t be completely accurate if the web analytics tool uses cookies to track visitors.</p> \n<h3>Traffic Sources</h3> \n<p>Traffic sources is a metric that shows where your site visitors are coming from. Like visitor information, this metric is usually collected via the tracking code on your site.</p> \n<p>The number of traffic sources you can track will vary depending on the web analytics tool. HubSpot’s traffic analytics tools tracks multiple categories, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Organic Search</li> \n <li>Referrals</li> \n <li>Organic Social</li> \n <li>Email Marketing</li> \n <li>Paid Search</li> \n <li>Paid Social</li> \n <li>Direct traffic</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Ideally, you want to increase all sources of traffic. But your biggest focus should be organic search, which is traffic that comes from non-paid search results in search engines like Google. That’s because this source has potential to drive huge amounts of traffic to your site. Plus, improving this channel often improves other channels, like referrals and social, as well.</p> \n<h3>Bounce Rate</h3> \n<p>Bounce rate is the percentage of visitors that leave your website after viewing a single page. You can look at bounce rate as a site-wide metric, or a page-level one. If your site’s bounce rate is high, then it might help to identify pages with high average bounce rates.</p> \n<p>At the page level, average bounce rate is the percentage of sessions&nbsp;that started on the page and did not move to another page on your site. A high average bounce rate might indicate there’s a problem with the page’s loading time, or that external links are not opening in a new tab or window, among other reasons.</p> \n<p><em>To learn what actions you can take to reduce bounce rate in WordPress or another platform, check out </em><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/how-to-reduce-bounce-rate-in-wordpress\">How to Reduce Bounce Rate in WordPress</a></em><em>. </em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Web Analytics Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Many aspects of web analytics are specific to your business: what metrics you track, how you build out reports, what tools you use. But there are some best practices that can help anyone collect, analyze, and report website data in a more consistent and effective way. Let’s look at a few.</p> \n<h3>1. Pick metrics that align with your business objectives.</h3> \n<p>Focusing on only one or two metrics won’t provide enough insight into how visitors are interacting with your site — but tracking every single metric might provide <em>too</em>&nbsp;much information. To make sure you’re focusing on the right metrics, start by plotting your business objectives. Think: what are the top priorities for your site? Then, think of specific strategies you’ll implement to achieve these objectives, like fixing broken links and images. You’re now ready to identify what metrics will help you track your progress for achieving your goals and ultimately your business objectives.</p> \n<h3>2. Use data to drive decision making.</h3> \n<p>After collecting and reporting your data, figuring out whether or not you met your goals is only the first step. The next —&nbsp;and arguably more important — step is to use that data to test, experiment, and make changes on your site. For example, say you identified some high-value content — like your Services and Pricing page — through user testing and feedback in your web design process, but these pages aren’t getting much traffic. In that case, you might move these navigation links from your footer to your header or implement other changes to make these pages easier to find.</p> \n<h3>3. Don’t limit your focus to traffic.</h3> \n<p>Understanding and reporting traffic data — including pageviews, top traffic sources, and most viewed pages — is important. But it’s just one piece of your website performance. High traffic doesn’t necessarily mean success. If you’re getting millions of pageviews but no conversions, then you’re probably not meeting all your business objectives.</p> \n<h3>4. Always pair data with insights.</h3> \n<p>If you report that your website got one million unique pageviews and four hundred thousand new visitors in a month, that doesn’t mean all that much. Only reporting the numbers provides an incomplete picture of your website performance. It’s essential that you pair this data with insights. If you report that your website got one million unique pageviews, which exceeded last month’s unique pageviews and showed a percent increase year over year, then the data is much more meaningful.</p> \n<h3>5. Look at your data in context.</h3> \n<p>While collecting and analyzing data, think about it in context. What variables or larger forces could be impacting the numbers? For example, seasonality, algorithm updates, and bots can all have a major impact on your traffic and other metrics. Say, a few pages on your site saw major spikes in traffic. These posts weren’t recently updated so you look where this traffic came from. If the traffic mostly came from one country where you usually don’t see much traffic, like <a href=\"https://medium.com/@hCaptcha/which-countries-have-the-most-bot-traffic-2019-dcb399f2c333\">Ukraine, Thailand, Vietnam, Turkey, or Russia</a>, then this was likely bot traffic. Looking at your data in context can help you better understand, analyze, provide insights, and make informed decisions with your data.</p> \n<h3>6. Share and ask for feedback from stakeholders.</h3> \n<p>You want to provide information to stakeholders in a consistent and understandable way. You also want to ask for information and ideas from these stakeholders. They can provide valuable feedback on how they use the data, what else they want to see or understand about their users or website, and how they think they can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ux-user-experience\">improve the user experience</a>&nbsp;or other issues the data uncovers.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Web Analytics Tools</h2> \n<p>Measuring organizational success requires more than one metric — and more than one tool. Let’s take a look at three web analytics tools you could use together.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/analytics\">HubSpot Marketing Analytics &amp; Dashboard Software</a></h3> \n<p><img alt=\"langing page of HubSpot Marketing Analytics and Dashboard Software \" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Draft%20-%20web%20analytics-1.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=Draft%20-%20web%20analytics-1.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p>With HubSpot’s free marketing analytics and dashboard software, you can measure the performance of all your marketing assets &nbsp;— from website and landing pages, to emails, blog posts, social media accounts, calls-to-action, and more — in one place. You’re able to track the complete customer lifecycle, measure traffic overall or on a page-by-page basis, and add multiple reports to your dashboard so you’re tracking your most critical metrics in one easy-to-access place.</p> \n<p>HubSpot’s free tool is ideal for anyone looking for built-in analytics, reports, and dashboards so they can make smarter, data-driven decisions.</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://analytics.google.com\">Google Analytics</a></h3> \n<p><img alt=\"Google Analytics dashboard showing users, sessions, bounce rate, and other web analytic metrics \" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Draft%20-%20web%20analytics.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=Draft%20-%20web%20analytics.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p>Used by <a href=\"https://trends.builtwith.com/websitelist/Google-Analytics\">over 28 million websites</a>, Google Analytics is one of the most popular web analytics tools. With this tool, you can track pageviews, unique pageviews, bounce rate, traffic channels, user retention, average session duration, sessions by country, sessions by device, and more. You can also build out reports about your audience, acquisition channels, website performance, and conversions in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-analytics\">Google Analytics</a>.</p> \n<p>Understanding the value, flexibility, and popularity of Google Analytics, some platforms offer unique integrations with this tool. <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/analytics-data/google-analytics-amplifier-222008\">Analytics Amplifier</a>, for example, is a HubSpot app that allows users to match HubSpot customer behaviours — including “hot leads” and “deal amount” — with real-time Google Analytics data.</p> \n<p>The sheer amount of metrics, reports, and integrations that can be tracked or created using Google Analytics can be overwhelming. Users without SEO or technical expertise, like content creators, may find it difficult and prefer an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/best-google-analytics-alternatives\">alternative</a>.</p> \n<h3><a href=\"https://www.crazyegg.com/\">Crazy Egg</a></h3> \n<p><img alt=\"homepage of web analytics tool crazyegg\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Draft%20-%20web%20analytics-2.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=Draft%20-%20web%20analytics-2.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p>Used by over 300,000 users, Crazy Egg is a unique web analytics tool that provides heatmaps, scrollmaps, and other visual reports to show you exactly how your visitors are interacting with your site. Thanks to Crazy Egg's tracking code, you’ll be able to watch what visitors are hovering over and clicking on in real time via heatmaps.</p> \n<p>Crazy Egg also also offers comprehensive A/B testing so you can test various content variables like color, copy, and content placement, to see how it affects the user experience and conversions. This makes Crazy Egg an ideal alternative or supplement to Google Analytics for users interested in conversion optimization.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>For example, Google Analytics offers several APIs that you can use to automate complex reporting and configuration tasks. One such API is the <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/core/v4\">Google Analytics Reporting API</a>. With this API, you can build custom dashboards to display your Google Analytics data, automate complex reporting tasks to save time (like getting data in two date ranges with a single request), and integrate your GA data with other business applications.</p> \n<p>Another popular example is <a href=\"https://docs.chartbeat.com/cbp/api/real-time-apis\">Chartbeat’s Real-Time API</a>. This API consists of data that is updated every three seconds so you can see how your visitors are interacting with your content in real time. You can use this data to improve audience engagement, inform editorial decisions, and increase readership, which is why Chartbeat is used by bigwig news organizations including <em>The New York Times</em>&nbsp;and <em>The Washington Post</em>.</p> \n<p><em>To understand what APIs are and how they work in general, check out </em><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/website/application-programming-interface-api\">The Ultimate Guide to Accessing &amp; Using APIs</a></em><em>.</em></p> \n<h2>Using Web Analytics to Improve Your Website</h2> \n<p>Whether you’re a small business, ecommerce site, or enterprise company, web analytics can help you and your company grow. By collecting, reporting, and analyzing data about your website, you can improve the user experience on your site and meet larger business objectives like increasing online sales.</p> 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"31 LinkedIn Stats That Marketers Need to Know in 2021","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-stats","description":"<p>With more than <a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">740 million active users in 2020,</a>&nbsp;LinkedIn's expanded from <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-platforms-through-the-decade\">a networking site</a>&nbsp;for professionals to one of the top social media platforms.</p> \n<p>By now, most of us have used LinkedIn to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/23454/the-ultimate-cheat-sheet-for-mastering-linkedin.aspx\">market our brands</a>, post <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-thought-leadership\">industry thought leadership</a>, or <a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/how-to-craft-an-inmail-that-gets-results&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1613532263441000&amp;usg=AOvVaw29TfFp610mPYD4KkirqqON\">look for our dream jobs</a>.</p> \n<p>As LinkedIn's continued to evolve by adding new features, like <a href=\"https://blog.linkedin.com/2020/september/24/share-your-professional-story\">LinkedIn Stories</a>, it's steadily grown its user base. While the LinkedIn audience still skews towards career-minded professionals, the industries, interests, and demographics represented on the platform have become much broader&nbsp;since its launch.</p> \n<p>Aside from LinkedIn's user growth, it's also continued to expand on advertising opportunities, which has helped make it one of the most important channels for B2B marketing.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-family: AvenirNext, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; color: #33475b;\"><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Get the essential guide to using LinkedIn for marketing and professional  networking.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ddd33609-1733-44d2-a811-a5435b201ffe.png\"></a></h2> \n<p>Today, it's becoming quite clear that LinkedIn isn't just for people in executive corporate roles. With millions of company pages and individual members, there's a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/top-phrases-topics-linkedin-data\">discussion, post, or professional network</a>&nbsp;for almost anyone on this channel.</p> \n<p>But, despite LinkedIn's growth and advertising opportunities, many marketers or brands still worry that the platform is still too formal or corporate for their audiences.</p> \n<p>The truth is -- LinkedIn could very well be one of your most underrated marketing channels.</p> \n<p>If LinkedIn's growth has caught your attention and you want to determine if its audiences and ad offerings are right for you, it's important to do some research before devoting more time and resources to this network.</p> \n<p>To get you started on your LinkedIn research, here are&nbsp;some need-to-know stats about the platform's audience, growth, and most common marketing tactics.</p> \n<h2>LinkedIn Stats to Know in 2021</h2> \n<h3>General LinkedIn Stats</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>In Q1 of 2021, LinkedIn revenue increased 23 percent year-over-year (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>In 2020, LinkedIn made $181 billion in revenue. (<a href=\"https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https://c.s-microsoft.com/en-us/CMSFiles/PressReleaseFY20_Q4.docx?version=7adc5017-52d2-5c72-cbeb-28ba7292a58d\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>LinkedIn has more than 740 million active users. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>In Q3 of 2020, the amount of content shared on LinkedIn increased by 50 percent. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/july/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy20-q4-earnings#:~:text=In%20FY20%2C%20LinkedIn%20revenue%20increased,%2Dyear%20in%20constant%20currency).\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>Marketing Solutions is growing 40 percent year-over-year in Q4 2020. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/october/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q1-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>Nearly 40 million people searched for jobs on LinkedIn each week in Q4 2020 (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/october/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q1-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>In 2020, LinkedIn was voted the most trusted network. (<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-digital-trust-study-from-insider-intelligence-2020-9#:~:text=Here%20are%20a%20few%20key,Instagram%2C%20Snapchat%2C%20and%20TikTok.\">Business Insider</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/LinkedIn-Most-Trusted-Platform.jpg?width=650&amp;name=LinkedIn-Most-Trusted-Platform.jpg\" alt=\"LinkedIn is the most trusted platform for 2020\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-digital-trust-study-from-insider-intelligence-2020-9#:~:text=Here%20are%20a%20few%20key,Instagram%2C%20Snapchat%2C%20and%20TikTok.\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<ul> \n <li>In Q4 of 2020, professionals watched 2X more LinkedIn Learning content than the year before. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>LinkedIn Live streams have increased by 158% since February 2020. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2020/april/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy20-q3-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>LinkedIn Demographics</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>57% of global LinkedIn users are male. (<a href=\"https://datareportal.com/reports/digital-2020-october-global-statshot\">DataReportal</a>)</li> \n <li>While 44% of those between 25 to 30 and 37% of those aged 30 to 49 say they use LinkedIn. (<a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2018/03/01/social-media-use-2018-appendix-a-detailed-table/\">Pew Research Center</a>)</li> \n <li>49% of internet users who make more than $75,000 annually use LinkedIn while only 26% of those in the $30,000 to $74,999 range use the platform. (<a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/04/10/share-of-u-s-adults-using-social-media-including-facebook-is-mostly-unchanged-since-2018/\">Pew Research Center</a>)</li> \n <li>51% of internet users with a college degree or higher use LinkedIn. (<a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/04/10/share-of-u-s-adults-using-social-media-including-facebook-is-mostly-unchanged-since-2018/\">Pew Research Center</a>)</li> \n <li>Four out of five LinkedIn members drive business decisions at their companies. (<a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/generate-leads\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>174 million U.S. Workers have LinkedIn profiles. (<a href=\"https://economicgraph.linkedin.com/resources/linkedin-workforce-report-january-2021\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>30% of LinkedIn users live in urban areas. (<a href=\"https://blog.hootsuite.com/linkedin-demographics-for-business/\">Hootsuite</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Marketing Tactics and Lead Generation</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>LinkedIn is the most popular platform of B2B marketers, followed by Twitter. (<a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/2018-b2b-research-final.pdf\">Content Marketing Institute</a>)</li> \n <li>As of January 2020, 663.3 million users have been reached by LinkedIn Ads. (<a href=\"https://wearesocial-net.s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/common/reports/digital-2020/digital-2020-global.pdf\">We Are Social</a>)</li> \n <li>Data shows that the most engaging LinkedIn posts are published on Wednesdays between 8 a.m. to 10 a.m. and noon, Thursday at 9 a.m. and 1 p.m. to 2 p.m., and Friday at 9 a.m. (<a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/best-times-to-post-on-social-media/#li-times\">Sprout Social</a>)</li> \n <li>LinkedIn's lead conversion rates are 3X higher than other major ad platforms, including Google Ads. (<a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/generate-leads\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>Roughly 15% of marketers are creating content for LinkedIn. (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?utm_campaign=2020%20State%20of%20Marketing%20&amp;utm_source=Blog%20CTA&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-stats&amp;hubs_post-cta=HubSpot\">HubSpot</a>)</li> \n <li>Only 10% of marketers say they're investing in LinkedIn. (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?utm_campaign=2020%20State%20of%20Marketing%20&amp;utm_source=Blog%20CTA&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-stats&amp;hubs_post-cta=HubSpot\">HubSpot</a>)</li> \n <li>In a study of over 5,000 businesses, HubSpot found that traffic from LinkedIn generated the highest visitor-to-lead conversion rate at 2.74%, almost three times or 277% higher than both Twitter (.69%) and Facebook (.77%). (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30030/linkedin-277-more-effective-for-lead-generation-than-facebook-twitter-new-data.aspx\">HubSpot</a>)&nbsp;<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/24%20LinkedIn%20Stats%20That%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know%20in%202020%20(From%20the%20BIR-1-1.png?width=650&amp;name=24%20LinkedIn%20Stats%20That%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know%20in%202020%20(From%20the%20BIR-1-1.png\" alt=\"LinkedIn is the best social network for lead generation\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>LinkedIn User Statistics</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>40 million people look to LinkedIn for job opportunities every week. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/about-us#Statistics\">LinkedIn)</a></li> \n <li>Three people are hired each minute on LinkedIn. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/about-us#Statistics\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>There are more than 55 million companies listed on LinkedIn and there are 14 million open jobs on the platform. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/about-us#Statistics\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>For companies who are active on LinkedIn, 30% of their engagement comes from their own employees. They’re 14x more likely to share their employers’ content on the platform compared to other types of content. (<a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/blog/linkedin-company-pages/2020/linkedin-pages-and-elevate--better-together\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>LinkedIn Advertising Statistics</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>LinkedIn Ads accounted for more than a third of LinkedIn’s total revenue in Q4 2020. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>).</li> \n <li>Marketing Solutions increased 50%. LinkedIn predicts the jump was caused by advertisers choosing the platform as the trusted way to source warm leads. (<a href=\"https://news.linkedin.com/2021/january/linkedin-business-highlights-from-microsoft-s-fy21-q2-earnings\">LinkedIn</a>)</li> \n <li>Hootsuite and We Are Social report that 727 million people can be reached through LinkedIn advertising. (<a href=\"https://datareportal.com/reports/digital-2020-october-global-statshot\">DataReportal</a>)</li> \n <li>Quarter-over-quarter in 2020, LinkedIn’s advertising reach has increased 3.5%. (<a href=\"https://datareportal.com/reports/digital-2020-october-global-statshot\">DataReportal</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img alt=\"LinkedIn advertising audience overview for 2020 featuring five Linkedin audience statistics\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/31%20LinkedIn%20Stats%20That%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know%20in%202021.jpeg?width=600&amp;name=31%20LinkedIn%20Stats%20That%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know%20in%202021.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://datareportal.com/reports/digital-2020-october-global-statshot\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Source</a></p> \n<h2>Mastering LinkedIn Marketing</h2> \n<p>Because LinkedIn has a slightly different audience from other major platforms like Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram, you'll want to understand whether your consumers are engaging there before investing time or resources into a campaign or advertisement. Be sure to keep the stats above, as well as emerging research about the platform and its audiences, in mind as you prepare your next social media strategy.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"How to Use LinkedIn for Business and Marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b612a0dc-34ea-4e79-908b-28874def7e5a.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flinkedin-stats&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
