Hahn","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b9960dd8-68b8-4caa-8a08-d3f7b7c3406e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn64@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-31-002_2bddda1efbc7d4e7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.47.09%20PM.png?width=1220&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.47.09%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn72@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-51-443_6d5631615194d0da.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/joomla-kunena-forum-example.jpg?width=650&name=joomla-kunena-forum-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn34@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-51-505_b28b0383dde87792.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/discourse-forum-software.jpg?width=650&name=discourse-forum-software.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn89@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-52-926_de1fb2965f503e2f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.52.39%20PM.png?width=1594&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.52.39%20PM.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.54.10%20PM.png?width=1800&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.54.10%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn41@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-51-534_1a0e60bdf7456d0b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/phpbb-forum-example.jpg?width=650&name=phpbb-forum-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn62@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-01-264_3b411c6bcdbea494.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.57.35%20PM.png?width=2428&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.57.35%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn60@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-57-244_9a8acd5137041f89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.58.58%20PM.png?width=1742&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%201.58.58%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn66@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-874_8ab2d4eb9d9c65a2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%202.01.21%20PM.png?width=1442&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%202.01.21%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn25@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-01-896_f5c6ebe2e9ea8e65.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%202.05.41%20PM-1.png?width=2054&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-23%20at%202.05.41%20PM-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn98@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-56-559_c8d64f741f92824d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mixpanel_community.png?width=1640&name=mixpanel_community.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn89@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-55-713_ed2c1cce6f2964e8.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/39441929-8c6f-4361-849c-69692c8ed5c4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn90@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-56-575_79df88906475ef60.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-forum-software&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn19@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-57-866_551c7183ab6c155c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370130},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"How To Choose the Right KPIs for Your Business","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/choosing-kpis","description":"<p>How can you tell if your company is growing?</p> \n<p>Sure, you can speak to a few team leads and get regular reports on their performance. But if you're not measuring that information against something else, how will you know when you've met the mark or fallen short?</p> \n<p>As they say, what gets measured gets improved. Quantifying your current performance through key performance indicators (KPIs) will give you a framework from which to assess your progress.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\"></a></p> \n<p>But how do you choose the right KPIs to focus on for your business? The short answer is that it really depends.</p> \n<p>While there isn't a hard-and-fast rule for choosing the proper KPIs, there are a number of factors you should always take into consideration.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll walk you through some of the factors that influence which KPIs you should focus on and help you hone in on the metrics that matter the most for your business.</p> \n<p>Let's get started.</p> \n<p>One thing to remember about KPIs is that they're meant to measure your most impactful indicators.</p> \n<p>For instance, your social media team may have a ton of data points that can serve as KPIs. However, they should only choose the ones that align with the broader business goals. Let's say it's brand awareness. In this case, follower count, post reach, and impressions will likely be the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-metrics-ceos-cares-about\">social media KPI metrics </a>to measure.</p> \n<p>With that in mind, having KPIs means narrowing your focus on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/marketing-metrics-to-know\">a few vital metrics </a>that will influence your business the most.</p> \n<h2>OKR vs. KPI</h2> \n<p>Objectives and Key Results (OKR) and KPIs are often used interchangeably because both terms refer to goals that are tracked and measured. However, where they differ is intention.</p> \n<p>Put simply, KPIs indicate if your business is hitting its targets. They are often called health metrics as they tell you how the company is doing to meet an objective that's already set.</p> \n<p>OKRs, on the other hand, are broad objectives for your business with the key results that will signify achievement in meeting those objectives. They are aggressive and ambitious goals that speak to the business's big-picture vision.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say a technology company has the objective of becoming one of the top 10 providers in their industry in 2021. Their key results could be:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Acquire 1,000 new customers by Q3.</li> \n <li>Generate 3,000 leads every month.</li> \n <li>Increase annual membership sales by 30%.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>While KPIs are ideal for scaling, OKRs are designed for dramatic growth. They're more ambitious and push teams to stretch their capabilities.</p> \n<p>It's also important to note that while KPIs can be the key results in your OKR, the opposite is generally not true.</p> \n<p>For example, your marketing team could have a KPI of 3,000 leads as mentioned in the example above. However, it's unlikely that any department would list the \"Top 10\" goal as their KPI as that speaks to a broader vision and has a more flexible timeline.</p> \n<h2>What is KPI reporting?</h2> \n<p>A KPI report is a visual dashboard used to track your metrics and assess how your team is performing against the targets. You can display your report using charts, graphics, and tables depending on the data you want to display and the needs of your team.</p> \n<p>As a business, you'll likely have data coming in on a daily basis that may or may not relate to your KPIs. Having a reporting tool does a few things, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Allowing you to track your most impactful metrics and filter out irrelevant data</li> \n <li>Making the data easily accessible to decision-makers and collaborators</li> \n <li>Giving you a quick and digestible snapshot of your team's performance</li> \n <li>Aligning everyone on the goals</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>How To Measure KPIs</h3> \n<p>Before you can measure your KPIs, you'll need to determine which metrics to track. This will greatly depend on your goals and your team.</p> \n<p>Once you narrow that down, set your targets. They're usually based on a combination of factors, including historical performance and industry standards.</p> \n<p>You'll also have to answer the who, when, and why. Who is responsible for this KPI? Identify the person on your team who is managing this KPI, so they can be the go-to when addressing roadblocks that may affect performance. They will also be responsible for reporting on progress.</p> \n<p>As for the \"when,\" you'll need to know the timeline to reach these targets. Many businesses set them on a monthly or quarterly basis, but your timeline can be shorter or longer depending on your team.</p> \n<p>Lastly: the why. It's the most important thing to keep in mind when measuring your KPIs. Having your goals clearly identified can help motivate your team and make sure everyone is aligned on the direction you're going in.</p> \n<h2>Types of Key Performance Indicators</h2> \n<p>KPIs can be set on a team basis. Sales' KPIs will be completely different from HR's KPIs. Beyond those differences, there are also variations in the types of indicators you can measure.</p> \n<p>Here are a few of the most common types of KPIs:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>A quantitative KPI </strong>relies on numbers to gauge progress. E.g., \"Sales team to generate 100 sales-qualified leads every month.\"</li> \n <li><strong>A qualitative </strong><strong>KPI </strong>looks at opinion- or feeling-based data. E.g., \"Brand sentiment.\"</li> \n <li><strong>A leading KPI </strong>can predict future performance. E.g., \"Website traffic.\" More traffic can mean more conversions, more leads, and more revenue.</li> \n <li><strong>A lagging KPI </strong>describes a past result. E.g., \"Turnover rate.\"</li> \n <li><strong>An input KPI </strong>measures the assets, time, and resources needed to complete a certain action or project. E.g., \"Employee count, budget.\"</li> \n <li><strong>A process </strong><strong>KPI </strong>assesses efficiency and productivity within the business. E.g., \"Average sales call time.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>KPI Examples</h2> \n<p>Your organization's business model and the industry in which you operate will influence the KPIs you choose.</p> \n<p>For example, a B2B software-as-a-service (SaaS) company might choose to focus on customer acquisition and churn, whereas a brick-and-mortar retail company might focus on sales per square foot or average customer spend.</p> \n<p>Here are a few examples of some industry-standard KPIs:</p> \n<table style=\"border-color: #99acc2; border-collapse: collapse; table-layout: fixed; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>SaaS KPIs</strong></p> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Professional Service KPIs</strong></p> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Monthly recurring revenue (MRR)</li> \n     <li>Churn</li> \n     <li>Cost per acquisition (CPA)</li> \n     <li>Average revenue per retainer</li> \n     <li>Lifetime value (LTV)</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Bookings</li> \n     <li>Utilization</li> \n     <li>Backlog</li> \n     <li>Revenue leakage (<a href=\"http://www.exact.com/downloads/finish/65-whitepapers/276-kpis-for-professional-services/0\">link</a>)</li> \n     <li>Effective billable rate</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Online Media / Publishing KPIs</strong></p> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Retail KPIs</strong></p> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Unique visitors</li> \n     <li>Page views</li> \n     <li>Share ratio</li> \n     <li>Social referral growth</li> \n     <li>Time on site</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Capital expenditure</li> \n     <li>Customer satisfaction</li> \n     <li>Sales per square foot</li> \n     <li>Average customer spend (ACS)</li> \n     <li>Stock turnover</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>While you will most certainly want to consider industry standard KPIs, it is more important that you choose the KPIs that are relevant to your specific company and the goals you are working toward.</p> \n<h2>How To Determine KPIs</h2> \n<h4><strong>Choose KPIs directly related to your business goals.</strong></h4> \n<p>KPIs are quantifiable measurements or data points used to gauge your company's performance relative to a goal. For instance, a KPI could be related to your goal of increasing sales, improving the return on investment of your marketing efforts, or improving customer service.</p> \n<p>What are your company goals? Have you identified any major areas for improvement or optimization? What are the biggest priorities for your management team?</p> \n<p>Answering these questions will bring you one step closer to identifying the right KPIs for your brand.</p> \n<h4><strong>Focus on a few key metrics, rather than a slew of data.</strong></h4> \n<p>As you begin to identify KPIs for your business, less is worth more. Rather than choosing dozens of metrics to measure and report on you should focus on just a few <em>key </em>ones.</p> \n<p>If you track too many KPIs, you might become overwhelmed with the data and lose focus.</p> \n<p>As you can imagine, every company, industry, and business model is different so it is difficult to pinpoint an exact number for the amount of KPIs you should have. However, a good number to aim for is somewhere between two to four KPIs per goal.Enough to get a good sense of where you stand but not too many where there's no priority.</p> \n<h4><strong>Consider your company's stage of growth.</strong></h4> \n<p>Depending on the stage of your company – startup vs. enterprise – certain metrics will be more important than others.</p> \n<p>Early-stage companies typically focus on data related to business model validation while more established organizations focus on metrics like cost per acquisition and customer lifetime value.</p> \n<p>Here are a few examples of potential key performance indicators for companies in various stages of growth:</p> \n<table style=\"border-color: #99acc2; border-collapse: collapse; table-layout: fixed; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Pre-Product Market Fit</strong></p> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Product Market Fit</strong></p> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Expansion</strong></p> </td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Qualitative feedback</li> \n     <li>Customer interviews</li> \n     <li>Awareness</li> \n     <li>Stickiness</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Monthly recurring revenue (MRR)</li> \n     <li>Renewals</li> \n     <li>Churn</li> \n     <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/customer-satisfaction\">Customer satisfaction</a></li> \n    </ul> </td> \n   <td style=\"border: 1pt solid #808080;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Cost per acquisition (CPA)</li> \n     <li>Average order size (AOS)</li> \n     <li>Lifetime value (LTV)</li> \n     <li>Number of customers acquired</li> \n    </ul> </td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h4><strong>Identify both lagging and leading performance indicators.</strong></h4> \n<p>The difference between lagging and leading indicators is essentially knowing how you did, versus how you are doing. Leading indicators aren't necessarily better than lagging indicators, or vice versa. You should just be aware of the differences between the two.</p> \n<p>Lagging indicators measure the output of something that has already happened. Total sales last month, or the number of new customers or hours of professional services delivered, are examples of lagging indicators. These types of metrics are good for purely measuring results, as they solely focus on outputs.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, leading indicators measure your likelihood of achieving a goal in the future. These serve as predictors of what's to come. Conversion rates, sales opportunity age, and sales rep activity are just a few examples of leading indicators.</p> \n<p>Traditionally most organizations have solely focused on lagging indicators. One of the main reasons for this is they tend to be easy to measure since the events have already happened. For instance, it is very easy to pull a report of the number of customers acquired last quarter.</p> \n<p>But measuring what happened in the past can only be so helpful.</p> \n<p>You can think of leading indicators as business drivers because they come before trends emerge, which can help you identify whether or not you are on track to reaching your goals. If you can identify which leading indicators will impact your future performance you will have a much better shot at success.</p> \n<p>With every business, growth is the goal. KPIs help you track your progress and scale progressively to grow in whichever way that matters to your company.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fchoosing-kpis&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 25 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"01aa565f6936083b917704853f97bec2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"jesse@kulapartners.com (Jesse Mawhinney)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn3@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-681_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn3@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-54-880_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fchoosing-kpis&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn92@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-54-547_164bcdc1ed74ea71.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370074},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"10 Common Virtual Meeting Mistakes to Avoid, According to Remote HubSpot Employees","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/virtual-meeting-mistakes","description":"<p>Whether it’s with a single client, a large internal team, or external stakeholders, hosting successful, engaging meetings is an art form.</p>  \n<p>It takes skill to know how to simultaneously capture attention, inform, be interactive, and leave a lasting impression — it’s really not an easy feat.</p> \n<p>The prospect of holding a meeting may become even more stressful when the session is online. As meetings are new to the virtual world, there is no roadmap to hosting a successful one.</p> \n<p>However, as nice as it would be, a roadmap is not always the key to success. Sometimes the key can be learning from people who have experience hosting virtual meetings and understanding what they think makes them successful. In this post, we’ll discuss common virtual meeting mistakes and get insight from experienced HubSpotters on how to avoid them.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download our complete productivity guide here for more tips on improving your  productivity at work.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h3>1. Not acknowledging mistakes.</h3> \n<p>Nobody’s perfect.</p> \n<p>Although many people know that, an all-too-common moment in virtual meetings is pushing mistakes under the rug and acting like they haven’t happened. Unfortunately, when everyone is looking at their screen, most people notice mistakes, and ignoring them can create a sense of awkwardness.</p> \n<p>In these moments, it’s important to remember that an increasingly virtual world is new to everyone. We’re all aware that adapting to new processes can be difficult, so of course, there will be unexpected issues.</p> \n<p>Jon Dick, Senior Vice President of Marketing at HubSpot, agrees, and his advice is relatively straightforward: “As the old saying goes, ‘If you can’t hide it, feature it!’ Slides not sharing? Children bursting into the room? Not on mute? Don’t stress out — just laugh, relax, and acknowledge it.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/virtual.png?width=1012&amp;name=virtual.png\" alt=\"quote snippet &quot;As the old saying goes, 'if you can't hide it, feature it!' slides not sharing? children bursting into the room? not on mute? don't stress out — just laugh, relax, and acknowledge it.&quot;\" width=\"1012\" style=\"width: 1012px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>2. No backup plan for faulty technology.</h3> \n<p>A dysfunctional microphone or PowerPoint won’t derail your in-person meeting, but it will effectively shut down a virtual one. Given this, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ashley-ladd/\">Ashley Ladd</a>, Manager on the Diversity, Inclusion, &amp; Belonging team at HubSpot, says that not having a tech backup plan for your virtual meeting is a mistake.</p> \n<p>Ladd says, “Our internet connection is always stable until we need it to be, so having a backup plan ensures flawless execution of your events and less worrying about your connection or having the meeting dropped.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ladd.png?width=1012&amp;name=ladd.png\" alt=\"quote snippet &quot;our internet connection is always stable until we need it to be, so having a backup plan ensures flawless execution.&quot;\" width=\"1012\" style=\"width: 1012px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>She says that your plan B can include things like a designated co-host, teammate, or friend to take over if something goes wrong, or while you troubleshoot any issues: “The worst is when you have to spend time fussing with your connection and it interrupts the flow of your meeting.”</p> \n<h3>3. A lack of discussion and collaboration.</h3> \n<p>One of the greatest aspects of meetings is the collaboration and discussion that stems from audience engagement. Virtual meetings notably make this harder, and they’re often marked by the opposite.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/becca-stamp/\">Becca Stamp</a>, Senior Global Learning and Development Onboarding Specialist at HubSpot, says that a common mistake is not making space for conversation. Her solution is to make a special effort to encourage it: “It’s important to give everyone space to come off mute and contribute throughout the session. Participants can add so much value, both through discussion and chat.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1).png?width=1012&amp;name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1).png\" alt=\"quote snippet &quot;it's important to give everyone space to come off mute...participants can add so much value, both through discussion and chat.&quot;\" width=\"1012\" style=\"width: 1012px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/jill-noonan-6a82926a/\">Jill Noonan</a>, Senior Facilitator at HubSpot, seconds this tip and says: “Create interaction whenever possible. Whether in person or virtual, listening to one person present without any interaction or conversation can be draining for those listening. If you’re presenting in a virtual environment and someone asks a question, open it up for group discussion.”</p> \n<h3>4. Leaving inclusion and accessibility by the wayside.</h3> \n<p>Whether your meeting is in-person or virtual, it’s crucial to be mindful of and prioritize inclusion and accessibility.</p> \n<p>Opt to use <a href=\"https://otter.ai/login\">software that adds captions</a> for speech transcription, write alternative descriptive text of images for screen reading devices, and be mindful of the differing experiences that attendees may have.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/benjaminrpereira/\">Ben Pereira</a>, Diversity, Inclusion and Belonging Program Manager at HubSpot, says that an easy way to show you care about DI&amp;B is to encourage attendees to put pronouns in their profile names. He says, “Add pronouns to your Zoom name as a way of showing up for inclusion during virtual meetings, and encourage your teammates to do so as well.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1)-1.png?width=594&amp;name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1)-1.png\" alt=\"quote snippet that reads &quot;Add pronouns to your zoom name as a way of showing up for inclusion during virtual meetings, and encourage your teammates to do so as well.&quot;\" width=\"594\" style=\"width: 594px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>5. Trying to multitask.</h3> \n<p>It’s never been easier to join a meeting, and it’s also never been easier to lose focus during a meeting.</p> \n<p>If you’re using a personal computer, it can be especially difficult to stay focused because everything you enjoy is right there in front of you. A quick check of your email can accidentally turn into ten minutes of distractions that take you away from meeting content.</p> \n<p>That’s why a common mistake is, or at least trying, to multitask during meetings. Dick says: “Multitasking during your meetings is a sure-fire way to feel uninformed and unaccomplished at the end of the day.” His solution? Easy — “Mute notifications and close email.”</p> \n<h3>6. Not encouraging speakers and hosts.</h3> \n<p>Don’t assume that someone may be more comfortable during a virtual meeting because they’re not in front of an in-person audience. It can still be just as nerve-wracking to face a screen full of faces as it is to stare at a room full of people.</p> \n<p>However, the support that people receive from attendees during in-person meetings, like applause, can be encouraging and make hosts feel more comfortable. Unfortunately, this support is often missing from virtual meetings.</p> \n<p>Even if you can’t clap, Dick says that it’s still essential to show encouragement virtually, as it can feel strange to present without any human reactions. He says, “Hop in the chat window to cheer people on and encourage them when they’re presenting. It’s encouraging and helps people feel like you’re listening.”</p> \n<h3>7. Leaving no space for networking.</h3> \n<p>As virtual meetings occur on a digital device, attendees have no further interaction with their peers when they end. Stamp says that forgetting about the hallway chat aspect of meetings can be detrimental, as this time often gives people a chance to network, make connections, and decompress.</p> \n<p>She says, about HubSpot employee onboarding, “We have seen incredible value in spending five to ten extra minutes on Zoom at the end of each session. It creates the hallway environment of in-person sessions, and these conversations help us build more community among the cohorts.”</p> \n<h3>8. Being impersonal.</h3> \n<p>You may feel pressure to display a more polished side of yourself during virtual meetings. In some cases, like when business executives speak to their teams, it makes sense and is expected that the experience is more corporate and clean cut.</p> \n<p>However, being too polished can sometimes dehumanize you, which affects relatability between you and your audience.</p> \n<p>Robotic meeting environments can also feel boring and disengaging, which is the opposite of what you want. Noonan’s tip is to display humanity through personalization. She says, “Humanity is extremely important. Knowing when and where to use personal examples or display vulnerability builds trust and shows that we’re all on the same page.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20jill-%20506x253%20(1).png?width=1012&amp;name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20jill-%20506x253%20(1).png\" alt=\"quote snippet that reads &quot;knowing when and where to use personal examples or display vulnerability builds trust and shows that we're all on the same page.&quot;\" width=\"1012\" style=\"width: 1012px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<h3>9. Not using the mute button for all it’s worth.</h3> \n<p>Nobody wants to accidentally leave their microphone on so everyone can hear them yell to a roommate or ask a pet to stop making noise. It’s not a huge faux pas, but there are easy ways to avoid this short-lived but all-too-common mistake of not using the mute button for all that it’s worth.</p> \n<p>Pereira says, “When you’re not talking, mute yourself. The mute/unmute can also serve as a signal to indicate you’re ready to contribute and serve a [sic] helpful way for group members to ensure that those who are looking to speak are given the opportunity to be heard.”</p> \n<h3>10. Not having fun.</h3> \n<p>Although hosting can be stressful, Ladd and Stamp say that it’s essential to have fun.</p> \n<p>Ladd recalls a BLACKhub community check-in where attendees played a game called This or That. She says, “We did a Black History Month edition, so our game featured Black leaders in sports, film, entrepreneurship, and more. We had about eight different slides, and it was a fun, quick, and easy way to get everyone interacting and participating.”</p> \n<p>Stamp makes space for these moments during onboarding meetings as well: “Schedule optional coffee, lunch, or afternoon hang-outs to help attendees connect. This gives our new hires a space to get to know each other in an authentic and more personal way.”</p> \n<h2>Virtual Meetings Can Still Be Successful, Engaging, and Fulfilling</h2> \n<p>Although there are quite a few mistakes on this list, they are exactly that — mistakes. They aren’t the end of the world, and nobody will penalize you for them.</p> \n<p>Consider the advice from experienced HubSpotters, and you’ll likely find yourself hosting engaging virtual meetings that are just as impactful as those you can have in-person.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Take me to Projects\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fvirtual-meeting-mistakes&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 22 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png","linkMd5":"15eb090c1dbd18629878aee2b9dfb524","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-665_e57995fecd8b2257.webp","destWidth":395,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4668,"destBytes":6412,"author":"fneedle@hubspot.com (Flori Needle)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/03/04-49-30-665_e57995fecd8b2257.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/virtual.png?width=1012&name=virtual.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn93@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-50-02-360_c30e353c8d77abfb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ladd.png?width=1012&name=ladd.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn66@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-50-01-399_bd065c8736601d25.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1).png?width=1012&name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn82@2020_4/2021/04/03/04-49-55-434_ba434454c141eed8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1)-1.png?width=594&name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20-%20506x253%20(1)-1.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20jill-%20506x253%20(1).png?width=1012&name=Twitter%20-%20Quotes%20jill-%20506x253%20(1).png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn50@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-55-113_9524aa96f1bc7dcb.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fvirtual-meeting-mistakes&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn37@2020_1/2021/04/03/04-49-52-478_09428e9a4d6b8647.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370029},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"The Beginner’s Guide to Cost Per Acquisition (CPA)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cost-per-acquisition","description":"<p>In the paid acquisition world, clicks can seem like the holy grail. But if you really think about it, clicks only tell you if people arrive to your content. They don’t reveal whether <a href=\"https://www.marketingshowrunners.com/blog/new-marketing-mandate-hold-attention/\">they stayed or not</a>.</p>  \n<p>But how do you know if your content is engaging and emotionally resonant enough to persuade your audience to stay and ultimately buy your product or service? A metric that’s arguably the most indicative of this is conversions -- if your creative convinced someone to download or even buy something, then it was worth consuming.</p> \n<p>In your advertising campaigns, the best way to measure your content's converting capabilities&nbsp;and, in turn, its resonance is cost per acquisition. Read on to learn more about what exactly it is, the formula for calculating it, how its bidding process works, and some principles for crafting creative and convincing ad copy.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download&nbsp;Now: Free&nbsp;Marketing Reporting Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Most acquisition marketers prefer the cost per acquisition pricing model because they can set their definition of an acquisition before they start advertising and only have to pay when their desired acquisition or action happens.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>AdRank is calculated by multiplying your maximum cost per acquisition bid with the quality score of your ad, which is calculated by measuring your page’s relevance to the keyword, user experience, and click-through-rate. This means organizations can’t acquire the top ranking for any keyword they want just because they have the biggest ad budgets. Their content has to be engaging.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-adrank-calculation.jpeg?width=1000&amp;name=google-adrank-calculation.jpeg\" alt=\"Google AdRank calculation\" width=\"1000\" style=\"width: 1000px;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/articles/what-is-google-adwords\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>Google wants to incentivize the best advertisers to advertise the best content on their search engine results pages, so they reward ads that have high quality scores with higher ad rankings and lower cost per acquisition.</p> \n<p>In the same vein, they also want to discourage bad advertisers from advertising bad content, so advertisers with low quality scores will usually only acquire a high ad position if they pay a huge cost per acquisition bid. If they want to pay lower a cost per acquisition bid, they’ll have to settle with stooping at the bottom of the ad rankings.</p> \n<p>To generate as many conversions as possible within the limits of your advertising budget, consider using <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/6268632?hl=en\">Google’s target CPA bidding</a>. Target CPA bidding leverages machine learning to analyze your campaign’s historical conversion data, recommend an optimal average target CPA, and automatically optimize all your eligible bids to meet the average target CPA you set for all your campaigns.</p> \n<p>If you use target CPA bidding, some of your conversions may cost more than others because your quality score or the competition in your ad auction might fluctuate, but Google will try its hardest to keep your cost per acquisition as close to your average target CPA as possible.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How to Optimize Your Cost Per Acquisition Costs</h2> \n<p>Since your quality score, which is a metric that measures how positive and relevant of an experience your content provides, is the most influential determinant in securing a top ad ranking and, in turn, generating more conversions, the best way to optimize your cost per acquisition costs is crafting compelling ad and landing page copy.</p> \n<p>When you sit down to write ad or landing page copy, your goal should be to write something so captivating that it can grab the attention of a distracted millennial slouched in front of the TV, with their smartphone in one hand and a slice of pizza in the other.</p> \n<p>So what’s the process for persuading your audience to ignore that pizza, click on your ad, and convert on your landing page? Check out this three-step process for crafting compelling ad and landing page copy.</p> \n<h3>1. Pique your audience’s curiosity</h3> \n<p>A little intrigue goes a long way in marketing. Humans are <a href=\"https://www.verygoodcopy.com/hubspotcom/6-brain-triggers-copywriters-use-to-drive-sales\">biologically driven to investigate our world rather than respond to it</a>. And if you can evoke enough curiosity in your audience so they can’t help but satisfy it, they’ll click on your ad. So don’t reveal too much about your offer -- but make sure to highlight its benefits in a clear and convincing way.</p> \n<h3>2. Sell a feeling</h3> \n<p>Psychology tells us that <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2015/01/when-to-sell-with-facts-and-figures-and-when-to-appeal-to-emotions\">emotions drive our behavior, while logic justifies our actions after the fact</a>. Marketing confirms this theory -- humans associate the <a href=\"https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/inside-the-consumer-mind/201302/how-emotions-influence-what-we-buy\">same personality traits with brands as they do with people</a>. Choosing between two alternatives is like choosing your best friend or significant other. The people we decide to live our lives with make us feel something.</p> \n<p>This is also the reason why pitching a product’s features is a lousy attempt at persuasion. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-compelling-copy-tips?_ga=2.168469350.658143849.1557313293-876255941.1530763234\">Features only appeal to the logical part of your brain</a>, which science suggests doesn’t drive action nearly as well as appealing to the emotional part of your brain does. So don’t just get creative with your copy -- get emotional too.</p> \n<h3>3. Design a simple yet convincing landing page.</h3> \n<p>Just because you’ve grabbed someone’s attention with your ad doesn’t mean your work is done. You still need to design a compelling landing page that clearly conveys the value of our offer.</p> \n<p>In order to do this, consider piquing your audience’s curiosity with an intriguing headline and subheading, scrapping any external links from your landing page so visitors can only leave your paid acquisition funnel if they exit the page or convert, and test out video, which can explain the value of your offer in a more engaging way than text can.</p> \n<p>If you want to learn how HubSpot creates <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-templates?_ga=2.168469350.658143849.1557313293-876255941.1530763234\">landing pages that convert at 35% rate</a>, check out this blog post.</p> \n<h3>Instead of chasing clicks, pursue conversions.</h3> \n<p>Marketers will chase vanity metrics until the end of time, and you might feel pressured to do the same, especially when your peers clamor on about their astronomical growth in views or clicks.</p> \n<p>But if you ever feel tempted to jump on that train, remember, in marketing, the goal is to persuade someone to take your desired action. So incentivize your brand to resonate with your audience -- that’s the thing that actually keeps people on your content and prompts them to act. And make conversions, not clicks, your carrot.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\" marketing reporting templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcost-per-acquisition&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 20 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129.png","linkMd5":"19d345608cd9c75afa7c5398ff8baa75","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn71@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-595_e209ac0ef6ff3e34.webp","destWidth":476,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4464,"destBytes":7216,"author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn71@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-30-595_e209ac0ef6ff3e34.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-adrank-calculation.jpeg?width=1000&name=google-adrank-calculation.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn48@2020_2/2021/04/03/04-49-53-882_8528b0c79af54327.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn18@2020_5/2021/04/03/04-49-59-525_d6970030134c53c8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcost-per-acquisition&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn88@2020_6/2021/04/03/04-49-59-402_dd4bccb141b6148d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1617425370044},{"createdTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","updatedTime":"2021-04-03 12:49:30","title":"What is Clubhouse? [+Should Marketers Care?]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-clubhouse","description":"<p>In 2020, you might have heard your favorite influencers talking about a mysterious new social media app called Clubhouse.</p>  \n<p>But, unless you had a huge online following of your own, you might just be getting access to the app now.</p> \n<p>Until a few months ago, Clubhouse was a platform where <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/19/technology/clubby-silicon-valley-app-clubhouse.html\">big-name celebrities, company leaders, Silicon Valley investors, and some of the web's top global influencers</a>&nbsp;could have uncensored audio group chats about their lives, hobbies, work, or industries.</p> \n<p>Now, as the invite-only Clubhouse continues to gain media coverage and a growing pool of non-celebrity users, you might be wondering, “What the heck is it? And, how do I get in on the action?”</p> \n<p>Below, we’ll explain where Clubhouse came from, what it actually is, and the pros and cons of using it in your marketing strategy.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Download Now: Social Media Trends in 2021 [Free Report]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3dc1dfd9-2cb4-4498-8c57-19dbb5671820.png\"></a></p> \n<p>Clubhouse was launched in March 2020 by <a href=\"https://twitter.com/pdavison?lang=en\">Paul Davison</a>, who previously worked at companies including Pinterest and Google, and <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/rohanseth/\">Rohan Seth</a>, a former Google engineer. According to a <a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/welcoming-more-voices\">post</a>&nbsp;from Davison and Seth, Clubhouse was created after a handful of social media app experiments.</p> \n<p>\"After a lot of iteration in the audio space, we launched Clubhouse in March of last year,\" the <a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/welcoming-more-voices\">co-founders wrote</a>. \"Our goal was to build a social experience that felt more human—where instead of posting, you could gather with other people and talk. Our north star was to create something where you could close the app at the end of the session feeling better than you did when you opened it, because you had deepened friendships, met new people, and learned.\"</p> \n<p>Initially, Clubhouse was marketed to top-tier influencers, celebrities, Silicon Valley investors, and industry thought leaders, but recently opened to more general audiences. A few of the app's first <a href=\"https://www.vogue.com/article/everything-you-need-to-know-about-clubhouse#:~:text=Drake%20and%20Oprah%20Winfrey%20have%20joined&amp;text=Expect%20to%20hear%20from%20superstars,Ashton%20Kutcher%20and%20Chris%20Rock.\">high-profile users</a>&nbsp;include <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drake_(musician)\">Drake</a>, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/thesharkdaymond/status/1352281894663163905\">Daymond John</a>, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1L8mI0i4XSA\">Elon Musk</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001856/\">Oprah Winfrey</a>. Early on, these notable users were heard chatting in Rooms related to their interests, hobbies, causes, or industries.</p> \n<p>Despite Clubhouse's exclusivity, it was valued at <a href=\"https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/clubhouse-voice/company_financials\">$100 million</a>&nbsp;and received a $12 million investment from <a href=\"https://a16z.com/portfolio/\">Andreessen Horowitz</a>&nbsp;within a year of its launch.</p> \n<p>Most recently, Clubhouse has begun to give access to a larger pool of users by allowing each new member to invite two friends of their own. This has caused the user base to jump from <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/23/style/clubhouse-app-influencers.html#:~:text=Clubhouse%2C%20which%20took%20off%20in,investment%20led%20by%20Andreessen%20Horowitz.\">600,000 active users</a>&nbsp;in December 2020 to <a href=\"https://www.latimes.com/business/technology/story/2021-02-25/clubhouse-clout-land-grab-influencers\">more than 10 million</a>&nbsp;today.</p> \n<p>\"This past week, two million people around the world—musicians, scientists, creators, athletes, comedians, parents, entrepreneurs, stock traders, non-profit leaders, authors, artists, real estate agents, sports fans, and more—came to Clubhouse to talk, learn, laugh, be entertained, meet and connect. It’s the most exciting thing we’ve ever been a part of,\" wrote the <a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/welcoming-more-voices\">Clubhouse team</a>&nbsp;in a Jan. 24 blog post.</p> \n<h2>Why Many Marketers Are Just Learning About Clubhouse</h2> \n<p>Just hearing about Clubhouse now? You aren’t alone.</p> \n<p>As mentioned, Clubhouse was initially targeted to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/23/style/clubhouse-app-influencers.html#:~:text=Clubhouse%2C%20which%20took%20off%20in,investment%20led%20by%20Andreessen%20Horowitz.\">high-profile industry \"elites,\"</a>&nbsp;such as celebrities, CEOs, and top online influencers. For a while, these types of users were the only ones who could send and receive Clubhouse invites. On top of the app’s invite-only nature, it's only <a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/\">available to iPhone users</a>.</p> \n<p>While Clubhouse's early exclusivity made it interesting and alluring to the every-day social media user, it caused the app's awareness and user-base to grow at a slow but steady pace.</p> \n<p>Now that the app's become more accessible to social media users, it's been getting more awareness online and across news media. At this time, marketers are also starting to wonder if and how they could use Clubhouse -- or something like it -- in their strategy.</p> \n<p>In fact, many professionals, business leaders, and non-profit members can already be heard speaking in Rooms that discuss a topic related to their brand, industry, or mission.</p> \n<p>For example, a recent Room I dropped in on featured a group of lawyers aiming to offer education around patent protection. While this content was intriguing to listeners, it also could have brought each lawyer’s firm more awareness:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Lawyer Room on Clubhouse\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-1.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-1.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<p>Aside from marketers, major social media companies are also trying to take advantage of Clubhouse's audio social media trends.</p> \n<p>Shortly after Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-ceo-mark-zuckerberg-on-clubhouse-2021-2\">spoke in a Clubhouse Room</a>, the New York Times reported that his social media company <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/10/technology/facebook-building-product-clubhouse.html\">was allegedly building a similar audio platform</a>. Meanwhile, <a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/spaces\">Twitter</a>&nbsp;just began rolling out Twitter Spaces -- a drop-in audio feature with its app -- to a small group of beta testers.</p> \n<p>At the moment, Clubhouse seems like a promising way to network and build a community online, and its audio social format is already being adopted by competitors. However, in a time where we see a handful of new online platforms each year, is Clubhouse really a game-changer in the social media space? Or is it just another over-hyped app you shouldn't waste your marketing efforts on?</p> \n<p>Below, I'll give a brief description of how the platform works and then weigh the pros and cons of using Clubhouse for marketing. Prefer a video tutorial instead? Check out this helpful YouTube video.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WSF1OIU4L8M\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<h2>How Clubhouse Works</h2> \n<p>While we'll be publishing a detailed how-to guide for the Clubhouse platform, which we'll link to in this post later, here's a quick description of how some of the major features work.</p> \n<h3>Clubhouse's Main Tabs</h3> \n<p>When entering Clubhouse, users will find a homepage that highlights ongoing Rooms related to their interests or followers. They’ll also find search, message inbox, calendar, and notification icons in the upper navigation.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-3.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-3.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\" alt=\"Clubhouse homepage\"></p> \n<p>When tapping the search or \"Explore\" tab, users can scroll through a feed of suggested Rooms, Clubs, or people to follow. They can also use the search bar to find specific individuals or Clubs. However, it does not seem like users can search for specific Rooms yet.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Clubhouse Explore tab\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-2.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-2.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<p>If users can’t attend a Room when they're surfing the Clubhouse app but would like to drop into one later, they can tap the calendar icon.to see or create their scheduled Rooms.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Clubhouse scheduled room tab\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-4.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-4.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<h3>Clubhouse Rooms</h3> \n<p>Entering a Room is essentially like attending a webinar or Zoom meeting with no video and a partially muted audience.</p> \n<p>Attendees, who can join or leave a Room at any time, enter (or drop-in) as automatically muted listeners. If they'd like to speak or ask questions, they can tap the \"Raise Hand\" icon in the lower right corner of the Room page. Room moderators will then be notified of the hand raise request and can ignore it or unmute the attendee.</p> \n<p>Below is a look at what Clubhouse Rooms look like:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Clubhouse Room\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-26-31-PM.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-26-31-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<p>Visually, attendees of the Room can see only the profile photos and names of current participants, with moderators and speakers appearing at the top of the screen.</p> \n<p>Users and moderators can also add people they follow to a Room by tapping the \"+\" button in the lower navigation. This gives their friends a notification that they've been invited to a Room and enables them to open the app and join it directly.</p> \n<h3>Starting a Room</h3> \n<p>At the bottom of the homepage, users can also tap \"Start a Room\" to launch either a \"Closed\" chat open to specific people only, a \"Social\" chat open to all of a user's following, or an \"Open\" chat that anyone on Clubhouse can drop into.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Starting a clubhouse room\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<p>Users can also tap the nine-dot icon on the lower homepage navigation to have a private audio chat with specific followers who are online.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"clubhouse lower navigation\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-13-PM.png?width=400&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-13-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 400px;\" title=\"\" width=\"400\"></p> \n<p>Room moderators, who either launched the Room or were assigned to a moderator role after the Room launched, see a similar page that attendees see. However, they also get notifications of new Room attendees and a list of attendees who have raised their hand requesting to speak.</p> \n<p>One interesting thing to note is that a Room only ends when a moderator ends it or when the final moderator leaves it. Additionally, moderators who want to leave a Room without ending it can assign someone else to become a moderator. This means that a Room with multiple moderators can go on for hours or even days.</p> \n<p>Because of how long Rooms last, and the fact that attendees can join or exit whenever they want, you might regularly hear more seasoned Room moderators re-introduce themselves, what they’re discussing, and who else is speaking throughout a Room event.</p> \n<h3>Clubs and Networking</h3> \n<p>Aside from creating Rooms, users can also follow individual profiles of friends, influencers, or thought leaders in their industry.</p> \n<p>They can also join or create Clubs, which are groups of users with interest in specific topics, hobbies, or industries. Take a look at some of the Clubs that appeared when I searched, \"growth marketing.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Growth Marketing Clubs\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-58-PM.png?width=400&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-58-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 400px;\" title=\"\" width=\"400\"></p> \n<p>Once users join a Club, they can be notified if a Club's manager launches a Room related to its core topic. For example, if I were to join one of the Growth Marketing Clubs shown above, I'd be instantly notified if they hosted a Room on a growth marketing tactic.</p> \n<p><em>Want another example of a club to join? <a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/club/hubspot-marketing-club\">Check out and follow HubSpot's Marketing Club </a>to be notified about our latest rooms.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.joinclubhouse.com/club/hubspot-marketing-club\"><em><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-29%20at%203.16.56%20PM.png?width=530&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-29%20at%203.16.56%20PM.png\" alt=\"HubSpot Marketing Club\" width=\"530\" style=\"width: 530px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></em></a></p> \n<h2>The Pros and Cons of Clubhouse.</h2> \n<h3>Pros of Using Clubhouse</h3> \n<h4>1. Clubhouse could help brands build trust and community.</h4> \n<p>In 2020, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-changed-brands-this-year?_ga=2.184373603.419613483.1613574184-1359294572.1613574184\">consumers began to favor companies with authentic, trustworthy messaging</a>&nbsp;over big-name companies with decades of brand loyalty. This shift will likely continue through 2021.</p> \n<p>Why? In a time of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-changed-brands-this-year?_ga=2.184373603.419613483.1613574184-1359294572.1613574184\">financial uncertainty and constant news events</a>, consumers want to know that brands care about their customers and share values with them. While creating a live, uncensored, unscripted Room related to your brand's industry might sound nerve-wracking, it could help some brands seem more authentic and trustworthy.</p> \n<p>\"Clubhouse offers a lot of opportunities for connection with celebrities, a vast variety of people in different industries, and even close friends,\" says Krystal Wu, HubSpot's social media community manager. \"It opens the door for live conversations allowing people to be vulnerable within a community space. This type of connection is unique to deliver audio content with small to large groups of people. Its unscripted content that anyone can be a part of.”</p> \n<p>Brands that use Clubhouse could earn credibility by discussing topics they're experts on. But, they could also earn trust because they've made themselves available to listen and talk candidly with their audiences.</p> \n<h4>2. The app's content is always evolving.</h4> \n<p>While the app initially hosted conversations related to entertainment, business, and technology due to its initial target audience, the audio content on the platform has broadened and evolved</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/10/black-users-turned-social-app-clubhouse-from-drab-to-fun.html\">CNBC recently reported</a>&nbsp;that some of Clubhouse's most engaging Rooms have been launched by innovative Black creatives who've done heavy experimentation on the platform.</p> \n<p>For example, instead of hosting a chat or discussion, one group of Black performers <a href=\"https://www.the-prestige-magazine.com/2021/01/01/black-creatives-brought-joy-to-the-world-with-lion-king-clubhouse/\">hosted an audio-only production of Disney's \"The Lion King.\"</a>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>While there isn't a recording of the Clubhouse performance, led by <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/noelle-chesnut-whitmore-1b379222/\">Noelle Chesnut Whitmore</a>, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/kam_dela?lang=en\">Kam DeLa</a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/iambomanix/?hl=en\">Bomani X,</a>&nbsp;here's a screenshot from the event, which shows each Room moderator as the character they played:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"The Lion King Room on Clubhouse\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-99-PM.png?width=300&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-99-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 300px;\" title=\"\" width=\"300\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><a href=\"https://jocksandstilettojill.com/professional-athletes/clubhouse-app-presents-1st-audio-performance-of-the-lion-king/\" style=\"font-size: 9px;\">Image Source</a></em></p> \n<p>\"What started as a random conversation on Clubhouse has scaled to something much greater. We have so many talented people contributing their time and energy to this performance,\" <a href=\"https://www.prlog.org/12851920-lion-king-event-launches-on-clubhouse-app-to-spread-joy-in-the-digital-space.html\">Whitmore said in a press release</a>. \"Our goal is just to spread some joy to people through these events. I never imagined this would get such a huge response.\"</p> \n<p>In another example, a <a href=\"https://loopstore.com/\">cocktail brand called Loop</a>&nbsp;hosted a Room that encouraged participants to have a cocktail and join a casual conversation with no specific topic. While this strategy is less structured, it enables people who want to learn more about the brand or just want to chat with other cocktail drinkers to connect.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-26-63-PM.png?width=300&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-26-63-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 300px;\" title=\"\" width=\"300\"></p> \n<p>Because Clubhouse is fairly new, there aren't major content-related expectations just yet. This means that anyone from any group, industry, non-profit, or brand can experiment with it and learn what's truly engaging to the app's growing audience.</p> \n<h4>3. The app is primed for thought leadership.</h4> \n<p>Clubhouse's user base was built around influencers and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-thought-leadership\">thought leaders</a>. This means that users are likely coming to the app to hear the latest tips, exclusive information, or discussions straight from industry experts.</p> \n<p>For example, the scheduled Room shown below features <a href=\"https://www.coinbase.com/plp/nar3?utm_source=google_search_b&amp;utm_medium=cpc&amp;utm_campaign=1711534994&amp;utm_content=68048698078&amp;utm_term=coinbase&amp;utm_creative=409186026435&amp;cb_device=c&amp;cb_placement=&amp;cb_country=us&amp;cb_city=open&amp;cb_language=en_us&amp;gclid=Cj0KCQiA1KiBBhCcARIsAPWqoSp23MoI-xsL96keTFSV7Qn3_exrSyCcBznpfnOKNchkT2ugtu-ryUUaApM5EALw_wcB\">Coinbase</a>&nbsp;Co-Founder and&nbsp;CEO <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/barmstrong/\">Brian Armstrong</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"Coinbase founder interview\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-31-PM.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20is%20Clubhouse%3F%20%5B+Should%20Marketers%20Care%3F%5D-Feb-17-2021-03-03-25-31-PM.png\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; width: 200px;\" title=\"\" width=\"200\"></p> \n<p>In a Clubhouse Room like the one shown above, users could learn more about a brand like Coinbase and ask its leader questions about the company or its industry. Through Rooms like this, Coinbase and other brands could boost both company awareness and credibility with audiences who listen.</p> \n<h4>4. Audiences want online communities and audio content.</h4> \n<p>In the last year, people who were stuck at home turned to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-sign-up-for-webinars\">webinars</a>, <a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=virtual+event+hubspot+blog&amp;oq=virtual+event+hubspot+blog&amp;aqs=chrome..69i57j0i22i30j69i60j69i64l3.5767j0j4&amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;ie=UTF-8\">virtual events</a>, and<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/examples-of-virtual-services\">&nbsp;other online experiences</a>&nbsp;to learn more about their interests, hear from others in their industry, or just feel a sense of connection to people outside of their households.</p> \n<p>But, while virtual events were beneficial for many, most of us eventually dealt with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/protect-mental-health-when-remote?_ga=2.210195792.419613483.1613574184-1359294572.1613574184\">screen fatigue</a>.</p> \n<p>Because too much screentime can be mentally draining, consumers also checked out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-stats?_ga=2.210195792.419613483.1613574184-1359294572.1613574184\">podcasts</a>&nbsp;or camera-free webinars. Now, these audiences could be primed for Clubhouse's audio-only nature.</p> \n<p>\"Clubhouse’s most appealing quality is that it's a break from the nonstop screen time we all exist in,\" says Kelly Hendrickson, HubSpot social media marketing manager. \"Clubhouse is also a wonderful place to have conversations among niche communities and topics.\"</p> \n<p>And, while consumers are craving personal connections and live content more than ever, many brands are trying to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-leverage-user-generated-content\">build stronger online communities</a>&nbsp;and launch <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/run-successful-virtual-conference?_ga=2.210195792.419613483.1613574184-1359294572.1613574184\">effective digital event strategies</a>.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, Clubhouse's audio-only layout could help brands meet and build an engaged community of fans on an interactive, authentic, and live platform.</p> \n<h3>Cons of Clubhouse</h3> \n<h4>1. The app still has limited audiences.</h4> \n<p>Ultimately, one of Clubhouse's biggest brand marketing flaws is also what makes it so intriguing: exclusivity.</p> \n<p>\"I am generally against anything that is invite-only as it creates a culture of 'others',\" Hendrickson says. \"Any time you need to be 'in the know' to have a seat at the table, how can you also be inclusive?\"</p> \n<p>While Clubhouse might pose unique group chat opportunities for community marketers when more people join, the audiences might still be too limited for some marketers at the moment. On top of this, the app is still unavailable to Android users.</p> \n<p>“Clubhouse actually hinders its capabilities because there are many talented potential users out there that are missing out all because they are on Android,” Wu says.</p> \n<p>If you're looking to only create content for the largest audiences possible, you might want to hold off on building a Clubhouse strategy right now. However, if you're only looking to experiment and see if you can reach the audiences it already has, it might be an interesting platform for your team to try.</p> \n<h4>2. Clubhouse could have strong audio-app competition.</h4> \n<p>Facebook and Twitter could be just the first platforms to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/10/technology/facebook-building-product-clubhouse.html\">create a similar audio drop-in experience</a>. And, while this hints that Clubhouse creators have stumbled upon a platform many social media users want, the big-name competition could also pose concerns about the platform's future.</p> \n<p>For example, if Facebook or another major competitor can create something similar that's less exclusive and allows iPhone and Android users, people might leave Clubhouse for a platform with a larger audience or more credibility in the social media world. If this happens, marketers who invest heavily in a Clubhouse strategy might need to do a sudden pivot.</p> \n<p>While this shouldn't scare you away from testing the platform if you think it's right for your brand, the competition is still important to keep in mind. If you are considering Clubhouse, continue to follow its competitors and determine how you could pivot your strategy to those platforms if your audiences start to flock there instead.</p> \n<h4>3. Clubhouse can feel like an \"unedited podcast.\"</h4> \n<p>\"Another challenge I think brands and individuals will have with Clubhouse is how it feels like an unedited podcast,\" says Hendrickson. \"That means you’re hearing all the great meat, but you also have to listen to the trimmings. It will be interesting to see if long term, people are okay with that in their content.\"</p> \n<p>If you're planning to experiment on Clubhouse, consider practicing a few conversation starters, how you'll enter the call, and determine what you'll do if you run into dead air, boring conversation, or off-topic discussion that draws attention away from your Room's goal.</p> \n<p>Although Rooms are live and unscripted, having a gameplan will help you moderate an effective, higher-quality conversation than users might find in other Rooms.</p> \n<h4>4. Brands could be too vulnerable.</h4> \n<p>Certain generations, like Gen Z,<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/millennials-vs-gen-z\">&nbsp;crave authenticity from people and brands they follow</a>&nbsp;on social media. With an app like Clubhouse, brands could create Rooms or Clubs related to their industry that include thought leaders, prospects, and even clients that want to talk with them in a live, unfiltered way.</p> \n<p>However, while Clubhouse's high level of unscripted authenticity has intrigued both marketers and prospective users, it also could put brands in vulnerable positions. Wu describes this as “a balance between good and evil.”</p> \n<p>Within a year of its launch, Clubhouse's live nature has already led to brand-related controversies.</p> \n<p>For example, in February, <a href=\"https://www.tesla.com/elon-musk\">Elon Musk</a>, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, dropped into a Room with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/vladtenev?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor\">Robinhood Markets CEO Vlad Tenev</a>&nbsp;and raised his hand. When he was invited to speak by the Room's moderators, Musk began intensely questioning Tenev and asked him to explain why his stock-trading company <a href=\"https://blog.robinhood.com/news/2021/1/28/an-update-on-market-volatility\">stopped its users from buying and selling GameStop and other manipulated stocks</a>. You can hear the line of questioning in the video below:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.5%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/1L8mI0i4XSA?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>While Robinhood's CEO remained calm and collected throughout the chat, some brands might not have well-trained speakers who would react as calmly or professionally to this surprising scenario.</p> \n<p>Additionally, although Clubhouse doesn't allow users to record, many either downloaded screen-recording apps or filmed their phones with another video recording device. Because of this, Musk and Tenev's conversation was covered by the media within hours.</p> \n<p>Even though conversations cannot be replayed or recorded in the Clubhouse app itself, marketers on the app must remember that they're live and anything they say could easily be streamed or quoted in seconds. Because of this, Room hosts should prepare themselves so that they can answer both easy and challenging questions from audience members. Moderators should also determine what they'll do or how they'll react if an unmuted audience member says something controversial or unexpected.</p> \n<h2>Is Clubhouse right for you?</h2> \n<p>In its current state, Clubhouse could offer some major awareness and community-building benefits to brands. But, because of how new it is, it also poses some challenges and cons to companies that want to reach the largest audiences possible. Ultimately, while some companies might thrive on it, others might realize that it isn't the best platform for their goals just yet.</p> \n<p>As with any new social media platform, you'll want to spend some time on Clubhouse and see what the app has to offer before putting time and effort into using it.</p> \n<p>At this point, it could be wise to see if one of your friends or colleagues can send you a Clubhouse invite so you can familiarize yourself with the app. If you can't log on, be sure to continue following the news around it.</p> \n<p>As you surf through the app or read Clubhouse news coverage, ask yourself questions like these:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Are topics related to your product or industry widely discussed on the platform?</li> \n <li>Are there any thought leaders or company experts you could host a panel or two with to boost your awareness or credibility on Clubhouse?</li> \n <li>Are our competitors using Clubhouse? And, if so, can we create stronger Room experiences than they can?</li> \n <li>Do you already use marketing strategies that could be adapted to an audio-only platform, such as live video Q&amp;As, webinars, or virtual events?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>With questions like those above, you can determine if you'll be able to create scalable and engaging content for this social media platform.</p> \n<p>Can't get access to Clubhouse just yet? Don't worry. We'll continue to cover it on the HubSpot Blog so you'll be ready when you do.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published Feb. 17, 2021, but was updated to add more HubSpot video coverage of Clubhouse on March 29, 2021.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5fc2491c-cd3c-4adb-ad3c-b082ce2793d3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \"
